What more is there to say about Portal 2 that hasn't already been said. It's perfect, there I said it. Taking everything its predecessor presented and upgrading it in every way, the puzzles, soundtrack, level design, and overall retro/ apocalyptic vibe the game presents makes it superior to the first game in every way (not at all meant to knock Portal, as I love that game too.)

The lovably moronic Wheatley, the maniacal yet sensitive Glad0s, and the character that is Cave Johnson are characters that have stuck with me for years. Still, to this day, I find myself quoting: "I don't want your damn lemons!," to confused friends and family members, much to my enjoyment.

Portal 2 is for many a straight up upgrade from the fist game, which is already an amazing title. Many things that lacked in the original are now masterfully inserted into the experience, like a fantastic story, marvellously written characters, lore, way more gameplay features and length as well as updated graphics and how to forget the co-op mode. But for me this game falls short of its predecesor, simply because in this one the atmosphere of lonelyness and discomfort are gone and it feels more like a normal game, a really good one, but not an experience that I will remember all of my life like the first. However, even though I think the first one is better, for many people this game will clearly be the best of the two, and the co-op mode is an spectacularly funny experience with your friends. A must play for sure, even moreso if you have friends who play.

A perfect sequel. Portal 2 expands the core gameplay that made its predecessor so beloved with new mechanics that add more depth to puzzles (the different gels are particularly interesting), adds a meaningful follow up plot and takes the time to immerse you in its word. I think the most impressive thing about portal 2 is how excellently it paces itself; puzzle room gauntlets are interspersed with big setpieces as well as more subdued exploration sections that progress the plot and build up the world. The first game was a concise series of interesting puzzles with some great writing as decoration. Portal 2 is a gripping plot with hilarious writing and uses the creative puzzle solving as decoration. The co-op mode is a completely distinct campaign with its own story and a further expansion of the mechanics, while somehow never being too convoluted or obtuse. It's everything a co-op campaign should be.

this is the third time i've purchased this game. first on xbox in 2012 when it came out. got it from the eb games (now gamestop) at fairview mall in toronto. played tf out of it, so much so that it felt like i had to pee all the time. totally psychological from the feeling of irritation of not being able to figure out the test chambers. true story; why would i make that up? i missed a few days of middle school. watched one of the hunger games movies in theatres and had to leave to pee like 5 times. the day before it happened i went to canada's wonderland and rode the leviathan for the first time. good times. i actually have to pee right now while i'm writing this review, but don't worry it's legit. i got portal 2 again for ps3 in 2021 for the trophies and to enjoy the game for the first time again after a few years of not really playing it. i've since trophy and achievement hunted it on both 360 and ps3. i did briefly play co-op on my ps3 in 2017 but it was my cousins copy of the game. i have now completed the story and achievement hunted from memory along the way on steam. only one i missed was pturretdactyl but i went back into challenge mode and got it after my game crashed after i beat the game. so would i recommend portal 2? absolutely. it's an 11/10. it's got some of the best writing, story, gameplay, atmosphere and environments of any videogame ever made. plus it's a dope puzzle game that gets you thinking... with portals. there's no cake though. and you never got to meet ratman. but it's okay. look, just don't pee if you feel like you need to but you don't actually have to.

After a failed escape from the Lab - Chel and his new comrade Whitley will still try to break through the many complex puzzles of the ruined institute - so that in the end each of them will achieve their goal!

[b]Pros:[/b] 
[*}+ Portals
[*}+ Achievements
[*}+ Single player game mode
[*}+ Co-op game mode
[*}+ Humor
[*}+ Challenging logic puzzles
[*}+ More action
[*}+ Easter eggs and secrets
[*}+ Community mods
[*}+ Half Life World
[*}+ Items in the user's inventory

[b]Minuses:[/b]
[*]- Lack of HL 3

[b]Total:[/b]
In fact, buying Portal 2, the player gets two games. Since playing in co-op with a friend is not just entertainment for a few minutes, or repetition of the plot - but for two. No - this is a completely separate story in which puzzles move to another level of complexity.
In case they seemed simple to you, I advise you to contact the workshops for custom tasks.
The game itself has undergone minor changes in graphic terms. The game has become much more dynamic and difficult, which was facilitated by the destruction of the laboratory in the first game. Thanks to Whitley, we will be able to learn a lot of the secrets of the Research Institute that the players have been guessing about.
The game is recommended for the acquisition and joint passage of both storylines.

Valve has done an incredibly good job world building for this game with little details that stick in the back of your mind where it comes in handy till the very end. The lore is also consistent within itself and other sources allowing a larger image to occur in our minds.  Even though the maps are massive they only follow the paths the player needs to walk, hinting in the correct direction to travel, sometimes its obvious and others we only subconsciously follow them. The puzzles themselves are rather challenging and often take time to step back and think allowing for a larger sense of achievement when you complete them.

Overall the game is highly enjoyable and I recommend playing till the very end.

This wasn't just a game, it was an experience. The characters are well written and the dialogue that isn't lore-based is humorous and always brings a smile to my face. If you haven't bought this game, please do. The puzzles are challenging, but rewarding. You feel like you've learned something every time a new mechanic is brought up, and the game is overall put together very well. 10/10 game.

While being the more robust counterpart to Portal and it's series with how much it adds and changes, it's still grown massively as a series. The amount of love that this sequel of a gem gets alone is extremely surprising. The amount of character buildup, realizations, humor and killer level design that was put into a simple puzzle game really goes to show that Valve really cares about the games they make. While the story may be pretty simple from a regular gamer's perspective, the story is still interesting to look into and research, especially when there's unanswered questions involved that are definitely answerable with theories, in-game secrets, and more. The introduction of new gimmicks really adds to the experience overall and makes it feel expansive, rather than feeling like a game where you do puzzles while a robot is literally trying to murder you, although that is the same case for both games. Twice in this game alone. The introduction of Wheatley as a character adds so much, especially since in the end, you get to partner up with both Wheatley and GladOS, where they come up with strategies to basically artificially kill each other, while Chell is just progressing through, trying to find a way out. I won't talk about the ending in this review because the ending is actually unexpected, and proudly admits to reusing the GladOS final boss by showcasing how the game and the boss design has been heavily upgraded. Neither of the Portal games offer replayability in most cases, however even if it's a single playthrough game, it still delivers as a fantastic game, and is truly the 2.0 of Portal.

A sequel is a work of literature, film, theatre, television, music or video game that continues the story of, or expands upon, some earlier work. In the common context of a narrative work of fiction, a sequel portrays events set in the same fictional universe as an earlier work, usually chronologically following the events of that work.[1]

In many cases, the sequel continues elements of the original story, often with the same characters and settings. A sequel can lead to a series, in which key elements appear repeatedly. Although the difference between more than one sequel and a series is somewhat arbitrary, it is clear that some media franchises have enough sequels to become a series, whether originally planned as such or not.[citation needed]

[h1] Game Details [/h1]
[list]
	[*]   [b] Game Name: [/b] Portal 2
	[*]   [b] Game Release: [/b] 2011
	[*]   [b] Genre Tags: [/b] Puzzle, Story Rich, Atmospheric, Platformer, Co-op
	[*]   [b] Estimated Playtime: [/b] 8-10+ Hours
	[*]   [b] Personal Rating: [/b] 9/10
[/list]

[h1] Review [/h1]
[b] Summary - [/b] Portal 2 is the sequel to the award winning and hugely successful Portal developed by Valve Corporation. It features a single-player story set after the events of Portal's story; and a brand-new Co-op game mode, featuring additional test chambers designed specifically for Cooperative play. Portal 2 takes place an indeterminate amount of time, somewhere between 50 and 50,000 years, after the events of Portal, which saw Chell destroying the sentient computer GLaDOS, and landing outside the facility, only to be dragged back inside of Aperture Science where she was ultimately placed in a Relaxation Chamber by Doug Rattman for the indefinite future.

[b] Story - [/b] First I must say Portal 2 has a masterpiece of an intro! The story brought back GLaDOS (which I'm really glad to see come back). You will find many interesting twists through your playthrough and I honestly really enjoyed it. It’s a big step up from the previous game and a longer story which I'm really thankful for. I felt like the first Portal game was a bit too short so Portal 2 fixes that and makes the story really fun with more dark humor.

[b] Gameplay - [/b] While Portal had some amazing and unique mechanics, Portal 2 ups the craziness even more! Physics plays an even better role in this game and it makes the game even harder when you get into the later stages. The environments are so stunning and a big step up from the previous game. You still have the same tool from the previous game, which is great and Portal 2 doesn’t add any weird mechanics for you to use and still keeps it simple. The gameplay is still a masterpiece just like the first Portal, but with more puzzles to mess with, so no complaints here. Ever wanted to play Portal with your friend? You are in luck! Portal 2 now has a cooperative mode, and I must say it is absolutely incredible. So easy to set up and download maps from the Steam Workshop. I mean it’s Valve, they never really mess up, so no surprises. Honestly Portal 2 is just ahead of its time.

[b] Difficulty - [/b] When I reviewed Portal, my biggest issue was the puzzles, and how easy they were (and I'm really bad at puzzles). Luckily Portal 2 fixes all these problems. You will still find some easy ones here and there throughout the campaign, but my goodness some of them made me use my brain meats a little too hard. Some puzzles in my opinion, were really challenging and people who love puzzles will absolutely love this game a ton. User created maps are also really challenging and bring so much replayability to this game.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Really fun story
	[*] Funny dark humor
	[*] Amazing level design
	[*] Gorgeous graphics for 2011
	[*] Co-op puzzle game
	[*] Really challenging at times
	[*] Amazing mod support
[/list]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] The second half of the story felt slow
	[*] Co-op with randoms can be a hit or miss
[/list]

From chapter 6-7, it felt like I wasn't playing Portal 2 anymore. (in a good way). This game is incredible and there's no denying it. It's jam-packed full of content and can get very creative.

Wheatley wasn't as random but it was cool when he popped on screen. And of course, the companion cube only appeared in one level but made a good appearance.

This game is truly a masterpiece, being one of the few sequels to be BETTER than the original.
If you have not already, i highly recommend picking it up, It's only $14.50 AUD. and is well worth the price.

Portal 2 is a 3D puzzle game that uses portal mechanics to solve levels and navigate through the game. You're probably familiar with it already unless you're very young or have lived under a rock for like... a long time. The puzzles vary in difficulty, but never feel unsolvable. The main reason to check this out is the humor, which was considered a bit dark at the time, but nowadays it's pretty tame compared to what's out there. It's witty and still holds up. 

I came back to this for a nostalgia trip in 2022, last having played in 2010 or so, and I thought I'd grind out the achievements this times. Everything was great until I realized that nearly half of them were co-op achievements. Now, Portal 2 was a big enough deal that it probably still has a fair enough player base (haven't looked into it), but I've got a feeling it's still going to be a pain due to the nature of some of the achievements. (One required pairing with someone who hasn't played co-op before and another requires playing with players specifically from your friends list.) I haven't decided if I'm going to bother yet, but that's really the only negative thing I have to say. It's a masterclass game in my opinion.

In the wake of Portals release in 2007, it would be an enormous and almost impossible task to create a successor worthy to sit on the same level and share the same remarks as "one of the greats". 

However, Valve being Valve,  responsible for creating the most successful video games in history did what they do best and created Portal 2.  Not only did this game build upon its predecessor in many different ways, it essentially became its equal, earning a legendary status and critical acclaim within the PC gaming world.

Portal 2 still draws upon it authentic roots from the original. The portal gun makes its return, along with the incredible mind blowing physics, scientific applied environments and off course the notorious puzzle platform to accompany. The levels are harder, contain more props than previously i.e lasers, beams and scientific created gels.  Rational problem solving skills and effective decision making are required to come to a solution, especially in the later levels. 

Portal 2, has an entirely new campaign that certainly draws upon the original, but explores the history and depth of Aperture Science.  It brings context to missing parts of the story in the original Portal as well as introducing new characters and of course Half-life related connections that fans will appreciate.

The level of graphical representation and colossal vastness of the levels is also incomprehensible. It gives the player an almost melancholy feeling of how such mega structures are built, a feeling of being trapped inside a huge void. Furthermore this is compounded when you plunge into the terrifying abyss into your travels. It gives you that Black Mesa perception, comparable to Aperture Science, both gargantuan complexes underneath, yet subtle from above like an iceberg.
 
The time differences were well observed during the game that linked the story together. Not just by technology advancements but also by the surrounding structural environment that seemed dilapidated and left behind like a hidden time machine.

One of the best highlights of  this game is its consistency to build upon the cross of deadpan and dark humour and it does not cease to amaze. Especially when between the main robotic characters, even filtering down to the types of robotic turrets, the dialogue is truly creative and reflects what we are to believe an unemotional AI would be. Bravo to Valve for the introduction of J. K. Simmons into the story line, I just knew that voice sounded familiar.. Spider man anyone?

I will not need to say anymore than what has not been said by numerous critics and outlets. Accolades, game awards, extremely positive reviews and reception. You would be silly as a wheel not to have played this game in the last decade and/or deciding to play it. 

A solid amount of hours you will spend in this game, with cooperative option included and community based maps, you can test your intellect and learn all you want until your bum cracks!

New to Portal? Play Portal 1. Portal 2 assumes you played the first game already, and will throw you into complex puzzles right away.
Speaking of the puzzles, they are really clever and still confuse me even after multiple playthroughs. When you're done with the campaign however, there's still more for you to do.
I suggest playing Portal Stories: Mel, or Portal Reloaded before jumping into the puzzle editor, as these games further add onto the knowledge Portal 2 sets up, and can help you make better puzzles.

That brings me to the Puzzle Editor, Portal 2's double-edged sword. Portal 2 offers a really easy to use and readily available puzzle editor, however this means the workshop is often flooded with really simple puzzles that are further recommended due to people voting for puzzles that they can beat instead of puzzles that are clever. This results in experienced players not having as much content, and those who make new content for experienced players finding their puzzles being buried under waves of puzzles that make Portal 1 look difficult.

Look, Portal 2  is a great game. I suggest you try it, but I also suggest you take a moment to better your skills before you start making content for the game. Play community made mods, try out some of the more popular and challenging puzzles. Just please, take a moment to dive into the rabbit hole of Portal 2's mechanics before jumping into the editor. There is so much to learn, and I honestly believe it still holds up even without the rose tinted glasses.

The Standard Engineer RIG is the most basic form of Resource Integration Gear available for engineers throughout the course of their employment. It closely resembles the Standard Astronaut RIG due to the fact that it is almost skin-tight and has a small projection system for holographic display.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Isaac's ID tag can be seen on the left of his chest while wearing the suit, but disappears when the RIG is upgraded.
From the beginning of the game, the suit appears to be badly worn and damaged. This pre-existing wear slowly disappears more and more as the suit is upgraded.
This suit only has 10 storage spaces, holding fewer supplies than any other suit.
The suit also made an appearance in the Previously on Dead Space feature for Dead Space 2, even appearing in the representation of Dead Space's ending.
Despite being put on like any normal helmet, the suit's helmet still forms an airtight seal, it could be speculated that it uses the same membrane system when the helmet is put on as the more advanced CEC Engineering Suit.

I do not like video games, but I cannot stop playing Portal 2. 

I asked my gamer partner if he could find me a game I actually like and BOY HOWDY does Portal 2 deliver. We started with coop games so he could teach me how to play as we went. As a true technophobic no0b who has never really played anything more complicated than Tetris, I can say that the way the game leads you through the steps and puzzles gradually is both fun and easy to understand. Now that I've discovered that I can play single player, I think my life as I knew it is over. I love this game so much and all I want to do is play it till I drop. The narrative is compelling and engaging if you want it to be, but negligible if you don't. The puzzles are challenging but not infuriatingly so. The mechanics of the game are fairly intuitive and there are only a few mechanical things you can do, so there's not much to master. 

We beat the game today and both of us - me, a known Luddite, and him, a seasoned gamer - were so sad it's over. It was fun and engaging for both of us, despite our different levels of experience. 

I may not like video games, but I LOVE Portal 2.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I was around 11 or 12 years old when I played this game for the first time. I remember liking the game quite a lot at the time that I was playing it, but for the life of me I couldn't pin down what exactly it was that made me like it so much. Of course there were the funny ramblings of Glados and Cave Johnson that I remember, and I remember how the game played, but it never occurred to me that this game was truly a special piece of media until I decided to replay it last year.

I hadn't played played the original Portal before I played Portal 2, and did not play it until years afterward when I got the Orange Box (a criminally underpriced collection of Valve's greatest games, and Half-Life Source) which had the Portal games in it. I decided to revisit Portal 2 after playing through Portal for the first time, and, even on revisit, a more mature me finally understood more of the writing qualities of the game while simultaneously feeling like I was being welcomed home by the gameplay, while still having it offer up a challenge due to my years of absence, and while I liked Portal 2 the first time, replaying it felt magical. 

I wasn't too keen on the story of the Half-Life games (and those games are still really good, don't get me wrong), but the snappy writing of Portal 2, the environment to compliment it, and the themes that tie it all together combined to make not only a good story, but also a good way of telling it. The gameplay is surprisingly simple, with changes coming sparingly, yet the game still has a progressively challenging and fun cycle that tests the limits you have with your portal gun. It is a superb single player experience whether you are a casual or hardcore gamer, and whether you prefer gameplay or story. Wheatley, Glados, and Cave Johnson were all hysterical to listen to, yet endearing in their own ways.

Furthermore, Portal 2 not only stands alone as a fantastic game, but also as a sequel that improves upon its series. It puts many story beats of the original Portal into a new context, turning what was a funny little puzzle game with a creepy twist into a riveting story that wraps itself up in a satisfying way. Unlike some of Valve's other titles, you don't really see an outcry for Portal 3, because Portal 2 sufficiently ends its story and caps it off with the most fire breakup song known to man, which is one of the best endings to a series that anyone could ask for.

However, what truly makes Portal 2 a special game is in its versatility. This is a game that is easily recommendable to everyone, (unless you are allergic to puzzles or terrified of robots, I guess). 

It's campaign provides fun on all fronts, and the singleplayer experience alone is worth the 10 dollars, even though the campaign only takes 5-7 hours to go through. However, its nature as a precision puzzle game with numerous quirks in the physics engine allows for a very fun speedrunning experience that's easy to learn, but hard to master.

All of this doesn't even begin to introduce the multiplayer aspects of Portal 2. You can choose to team up with a friend and tackle the co-op game mode, which itself holds hilarious writing and fun gameplay that requires coordination between you two that can improve your teamwork for other multiplayer games, or result in sabotage that leaves you both laughing by the end. Furthermore, you can flex your creative muscles by designing your own levels for others to enjoy, and enjoy the levels of others when the base game tires you out, by proxy.

I tend not to recommend games based on my own personal enjoyment of them, but by how much they can be enjoyed by others, and the scope of who is likely to enjoy it. Some of my favorite games of all time are slow-burning, turn-based JRPGs, but oftentimes they can only really be recommended to a particular demographic. Portal 2 is one of the few games that, I feel, can be recommended to just about anyone. Whether they are picking up a controller for the first time or a seasoned veteran of a variety of genres, Whether they play games for laid-back fun or top notch competition, whether they enjoy a slow burning story or complex and fast-paced gameplay, or whether they wish to consume the work of others or showcase their own creations, Portal 2 is a game that can scratch any itch, all at an affordable price with content that can last as long as you need it to.

I understand that another positive review on Portal 2 is just a drop in the bucket for a game that receives near-universal praise, but these were thoughts I just wanted to put into words for a game that I think warrants all of the praise it gets, and sometimes I think people need to step back and remember what makes games like Portal 2 so special.

This game is (at most) 10 dollars, you'd be foolish to even consider not buying it, if you somehow don't have it already.

You are curious about the game Portal 2? It is just an awesome game, developed by Valve in 2011. Though it's quite old for a game, it is still awesome for modern standards. The Game is built around the Portal universe, but you don't have to play the first part (but I recommend it). It is not as buggy as the previous part, for example, you can't shoot a portal if you're inside a portal.

Lost inside the puzzle rooms is sometimes your lot. Even though it's sometimes quite complicated to find the solution for the puzzles (especially with the gels -> it still destroys my brain), it is still awesome.

The re is a workshop with a strong community with awesome puzzles which are often better than Valve's puzzles (which are still amazing). There is also a coop mode which is pretty fun if you have friends.

Game play is also awesome. There is a story that is quite good and the level editor is the most amazing thing I've ever seen. It is possible to build quite complex puzzle rooms but you also have the option to build complex logical contraptions. For example, I buildt a four-bit full adder and included it inside a puzzle (which is quite fun imo). You can find it in my workshop.

So originally this review was one of those copy paste review things but after some consideration i've decided to delete that old review. This game means too much to me to just play it of as "just another game" cause it isn't! Portal 2 made me realize the quality that games should strive to go after. Of course this is just my opinion but i think that those who look at older games and say "Eww oLd GaMe BaD!" are idiots.
(Also this review will have minor spoilers)

Portal 2 is a 3D puzzle platformer set after the original portal (btw portal 1 is also very good). It mostly follow the same gameplay loop the original game had but instead of the clean, sterile look of the first game, we now instead navigate through a more old, run down facility, where veggitation grows everywhere. It's quite a different feel. This is an excellent way to showcase the world without GLADOS, and how us defeating her in the first game really shut down the whole facility. Also, as always, the portal and movement feels very good and is a massive improvement over the first game.

Anyway let's discuss the story. 

(Here is where there is A LOT of spoilers so if you wanna buy it DONT READ THIS)

The game begins with us waking up in our sleeping chambers, but something isn't quite right. The voice that normaly says how long you've been in stasis for glitches out implying that we may be hundreds of years in the future! Then we get introduced to the greatest ball in all of gaming. Ladies and gentlemen and whatever genders there now are, I present Wheatley! (voiced by Stephen Merchant) He adds alott of charm into what otherwise is like a lonely test facility. Anyways in a really cool cutscene (playable of course since valve) he gets you out of the stasis chamber and into the old testing areas. We traverse through it until we find THE PORTAL GUN (yellow not included) With this we finally delve into the core gameplay and traverse old test chambers that some may find familiar. After a bit of puzzling we step into the room where GLADOS's corpse lies, lifeless. Wheatley remarks on how a human defeated her (not knowing that was us). We continue on until we find the control room were Wheatly quotes god, makes the elevatior move upwards and you know just REACTIVATING GLADOS! In a stunning cutscene we see how GLADOS makes herself whole again and then focuses on you. She remarks on how long it's been and tosses Wheatley aside. Guess what? Testing time!!! Which also means the DUAL PORTAL GUN!!! Finally it's time to test as GLADOS does her best to repair the broken test chambers. After alot of bullying recieved from GLADOS, Wheatly comes to the rescue! You and Wheatly make a run for it and end up in the manufacturing and closed of section of the facility. It is here were Wheatley makes a plan on how to defeat GLADOS! So you go aroung and destroy the Turret manufacuring aswell as her "deadly neurotoxin". With all of these gone you head back to once again face GLADOS. As she realizes what you've done you plug Wheatly into the core transfer to give Wheatley control of the facility. You end up succeeding and Wheatley begins to send you up the victory elevator but oh no ohhh no! The twist you didn't see coming! He becomes EVIL! He begins to pull the elevator downwards. After turning GLADOS into a potato battery he smacks you down, breaking the elevator, causing you to fall down the very long elevator shaft. You eventually land and see GLADOS getting kidnapped by a bird. You begin traversing these large rooms to eventually discover that this was the original Aperture science testing facilities. Then you hear old speaker recordings echoing throughout the large caves. None other than Cave Johnson/J.K SIMMONS! WHOOOOOO! Oh and his assistant Caroline but she totaly isn't that important. While traversing through the test chambers you hear the slow downfall of Apeture, and get new game mechanics! After some time you arrive on a bridge, where Cave J delivers one of the most famous video game quotes of all time,

"Alright, I've been thinking. When life gives you lemons, don't make lemonade. Make life take the lemons back! Get mad! I don't want your damn lemons! What am I supposed to do with these?! Demand to see life's manager! Make life rue the day it thought it could give Cave Johnson lemons! Do you know who I am? I'm the man who's gonna burn your house down! With the lemons! I'm gonna get my engineers to invent a combustible lemon that burns your house down!"

trange as it may seem to start a five-star review on a note of concern, I worry about Valve. It's not that I think the developer has put a foot wrong so far, or that its latest release won't meet the impossibly high expectations of its audience. On the whole, the titles that Valve has produced have been critically lauded and have sold very respectably.

But if the history of art and entertainment has taught us one thing it is this: if you habitually make genius look easy, audiences and critics will round on you if you stumble, even more viciously than they would have done if your track record was of a mediocre quality. Valve's winning streak has to get snapped at some point, doesn't it? And if it does, the knives will be out in force.
Well, thankfully, Portal 2 isn't the game that's going to cause this, which is remarkable when you consider it's arguably the sequel of 2011 with the toughest act to follow. The first Portal, released in 2007 as part of the Orange Box, was a short, ingenious puzzler wrapped up in first-person-shooter mechanics, underpinned by a darkly comic story about scientific research taken to dangerous extremes. The game seemed like lightning in a bottle and a sequel sounded unnecessary. Still, Valve has managed to go one better than what its team created before, and then built on its impressive foundations.

Portal 2 kicks off with player waking up in the Aperture Laboratories, the human behaviour research facility from the first game, and finding out very quickly that things have gone haywire. Aperture is a wreck: without GlaDOS – Portal 1's female AI antagonist – to run things, the facility is in an advanced state of disrepair. Walls are crumbling, test chambers malfunction and every room the player moves through is riddled with smashed windows, natural overgrowth and broken machinery. In the opening stages of the game, players are introduced to Wheatly, a stammering, motor-mouthed droid voiced by Stephen Merchant, and reacquainted with the Portal Gun, which creates interconnecting portals capable of bending distances, and physics, in their environment.

They're also soon reunited with GlaDOS, who takes umbrage at their presence and decides that a new round of potentially lethal tests is in order.

While the set-up will sound incredibly familiar to Portal veterans, Portal 2 is hardly a retread of the first game. Yes, using the Portal Gun to navigate one's way through every new environment is the core premise of the game – and cubes, gun turrets, floating platforms and pressure pads all make a return. But Valve has added some mind-bending mechanics and tools to the mix.
As the player advances through the Apeture Labs they're introduced to new items that the research facility has created to exercise their grey matter and potentially kill them off. There are Hard Light Bridges, which can create walkways or block off the sensors of lasers and gun turrets. There are Aerial Faith Plates, which fling the player through the air. There's Propulsion Gel, which allows them to zoom across the floor, building momentum for jumps and portal leaps. Puddles of Repulsion Gel can create areas the player can bounce on– and the higher the ledge they drop from, the higher they'll fly through the air. White Gel can be sprayed on to surfaces to make them Portal Gun-friendly. Excursion funnels are blue tubes of anti-gravity, which gently transport the player from one end of the map to the other, and they too can be redirected and repositioned with the Portal Gun. Each new item is introduced gently, to let the player become familiar with its capabilities, and then Valve starts ramping up the difficulty.

The puzzle rooms are incredibly well designed in that there's no hard and fast rule with the game's difficulty curve. Once the tutorials are out of the way, it's down to every individual player's desire to break the code on each environment, which allows them to move from the entrance to the exit. Even if one player finds the solution to one particular room obvious, this doesn't mean that everyone else will, and some puzzles may take up to hour to solve. All the while GlaDOS pours scorn over the player's efforts, with a stream of insults that are petty, vindictive and immature – made more hilarious by her robotic, sing-song voice.

The humour in Portal 2 is another trump card in the game's well-paced, engrossing and unsettling story. Without giving too much of the game's plot away, the player will find Portal 2 funny throughout, but also faintly spinechilling. GlaDOS and Wheatly are by turns funny and monstrous and the Aperture Labs take on an increasingly oppressive atmosphere as the player ventures deeper into the facility, learning more about its origins. Meanwhile, the unseen character from the first Portal is still lurking behind the scenes, scrawling paranoid messages and horrific cartoons on the walls.

The game's main campaign is longer than in Portal 1, and arguably better too. Once that's over and done with, however, players can return to Aperture in the multiplayer. This mode is a standalone story starring two cute droids, Atlas and Peabody, who are sent testing by GlaDOS, and the series of puzzles they have to navigate depends on them working successfully as a team. While it may sound strange that a game offering such a successful solitary experience as Portal should include such a mode, it's actually delightful fun. Once again, the puzzles are well-balanced and brilliantly constructed and, GlaDOS has a new collection of insults.

Valve has created a masterpiece in Portal 2. The depth of content, the mind-bending mechanics and fantastic experience are almost certain to satisfy ardent fans of the first game; and to all newcomers to the series, it's as simple as this: prepare to have your mind blown. Over and over again.

I wanted to like this game. I loved the first one, and fully expected those feelings to carry over to the sequel. And it does have a lot going for it, you can really see the dedication the developers put into it and the lengths they went to to expand every part of the experience. We learn much more about the game's lore with Aperture Science, what they're actually about, and the true nature of GLaDOS. There are a bunch of new puzzle features like bounce gel, energy bridges, and stuff like that, which are very interesting and can be fun to play around with. And the game has more of a clear-cut, interesting story beyond just "do tests (and try to escape)." To be fair that is the basis of this game's plotline just as much as the first, but there is more depth to it, twists and turns, and more characters. 

My main issues with the game are 1) It is not nearly as intuitive in design as the first one, and 2) It is way too dark for the majority of the game. 

In Portal 1 the levels were generally very bright and clinical, you could see everything in a room and could much more easily parse out what the mechanics of the level were. In this one it feels like I'm constantly straining my eyes to try and figure out where I am or what the room around me looks like. There are long linear chase scenes where you race across catwalks and whatnot in the facility, and they made me feel frustrated and like I was missing things because I could hardly see where I was going. The problem was most egregious in the lower levels (pun intended) where large complex puzzles had to be solved in very low light. Several times I got stuck because I couldn't see where I was or got confused because I thought there was somewhere in the darkness I was supposed to try and reach, but there was nothing there.

This ties into the level design in general. In Portal 1 I enjoyed all of the levels (although I was impatient in the first couple levels to get a fully functional portal gun) and only got truly stuck one time. In this game I got stuck much more frequently and found myself getting more and more frustrated. With the first Portal I played the whole thing in only a couple of sessions and could hardly tear myself away from the game. With this one I found myself wanting to play it less and less. By the last third or so of the game I was no longer having much fun. I wanted to get to the end and see how the story concluded, but I wasn't enjoying myself on the levels themselves. I think this is related to the level design (being poorly-lit among other things) but also because I think the 2nd Portal game is much harder. There are a lot more mechanics and machines to remember and they interact in interesting ways. This isn't necessarily a bad thing (in fact it's probably a really good thing) but it got overwhelming for me and lessened my enjoyment.

The first portal game was generally a pretty relaxing experience for me; as previously mentioned I only got stuck once in the whole game and it was generally pretty simple for me to determine how to beat each level with some low-stakes experimentation. It was fun to see how the different mechanics worked together and it never took too long to determine the way forward. Maybe it's just that it was easier, and I'm sure many other players will welcome the added challenge. But each room took so much longer in Portal 2, and I died much more frequently. I got frustrated, and it honestly diminished my enjoyment. Say what you will about me complaining that a game was too hard, but I really liked Portal 1 because I thought it had a very good balance between interesting, complex levels and difficulty. This game lacks that, at least for me.

P.S. As a result of me taking so much longer to complete levels, as well as the greatly expanded NUMBER of levels in the 2nd game, it felt very very long to complete. If the levels were all as fun and intuitive as the original this wouldn't be a problem, and I understand to a point why there were so many because it introduced so many other kinds of mechanics and machines. It's wonderful that the developers wanted to include so many new and unique ideas. But it just seemed like way too much for me. If you see my # of hours played you'll see that this took twice as long to beat as the original. And honestly after all of that I feel too burnt out to really muster any enthusiasm for repeating the experience, much less recommending it to others.

TL;DR- respect the developer's efforts to expand the experience, but found the game frustrating, counter-intuitive, and not as fun as the original.



EDIT: Played the game through again, got a better set up where I could see the dark parts of the screen better. Its still kind of an issue in my opinion, but not a major one. Anyway, the game grew on me. I helped my little brother in his playthrough it as well, and we had fun. So I suppose I WOULD recommend it to others, as long as they understand that this game is noticeably more challenging than its predecessor.

It's Portal 2, there's little one can add about it that hasn't been said before. It might feel a bit short, but the comedic factor, soundtrack, atmosphere and gameplay ALL make up for it. Besides, there's even a co-op mode with plenty of missions (too bad I haven't anyone to play it with). You might need to buy the original Portal game to fully understand the story, but it's quite straightforward to understand even if you don't want to play through the first game. All in all, I'd honestly recommend this to anyone.

The original Portal had the element of surprise. Its style of first-person physics-based puzzle gameplay was unique. GLaDOS, the murderous robotic villain, was new and vibrant and evil in the most charming way. Cake jokes and songs about surviving dismemberment were still hilarious. It was short, succinct and essential. Creating a sequel without playing all the same notes and making it feel like Portal: The Longer Version is a tough task. For Valve, it's apparently no problem.
From the first moments of waking up in the rusting Aperture Science facility to right before the credits roll, Portal 2 rarely falters. The world is bigger, the story thicker, and the character development more surprising. The mania of GLaDOS, the facility's operator, is molded into unexpected forms alongside a host of brutally funny personalities. The history of the Aperture Science facility is filled in, character origins discussed, and though its pacing suffers as it occasionally strikes a more serious tone, an abundance of cruel jokes and cheerfully sincere death threats prevent it from losing its sarcastic charm. When you're not staring at your screen with wrinkled, pained expression on your face trying to figure out a puzzle, expect to be laughing.

Portal 2 may very well be the best first-person shooter of the decade it released. The sequel to the legendary Portal, which used incredible mechanics and a fair share of dark humor to captivate its players, Portal 2 simply improved on an already amazing title and literally made it perfect. Unlike the original, which focused primarily on the puzzling tests, this game also featured an incredible story, following the end of Portal. The mechanics alone make a great game, regardless of the way they are used: with your Aperture Laboratories Portal Gun, your protagonist (named Chell) can teleport in marvelous ways. Left click on the mouse, and a blue portal will shoot from your gun and land on the nearest wall, if it is portal conducting. Right click, and an orange portal will come out. You can now walk through either portal and teleport to the other. Some very fascinating concepts spring from this. For instance, if you drop from a ledge and fall into the blue portal on the floor, and you have an orange portal on the wall, you can fly out of the orange at a very fast speed onto another ledge.
The fully voice acted characters are quirky, fully formed, and at times, [REDACTED].
Honestly, the game is worth much more than $10, considering the sheer amount of work it took to create, the replayability, the entirely different co-op campaign, and the endless stream of community levels, plus the easy to use level creator, and of course, the lovely song sung by GladOs at the end.

I would like to say that you rarely see such a richness of events in the first hour spent playing the game: you get acquainted with the nervous Whitley robot trying to save you, demolish several gates, break the room in which you supposedly live, meet the GLADOS machine that you destroyed at the end of the last part and 
many more fun things!

ORIGINALITY:

At first glance, Portal 2 is not far from its predecessor, but this feeling is dispelled after a few tests. Speaking of tests! The local "brain breakers" are noticeably relieved, but some still make you think.

PLOT:

The plot is closely intertwined with the last part, similar characters, similar places. But it plays completely differently. In Portal, we spend 95% of the game time running around the laboratory, making holes in space and no plot twists. Here the plot takes up a significant part of the game.We run away from the evil "aunt" GLADOS, and almost an hour later, we find ourselves in the same position with her and are forced to help her. Plot twists are waiting for you everywhere, not even an hour of the game passes, as something does not change in the situation.
Many beautifully staged story clips are pleasing to the eye. Portal 2 has noticeably added in directing, which is worth only a fall from 4000m. or even the opening scene, where the game greets you very "friendly".

GAMEPLAY:

Portal 2 is the benchmark for video games in the Valve genre. Coming out in the distant 2011, I still want to go through it. Throughout this time, many games have borrowed certain features from "half life", which confirms the high level of this game, hundreds of games are equal to it. If for some reason you have not completed this game, then know that it is worth doing. If you like puzzles, you will enjoy it anyway, because this game has its own extraordinary magical atmosphere, this game can still pleasantly surprise you.

GRAPHIC ARTS:

Portal and Portal 2 are classic examples of games where the actual gameplay outperforms the graphics. In any of the games there is nothing particularly remarkable in terms of visual complexity, but the settings are instantly remembered. Bare white walls and ominously mocking voices have left their mark on many gamers. And we're pretty sure no one has forgotten about the crudely painted cake pieces covering some of the walls.Portal 2 creates an atmosphere with well-designed levels of graphics

SOUND AND MUSIC:

At the same time, Valve is honestly trying to complicate and deepen the original sound and music, for which a number of tricks of varying degrees of success have been invented. A must play for anyone with a computer. It's a solid piece of media, and easily one of the titans of AAA games two generations ago. The mechanics are simple but the tests can get really hard, especially if you're playing the community made chambers which are a great addition to the game and really add that bit of extra content the game needs. The story isn't very long, as was the case with most games in this era, but it's interesting for the time it lasts and surprisingly has a good variety in environments for a game located solely in a science facility. The co-op half of the game is also a really great addition and not only makes the levels considerably more challenging, but allows for some really fun and satisfying moments finally solving a really tough test chamber. I don't know the price of this game offhand but, whatever it is, it's worth it. There really is no other game like it.

I am a 50 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 13 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 26 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Portal 2 is the sequel to Portal and adds more puzzles and more fun.
At the beginning of Portal 2, Chell is awakened in a “long-term relaxation chamber” in Aperature Science by a little hilarious, British personality named Wheatley. Wheatley's goal is to help you escape, however you soon find out that GLaDOS is still alive. Chell is once again forced to use her portal gun to navigate the ruins of the facility and deal with the resurrected GLaDOS. The story takes some very interesting twists and turns along the way and the terrific dark humor of the first game remains intact.
The gameplay from the original game returns in all of its mind-bending glory. Players use the portal gun to shoot blue and orange colored portal holes onto walls to traverse over deadly pits, transport Weighted Storage Cubes to switches to open doors and lower elevators and redirect lasers. Additions to the gameplay include the propulsion and repulsion gels which do pretty much as they describe, either sliding the player off at great speed or sending them bouncing high into the air. In addition, players must redirect light bridges and conveyer beams with portals as well.
One of the most exciting new features in Portal 2 is the inclusion of co-op gameplay.
Co-op gameplay gets its own storyline and characters, Aperture Science robots ATLAS and P-Body, each armed with their own portal gun and even more challenging puzzles for the gamers to solve. You can either play with a friend (split-screen or online) or team up with a random player.
I highly recommend Portal 2 to anyone who is looking for a good fun game that will take up a few hours and even make you think instead of the average First Person Shooter. 
Overall, Portal 2 is a masterpiece and definitely worth the money.

Absolutely incredible puzzle platformer. This game is the highest rated Steam game of all time, and it is well deserving of that title. The story telling is amazing. Portal 1, as impactful as it was and still is, was only a glimpse into the unique identity Aperture Science would come to accrue. Apart from the still impressive portal gun mechanics, most of the bones constructing that first game's skeleton are obvious reapplications of Half-Life 2 assets. With the sequel, almost nothing like that is present at all--everything feels uniquely Portal. Some mechanics, like the red lasers, are both functional replacements and vast improvements over older, similar concepts (in this case, the energy balls.) There are also more efficient, not to mention cooler methods of building and releasing momentum for movement-heavy puzzles. Heck, functionally turrets are the exact same, but their placement is carefully calculated for minimum cheese and maximum squeeze, and it makes all the difference in the world. The Portal series really came into its own with this wildly innovative sequel, and no gamer's collection of experiences is complete without it.

tl;dr my key point here is how this game reinforced the series' identity, but in general, Portal 2 is mandatory gaming, go play now

I think I get it now. I think I understand why Portal 2 is the greatest game of all time. I don't know why it took me so long, but I get it now. It's the fact that the game has so much content, something is bound to appeal to you. People love the story of Portal 2 and how it recontextualizes the first game, for good reason. The story of what happened at Aperature captivates people, obviously. But the gameplay is relatively standard compared to the first game, with some new mechanics added. I'm not gonna get too into it, but it's very clear that the Multiplayer is a big factor as well, for good reason. It allows for so many unique ideas that wouldn't be possible in singleplayer. There's also a level creator, allowing you to do the obvious, allowing people to express their creative wings through portal. If you are a fan of first person shooters, multiplayer games, story-focused games, level creators, the like, something in Portal 2 will appeal to you. I whole-heartedly reccomend it.

I first started playing the Co-op of Portal 2 with my dad when I was twelve on our Xbox 360. I fell in love with the game and thought it beautiful that after watching my dad play the first game for years that the devs took the time to make a second game with a two-player feature. It was only later that I learned about the single-player mode and fell in love with that as well. The story was well-executed, with twists and turns and a heartwarming end. The concept was truly something special, and overall this game holds a special place in my heart to this day.
Years later, I bought a Portal board game for my dad, titled: Portal: the uncooperative cake acquisition game. With it came a free copy of Portal 2 for Steam. After asking my dad if he wanted it, to which he said no (he already owns the Orange Box), I was able to get my own free copy of the game. It's even better than I remember with the new(ish) Test Chamber Building feature.
Anyway, if you're reading this, know that I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes that "I DID IT!!!" feeling, anyone with a quick sense of humor with a taste for sarcasm, and anyone who just likes a good story. The brain-bending puzzles aren't for everyone, but at least try before you look up a tutorial.
Happy Testing!

Is this a masterpiece or what? First of all, go play the original if you haven’t yet.
Portal 2 is like the complete game after Portal being the beta version. So much more stuff is here. You have gels, you have the crazy bot lady, you have a new British bot guy, you learn about the history behind this crazy lab, you get an ending which you wouldn’t see coming in anyway. Jokes? Still there, even funnier. Launching yourself by jumping into portals? There’s more of that. It’s amazing how a story can be so stupid and serious in the same time. Puzzles are so innovative. I was so annoyed by seeing some similar puzzles in games over and over again but in Portal 2 there’s none of that shit. Portal has a unique style in puzzles which it commits to till the end of the game.
Now co-op is a whole other story. You can buy this game just for the co-op and not even play the single player. Remember that Portal style which gives you so much freedom to experiment every possible way? Well imagine doing that with a friend. You can get as stupid as you want and the game just does whatever you want. Every stage is a showcase of how creative the designers are and how they invite you to use your creativity as well.
I had a blast playing Portal 2 and definitely gonna go through it again soon. This is a must play for every gamer.

You will be challenged with critical thinking. You will have a damn good time. 

And then it will end, and you will be right back where you were: Looking for the next game to give you the dopamine hits you crave. But what you won't do? Regret playing this gem.

Portal 2 is a masterclass example of what a sequel to an already good game should be: more story and characterization, fun new mechanics that are mixing familiar with the unexplored, as well as better pacing and more content. Portal 2 offers exactly that!

Without getting into spoilers, you meet 2 wonderfully characterized, written, and voice-acted characters (well, 3 now that I think about it) that follow you throughout your journey, offering some nice dialogue and more world-building.

Gameplay has been enhanced; you got your classic Portal gameplay - portals, lasers, turrets, cubes and buttons, but Portal 2 introduces mechanics such as Repulsion gel (blue gel that makes your jumps higher, and is pretty bouncy, allowing you to jump great heights if you have fallen from enough of a drop), Propulsion gel (which makes you go faster, and as you might remember from the first Portal, you keep your momentum while entering portals), Conversion ges (this gel creates surfaces that can allow portals to be placed on them), as well as Excursion Tunnels (tunnels that propel you forward while you float in air). There's also solid light beams, that can be used as pathways since you can stand on them, as well as walls that can protect you from turrets.

There's also co-op - 2 players, 4 portals, which makes the gameplay even crazier!

All in all, a must-play for every gamer, an enjoyable experience through and through!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, go below, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I wish I were some master author so I could write Portal 2 a love-letter as a review to do justice to the experience it gave me when I played it - and, for all I know, which it could still offer if played again.

However, even if I had that capacity, Portal 2 might be most impactful if one knows as little as possible going in, similar to- although not quite to the same degree as- Portal 1.

In terms of story: [spoiler]If you're reading this review, the cat's most likely out of the bag for you at this point that the Portal series actually has[/spoiler] [spoiler]a universe and story to it, instead of necessarily being just a set of rooms in a computer space like Mario or Quake. If you didn't, I recommend booting up Portal 1 and playing it through before Portal 2. There actually are references to Portal 1's simple events, and while it isn't necessary to have played Portal 1 to understand the gameplay or what's going on, Portal 2's harkening to Portal 1 is in my opinion one of its most enrapturing aspects, and the fuller understanding is worth it.[/spoiler]

In terms of gameplay: If you know Portal 1, you probably know the basics, and if anyone reading this doesn't, here they are: The player walks around in a 3D space, moving between rooms/chambers. You have a a very light hop and the ability to grab things; you're introduced eventually to the signature "weapon" of the game, the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, and its signature ability to make quantum space holes on (most) walls becomes fundamental to reaching point B of each chamber [spoiler]- and on occasion, other goals that deviate a little bit from getting to a particular location.[/spoiler]

With this simple formula, and various environments that can adapt to your actions, Portal 2 manages to reintroduce familiar gameplay with a new attitude. [spoiler]It isn't all more of the same, though.[/spoiler] [spoiler]Aperture Science gradually reveals new tools, devices, and even substances as you go deeper in, that create new gameplay and new possibilities. For me personally, these new things were so exciting that they are exciting to see as story developments.[/spoiler]

The visuals and audio in Portal 2 are sublime and would arguably merit their own review. Surfaces are successfully shown as severely decripit without being over the top. The architecture, the test-intentional objects (cubes, switches, etc.), and  the Cheli-Shayim of Aperture Science have their own distinctive visual identity, each individual item with intricacies that seem interesting in their own right without being hammy, that stands out, and largely defines the eerie Portal experience and then goes on to fit inside thsi experience. Granted Portal 1 does the same; and yet Portal 2 still seems like Aperture Science from a new angle and with a new sight of vulnerability.

As for audio, eerie soft noise of the luft and the reverberation of sounds such as footsteps give the facility a spot in the uncanny middle ground between decay over time and the over-engineered cold industrial facility we met in the first game - all while retaining, largely, the sense of loneliness. The gameplay-sounds, such as blips for when buttons are activated, and the nearly-harsh pulse sound of a launched portal, the warbling of the portal pulse as it flies and the light burning sound of a portal already set, all seem to fit into what  you're actually doing in the world itself instead of being only for our ears and not for Chell's.

Add to this the voice acting on top of the writing, and Portal 2 is certainly a game to look for a chance to play with the volume on.

Each one of these merits - the audio, visuals, story, world-building, gameplay - deserve their own deep review, and all this doesn't even touch upon how they each serve each other.

If you have already played Portal 1, and you have decided there's anything at all about it you'd like more of, I definitely recommend giving Portal 2 a chance. That goes especially for the new highly affordable price, which is about the cost of a pound of beef at a local deli here in suburban Texas.

___

Oh, and by the way, I've only ever played single-player. Reader and I alike have no idea what wonders might also lie in store for the much-anticipated co-op mode. Consider this if you also have likewise-curious acquaintances who'd like to go a round with you.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

This is a complete masterpiece. They improved everything from Portal 1 and added a lot more content, especially the brand new co-op.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
As the name suggests, you create portals for solving puzzles and getting over obstacles. Since only two are present at a time and on certain surfaces, it limits our options and we need to think of a clever solution. In Portal 2 they added a lot of new mechanics to the puzzles: lasers, force-field beams, gels that increase your jump or speed, and much more. It adds a lot of complexity and increases the variety of puzzles this game can offer.

Now there are tons of stuff to do in Portal: singleplayer, challenges (if you want), co-op, and even workshop maps for both single-player and multiplayer. I was surprised that many community maps are on par with the original campaign, and some of them even have their own steam page.

[h1] Story [/h1]
One of the elements they really pulled out nicely is the story. It is now very deep and a lot more is revealed about the lore than in the prequel. You get to meet funny new characters that play a huge role in the plot along with GLaDOS. In addition, when I played Portal 1, it felt that most of the game was all about puzzles. Now, a lot is going on in every chamber. Each dialogue and action make you feel the story's progression, and add a lot to the atmosphere. 

[h1] Artstyle [/h1]
Absolutely wonderful. You can really see how their improved engine works at its best. The water reflection, high details, and ariel's perspective really make this game look realistic. In addition, the level design looks fantastic. What I love the most is the combination of green plants and a ruined environment. 

[h1] Co-op[/h1]
That feature alone makes the game worth even at full price. It is completely separate from the single-player in both story and maps. In co-op, both players must think, since there are puzzles that require them to be in separate positions. As a result, every player sees only part of the solution and their partner the complementary. Communication and coordination between the two-player are the keys to success.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
The single-player and the co-op can be completed in 10 hours each, and adding the workshop it can go to infinity and beyond. Portal 2 succeeds in every aspect and is truly worthy to be called a AAA game. I never write it in my reviews, but for me, this is really a 10/10.

Usability/Playability: The game is still playable because it is not a game known as the best graphics out there. It is known as a puzzle coop game and the game does not feel old for me. The graphics are still good and when you are playing with friends it is fun. 

Narrative/Story: Portal 2 is an after apocalyptic game in which you are controlling robots. There is no human left and an AI (Artificial Intelligence) experimenting on you with some puzzles. This game is still playable for me because it feels right when you are playing the story. The story is interesting and playable. 

Fun/Enjoyment: When you are playing with your friend it is fun because there are two humans and there are many more ideas for solving puzzles and it is easier to solve puzzles. It is fun in single-player too because the story is interesting, and gameplay is fun. 

Visual Aesthetics: Visuals are quite good for the 2011 release date game. It feels like you are really in an experiment, and you are the lab rat. But I think if there were some trees and something green it could be better because you are in a post-apocalyptic era and because of that there are no humans left. If there is no human left, there could be some trees bushes. There are security cameras, and they are watching you and tracking your movements and it feels like you are a lab rat again. 

Audio Aesthetics: Audio is helping players to feel right in the environment. The portal guns audio feels good, the robotic voice is feels good. But when you are moving you can hear just the steps. I think if there was a robotic leg sound it would be better. 

Challenges/Difficulty: It is a puzzle game so sometimes it is quite hard but mostly you can just see the way like there is a forty-five-degree platform. When you see this, you can just think it is part of the solution and you are trying this platform. If there were more similar objects it could be harder but game would be harder and playability would decrease.

An amazing sequel which surpasses the first game. The level design is incredible. The mechanics are brilliant. The game offers a variety of mind-bending puzzles with increasing difficulty but are properly balanced so they never appear Sisyphean. Despite the mechanics seeming limited in number, Valve cleverly designed the levels injecting novel and creative use of the mechanics, so the experience is anything but monotonous as you work through the puzzles alongside a gripping storyline. The production in terms of in-game characters and voice acting is legendary. 

Apart from this, there is a co-op mode. If you've gone through the story multiple times and want a challenge, the community has a lot to offer and you can play awesome community maps! There are some amazing community mods too like Portal Stories: Mel and Portal Reloaded which extend your gameplay experience further.

This game is pretty good, but not quite as good as Cinnamon Pull Apart Bread!

What you'll need:

- A 9x13 Pan (preferably glass)
- Non Stick Spray
- 2 Tubes of Biscuits (Pillsbury or Otherwise)
- 1 and 1/2 sticks of Salted Butter (Unsalted also works, just be sure to add a 1/2 teaspoon of salt in step 3)
- 4 Teaspoons of Brown Sugar
- 1 Teaspoon of Cinnamon
- 1 Tablespoon of Honey
- 2 Tablespoons of Milk, Heavy Cream, or Buttermilk (Non-Dairy Milks work as well. See Step for more info) (More as Needed)
- 2 Cups of Powdered Sugar (more as needed)

Step 1. Preheat your oven to 350 and give your pan a light coat of non-stick spray

Step 2. POP THEM BISCUITS OPEN BABY!!

Once you get the biscuits out, grab a butterknife (or use your hands you filthy animal) and quarter them. Start laying em out in the pan. Spaces in-between the biscuits is A-okay cause we want that buttersugar to get down in there once we start pouring. Likely, you'll run into the issue of "too many biscuit pieces, not enough space" so just kinda squish em down and try to fill in the edges and corners with an extra biscuit piece. Once you've got all the biscuits packed in there, we're on to step 3!

Step 3. BUTTERSUGAR TIME

Grab your 1 and 1/2 Sticks of butter and we're gon' melt that son of a gun. Personally, I like to melt butter in the microwave, but if you wanna get all fancy and pull out the saucepan then go for it. Ain't nobody stopping you.

So for the rest of us common folk, put your butter in a microwave safe bowl or Pyrex measuring cup. I throw it in there for like 1min and just check on it closer to the minute mark, but we all got different microwaves. Basically, you just want the butter to be melted with no chunks left in it. So however long it takes to do that. DON'T leave it in too long or it'll burn and then you gotta go get more butter.

NOW. You've got your melted butter. Add the Cinnamon and the brown sugar to it and stir the everliving life outta that thing til' it's all nice and pretty. Once you've successfully crafted the buttersugar, pour it over the biscuits in the pan. My two main goals here are "1. Make sure every biscuit gets some love" and "2. Fill in all the cracks" So pour slow and steady.

Step 4. MAKE IT HOT

Okay. Let me level with you here. I am not a classically trained baking professional. I'm just a regular schmegular person who likes the sweety sweets. I have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ these up before and this is the step that made my spouse leave.

Double check the oven is on 350. Put the little biscuits in the oven so that they can grow up to be big and strong. Leave them in there for about 10-13min. Be sure to check on your biscuits throughout the process. What you're looking for is the tops to be golden brown. Like that real fresh baked brown, that you see in the movies and tv and recipe sites. Once you see golden brown, open the oven and don't be afraid to get a little greedy. Grab a biscuit off the top so you can see how the middle section and bottom of the pan look.

If it looks doughy Turn the oven off and let the biscuits sit inside for maybe 5 minutes. Again, note the color of the tops and go back to your reference piece that you took out. You want them to look like done biscuits. I can't put pictures but I'll make a guide if people are interested and go back through all the steps with pictures.

If it doesn't look doughy Well then what the ♥♥♥♥ are you doing? Move on to the next step champ! We got biscuits to eat!

Step 5. Make the Glaze

In a good sized bowl, whisk together your Powdered sugar, honey, and milk. If you don't have a whisk, that's fine. Just go grab a utensil or something. Personal preference: Fork. They look meaner than the other utensils.

NON-DAIRY MILK USERS UNITE!
I really like an almond milk substitute here, but whatever works, works. Just know, with the amount of ingredients we're using here, your glaze may come out thin and runny. If it does, don't panic and cry. Just add a little more powdered sugar in tablespoon increments. Add, whisk and repeat if it still comes out runny. Once it's thick enough, go ahead on.

Take your whisked mixture and and drizzle it over the finished biscuits. And boom done. You just baked something delicious.

If you read this far, thank you. If you liked the recipe, thank you. I'll try to make a guide and go back through with pictures and gifs to make this a lot easier to follow if enough people want that.

Call the ones you love, tell em you love them.

Let me know what recipe you want me to do next.

A must play game for anyone who loves solving puzzles.  A 3D puzzle that uses a physical body to set the "pieces" and physically navigate said body as you go through the course.  I'm especially thankful for the community created maps; they can be easy as pie to extremely frustrating until you get the "duh" or "wow" moment.  The humor is dry yet will give you a chuckle once in a while.  The violence is limited to the user falling into water, getting burned, crushed, and shot at BUT no physical gore to be seen (except some blood lines which look more like red paint).  The death is quick and subtle (screen just dims to black without showing any body or gore) so you don't have to worry about your kids getting scarred mentally.  So if you would like to introduce your children to a game that has the concept of death (without gore) while letting them flex their brains solving puzzles, this is the one!
