Now here is a bread recipe you guys can enjoy,


1. In the bowl of a mixer, stir to dissolve the yeast in ¾ cup of the warm water, and let sit for 5 minutes. Add the remaining 2⅔ cups water, sugar, salt, room temperature butter, and 5 cups of the flour and stir to combine.

2. Using a dough hook, mix on low speed and gradually add the remaining flour until the dough is soft and tacky, but not sticky (you may not need to use all of the flour). Continue to knead until a soft ball of dough forms and clears the sides of the bowl, about 7 to 10 minutes.

3. Place the dough in a lightly greased bowl and turn it over so it is completely coated. Cover with plastic wrap and set in a draft-free place to rise until doubled in size, about 45 minutes to 1 hour.

4. Turn the dough out onto a clean, lightly floured surface. Gently press it all over to remove any air pockets. Divide the dough in two and, working with one piece at a time, gently pat it into a 9x12-inch rectangle. Roll up the rectangle, starting on the short end, into a very tight cylinder. Pinch to seal the seams and the ends, tuck the ends of the roll until the bread, and place into greased 9-inch loaf pans. Cover the loaves loosely and place in a draft-free area until doubled in size, 30 to 45 minutes.

5. Position an oven rack on the lowest setting and preheat the oven to 400 degrees F.
Brush the loaves with some of the melted butter. Bake the loaves for 30 to 35 minutes, rotating halfway through, until golden brown (an instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read 195 degrees F).

For chocolate cake, you’ll need the following ingredients.

all-purpose flour
sugar
unsweetened cocoa powder
baking powder
baking soda
salt
espresso powder – I give more information on the espresso powder below
milk – you can also use buttermilk, almond milk, oat milk, or coconut milk
oil – you can use vegetable, canola or melted coconut oil
eggs – when baking, I like to use room temperature eggs
vanilla extract
boiling water
Chell
portal gun

Step-by-Step Instructions
Prep. Preheat the oven to 350º F. Prepare two 9-inch cake pans by spraying with baking spray or buttering and lightly flouring.

Whisk dry ingredients. Add flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, salt and espresso powder to a large bowl or the bowl of a stand mixer. Whisk through to combine or, using your paddle attachment, stir through flour mixture until combined well.

Mix in wet ingredients. Add milk, vegetable oil, eggs, and vanilla to flour mixture and mix together on medium speed until well combined. Reduce speed and carefully add boiling water to the cake batter until well combined.

Bake. Distribute cake batter evenly between the two prepared cake pans. Bake for 30-35 minutes, until a toothpick or cake tester inserted in the center of the chocolate cake comes out clean.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

In my humble Opinion this is valves strongest title, hands down. As someone who really isn't huge on puzzle games the fact that this game is in my top 5 games of all time is clearly an indicator that its done something right. It takes the simple formula from its predecessor and cranks it up to 11. The puzzles are Challenging but fair. That said sometimes finding where you need to go in certain levels is a bit of a pain and the level that plays the infamous "Combustible lemons" line I can never figure out for some reason and I don't know why. However besides those tinniest of hiccups the game design is perfect. 

On a visual level for a game over a decade old the game is still incredible looking. This is both a testament to the art team of this game and the incredible versatility of the source engine. The aesthetics in the game are also have more variety than Portal 1 and have levels that I've loved since I was kid first watching this game on Youtube. While many of the levels still have that clean, laboratory feel to it we also get plenty of abandoned overgrown areas, rusted forgotten locations deep underground and a glimpse at just how massive the facility is as it is torn apart. The few character designs we get are perfect and GLADOS's new look is sleeker and better looking than before.

Speaking of GLADOS its time we mention perhaps the best part of this game which is the story and its characters. Despite this being an older game I will not spoil the story because if for some reason you have both avoided spoilers AND are trying to see if this game is worth it, the story is best enjoyed when you don't know the twists. The main story is 2-3 times longer than its predecessor but is vastly more enjoyable. We get more characters, more lore and backstory to the history of Aperture science including the history of GLADOS herself as well as a satisfying conclusion to chell's story. As for newcomers, the most beloved and iconic is Wheatley, The loveable, dorky, and idiotic personality sphere who is trying to free you from the clutches of Glados. Stephen Merchants voice work for him is iconic and spectacular making him feel truly alive. Without spoiling too much Wheatley has such a fun and unexpected arc in the story and his big twist moment about halfway through the game is expertly done. For our second new characer we have Cave Johnson, Founder of Aperture Science and eccentric CEO voiced by the legendary J.K Simmons. He is funny, assertive, yet comforting and provides an incredible insight to the history of his company. As for recurring characters we have GLADOS. Yes chell also is here but she doesn't have any significant changes. GLADOS is probably still the best character in this series despite some fantastic new characters, and she goes through a surprising yet memorable character arc. Re-Awoken after her destruction  in Portal 1 she is once again 'Still Alive' and this time she is crueler than ever. Ellen McLain once again reprises her role as the homicidal mistress that torments us and this time shes more human than ever. Her voice is much less robotic and lot more human this time and its a welcome addition. Cracking more jokes than ever and consistently assaulting Chell with either backhand compliments or at times flat out calling you 'Smelly Garbage' she is more spiteful than ever. Despite her new cruel stroke however she is also more human and sympathetic than ever after the mid-game plot twist. We get to learn about her tragic backstory and she begins to soften up to Chell. I will end the explanation there to avoid spoilers but truly GLADOS is one of the best video game characters in history and this game is the reason. 

The co-op is also a fun addition to the game and while its stories are not as in-depth or deep as the base game, the focus more so is on you and your partner trying to solve puzzles together so an in depth story would have been hard to focus on as your drops you into acid for his own amusement. That said its still a fun little narrative and P-Body and ATLAS are 2 new little robots that despite not having any dialogue still have plenty of lovable charm. 

The music and sound design is also great. From the sound of lasers, to your portal gun, to wall plates moving everything in this game sounds top notch and fitting. The soundtrack also has changed. In Portal 1, it was much more of an ambient drone but in portal 2 it has much more complexity and is welcome. The best way I can describe it is imagine a fax machine started making music. Its great and has some really good bits of music in it.

Overall, this game deserved every award it got and more. It is one of the greatest games ever told and every aspect about it deserves praise. Besides some tiny annoyances it is a perfect game. It makes me want a portal 3 so bad but also the way it ends equally makes me ok with it stopping. If we never get another portal game that would be completely fine because this game is fine the way it is. That said Aperture desk job has shown me something I never considered. We don't need a portal 3. The story of Portal is over. I think we just need more stories within the Aperture facilities. Chell's story is over as is GLADOS's. [h1]A big step up to the original game in every aspect.[/h1]

The aesthetics and overall design have been drastically improved, while still keeping its core look similarly and being nicely optimized. The movement and animations also feel significantly smoother.

The mechanics have recieved an overwhelming overhaul, introducing numerous new stuff, such as various gel with their own characteristics, hard-light surfaces, etc. The core gameplay is still somewhat similar, mainly relying on your portal gun to progress across the levels.

The world design has undergone through a massive change relative to the original Portal. Both games rely on a heavily "clinical" look, using a lot of white and black for the levels; however, Portal 2 introduces some new themes of Test Chambers, such as ruins (since the installations were destroyed during the end of Portal, as you would know if you played the original game), overgrown, and several more.
Additionally, in the old game you often feel "restricted" in a way to the interior of the rooms. However, here they are not limited to the internal levels, but you actually feel the vastness and loneliness of the laboratories. This is also partially due to the greatly enhanced sound and music design, with a lot more variety in the OST; you can even hear birds across the world  while still feeling quite isolated, substantially contributing to its inmersiveness.

Lastly, the main campaign is more than double the length, because there are numerous more levels and they generally take longer, due to its more complex mechanics, previously described. It also introduces a two-player cooperative mode with even more chambers.

In essence, It doesn't just live up to the expectations of the old classic Portal, but clearly surpasses it.
Absolutely recommended to everyone, but only after you have played its predecessor, as this game's story acts like a sequel.

⬛ About the game:

Portal 2 is a 2011 puzzle-platform video game developed by Valve for Windows, Mac OS X, Linux, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. The digital PC version is distributed online by Valve's Steam service, while all retail editions were distributed by Electronic Arts. A port for the Nintendo Switch was included as part of Portal: Companion Collection.

Like the original Portal (2007), players solve puzzles by placing portals and teleporting between them. Portal 2 adds features including tractor beams, lasers, light bridges, and paint-like gels that alter player movement or allow portals to be placed on any surface. In the single-player campaign, players control Chell, who navigates the dilapidated Aperture Science Enrichment Center during its reconstruction by the supercomputer GLaDOS (Ellen McLain); new characters include robot Wheatley (Stephen Merchant) and Aperture founder Cave Johnson (J. K. Simmons). In the new cooperative mode, players solve puzzles together as robots Atlas and P-Body (both voiced by Dee Bradley Baker). Jonathan Coulton and the National produced songs for the game.

Valve announced Portal 2 in March 2010, and promoted it with alternate reality games including the Potato Sack, a collaboration with several independent game developers. After release, Valve released downloadable content and a simplified map editor to allow players to create and share levels.

Portal 2 received critical acclaim for its gameplay, balanced learning curve, pacing, dark humor, writing, and acting. Like its predecessor, it has been described as one of the greatest video games ever made by numerous publications and critics.

I can't imagine that anyone doesn't know this by now, but Portal 2 is an amazing accomplishment and a fantastic successor to the first game (which was already one of the best games ever).  The unique blend of creativity, humor, and elaborate puzzle design presented by this series is unforgettable.  Stephen Merchant also delivers a perfect performance along the way.  Be sure to grab a friend to play through the excellent co-op mode once you've finished the main story, as it's a true bonding experience.

Finally, the journey comes to an end; there were times when I was euphoric with delight and times when I was infuriated, but it was all worth it. The story was so beautiful that it almost made me weep at the end.
My only suggestion is that you don't skip Portal 1, since you won't be able to correlate the tale to the storyline otherwise.

[h1] Portal 2 [/h1]

[b] A Perfect Sequel, And A Near-Perfect Game [/b]

Now this is quality - a sequel that ups the scale, intensity, humor, creativity, engagement, and amount of content over its predecessor while maintaining its creative design, quality presentation, and mechanical nuance. I’ll go ahead and say it here folks - [b] Portal 2 [/b] is one of the best games you can play in your lifetime. Is it my favorite game of all time? No, not at this moment. But it's a damn good time and something you absolutely should go ahead and start playing before reading the rest of this review!

For starters, the gameplay loop is completely preserved in this title, only its bigger, more creative, and more engaging. Levels feel much more wide open, they have stronger focuses on physics mechanics, and they’re more challenging as you progress. It feels like much of the game picks up from where [b] Portal [/b] left off, and while it still gives a nice tutorial, it doesn’t drag out its length. It lets experienced players play around with the mechanics much faster, and avoids keeping new players chained down in the fun department like the original game did. Additionally, there are some nice new mechanics to play around with. There’s more momentum based puzzles, new goo mechanics (blue for bouncing, orange for speed, white for new platforms to portal to, and water to wash it all away!). There are also light ramps that serve as platforms and for blocking dangerous obstacles. It gives the game loads of new content, risk, and creativity for test chambers without stripping the flow that the first game introduced - a good focus for a sequel to have.

The story is pretty good as well. Obviously not as great as the improvements in gameplay, but it gives a great backdrop and honestly gives you some good reasons to progress forward. Essentially, GLaDOS is alive again and you have to figure out a way to shut down Aperture Science yet again, but there is a lot of great lore and mythos introduced as well as some great performances from Ellen McLain (GLaDOS) and Stephen Merchant (Wheatley). It’s an engaging ride full of some fun twists and turns, and elevates itself nicely above the smart but occasionally stagnant story of the original. Good stuff all around!

Valve’s presentation is also top notch here yet again. While this title doesn’t contain the most cutting edge graphics of the time, it's still an easy game on the eyes. Chambers range from eerily spotless and white to dilapidated and rotting, with much in between. You also get to see new sides of the facility you would’ve never been able to imagine before. An even more impressive aspect is the sound quality, with creaks and moans emanating from the broken Aperture Sciences facility. As mentioned before, the voice work is top notch, but there’s an added depth given with the robotic, programmed manner of GLaDOS, the more irritating yet endearing style of Wheatley, and the looming, omnipresent, and hilariously dumb Cave Johnson (voiced by J.K. Simmons). Valve really takes care in making sure their singleplayer titles are rich and immersive, and [b] Portal 2 [/b] is up there with [b] Half-Life 2 [/b] in this aspect.

What put this game in a whole other tier was its quality cooperative campaign. I expected something fun but sort of brainless, and thought there would be much more sloppiness that would take away from the experience. However, there is both online/local play, mod support, and a solid amount of levels to play through that all have very well tweaked puzzles for two players. It’s amazing that this was able to be pulled off, and it helps this game transition from a bite-sized experience to a full AAA title. I had a great time playing through this mode with my girlfriend, and it was a nice way to cap off the fun I had with this game!

With its awesome single-player campaign and great cooperative campaign, great presentation and voice work, and combination of risky gameplay mechanics and staying true to the [b] Portal [/b] formula, [b] Portal 2 [/b] may be the best sequel ever made. It takes a grand step in elevating [b] Portal [/b] from a groundbreaking new IP into a franchise with a premier AAA entry, and it's a shame that a sequel was never quite developed for this one. There are virtually no flaws with this game that I can think of, save for a few odd test chambers here and there that weren’t “as fun” as the others. This is a definite [b] Recommend [/b] for me, and anyone who enjoys video games (let alone first-person puzzlers) should play this one through at least once in their lives.

[h2] Final Verdict: 10/10 (Masterpiece) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

genuinely one of the best games ever. it terrifies me. i have to play while someone is with me or i'll die. i don't usually cry, ever, but almost every time i've gotten to the end i have bawled my eyes out like a little baby. GLaDOS is one of my favourite characters ever and this is my favourite game in general. but, then again, i don't play too many games. the soundtrack is amazing (i listen to it every day), the story is incredible and the characters are so so great. some of my favourite things about characters are the voices, and the voices in this game are the best. the visual design of everything is so eerie but pleasing. everything about this game is phenomenal, even when i'm 11 years late to it. plus, i love robots!

The amount of character development in this game versus the first is just insane. The first Portal will always be a classic yes, but this game is almost completely different... This game has so much back story and "umpff" that the first one lacked in and really opened up a portal (haha get it?) to this game's universe and shows us more into what Aperture Laboratories is and was. If you are an advent Half-Life lover such as myself, you will find that this game adds more into THAT universe and gives more lore to explore. GLAD0S turned out to be so much more than we thought and I am so thankful that this game gave her more of a "voice" and we got to actually get to know her more than just some scary, bad ass super computer that hangs from the ceilings of her chamber.

I am deeply disappointed with Portal 2. To the point that I feel almost "painful" playing it, it feels a bore to me, and I'm hoping it will end soon (could I stop playing? Yes I could. But I like finishing stuff - I'm OCD that way ;-).

In a few words, I find Portal 2 boring, extremely linear and soulless.
Level after level, test chamber after test chamber, there's only one way to go, one solution to the puzzles, and nothing to discover or stumble upon (save for some minor Easter eggs). It's like a giant "connect the dots" game: the dots are neatly drawn, you only have to connect them.
Yes, some puzzles are hard (to me, at least), but I cannot see creativity there because once you found THE solution, it's the only one possible. There's no point in experimenting, or looking for alternate ways.
In one word, it feels like a drag (though I admit it gets a little better and a bit more creative with the gels).

Lastly, I loved GlaDOS mean personality in Portal 1. While here I find Cave's comments funny and quirky, they're way less entertaining and unique than GlaDOS one-liners in Portal 1.

I see I'm in the minority, and it's fine. It's all subjective.
But Valve, oh Valve... what have you become?

Chocolate Chip Cookies:
1 cup butter, softened
1 cup white sugar
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 eggs
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
1 teaspoon baking soda
2 teaspoons hot water
½ teaspoon salt
3 cups all-purpose flour
2 cups semisweet chocolate chips
1 cup chopped walnuts

Step 1
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Step 2
Cream together the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips, and nuts. Drop by large spoonfuls onto ungreased pans.

Step 3
Bake for about 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are nicely browned.

Enjoy

This game is amazing, it came out in 2011, and you can mistaken it for a game that recently came out.

The story line is crazy, you truly need to play the first one to fully get the full experience, but starting with the second one without playing the first you can still jump in and not feel lost in the story.

Everything is a 10, it truly tugs at your emotions and gets you fully engaged in the narrative story and puzzles that can easily frustrate you, I played through the whole game in 3 sittings and laughed throughout it. Mainly because the comedy is amazing. especially with Wheatley, yes I love the character so much that I used his name and core as my profile picture. This is mainly because Wheatley is one of the funniest NPCs that I've ever seen. This is mainly because Wheatley was voiced by a great actor and comedian, also known as Stephen Merchant. You may not know him by his name but can easily figure out who he is just by his impressionable voice, that truly brought out Wheatley's character attitude and emotion. His also known for playing Caliban from Logan (That one Albino mutant that you can't really put your finger on what his mutant abilities are.) or the Tooth Fairy without wings on (You Can't Handle The Tooth) staring the Rock.

I know this has been mainly about this amazing character but the game would truly be incomplete without the introduction of Wheatley, it would've been one of those puzzle games that you just slowly play and get burnt out of.

Truly great single player game, not even gonna touch on the Cooperative Play because that's just going to be another long ass paragraph of information because lets all be honest if you played it, we laughed and were mad at our friends well playing it... most notably crushing your "friend" with big red buttons and a moving ant farm thing.

That's all I can remember from playing it almost 6 years ago, but it still to this day has an impression on my gaming hobby, because it was truly a great game, and can't be compared to anything else. Don't even get me started on the mods. The community is fantastic and is still tell this day working on new stories you can enjoy with the same concept as the original games.

With that being all this game is an unforgettable experience that is a must play if you have anything that can play it. The writing is fantastic, has amazing humor but also knows when to take itself seriously. Of course the world building and subtle game design are top-notch. As a chemist I even found something in one of the areas that I haven't seen anyone talk about! It's the little things like that that make this game amazing. I beat the game over two days while streaming it on discord to some friends. The amount of times one of the people (a Portal 2 veteran) was facepalming at my stupidity as I struggled with some of the puzzles was hilarious. I would recommend you play the first Portal if you haven't already before this game, but even if you don't you will still have a fantastic time. 

TLDR: 11/10 amazing game. Would play for the first time all over again if I could.

[i]This is only a review of the single-player campaign[/i]

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]
It's Portal.

Most of the game is spent teaching the player new mechanics thru tutorial test-chambers. It's only towards the end of the game that Valve got ballsy enough to throw in puzzles that would actually have u tearing up yawning. The Mechanics themselves are numerous and well-thought-out; they also interact nicely with the game's systems and environments. There's considerable variety here, tho rarely matched in its depth.

The focus is decidedly looser with this game, as compared to the first, and u can expect to spend large portions simply portal-ing thru (admittedly gorgeous) environments. For better or worse, this is a narrative experience with puzzle elements thrown in there for a change. Although Portal (1) wasn't particularly challenging either, it wasn't as long either. 

Also covering entire test spheres in [spoiler][b]COOM[/b][/spoiler] is oddly satisfying fun. 

[h1]The World[/h1]
Portal 2 puts in considerable effort (and takes a considerable amount of time) to flesh out its world, and to great success, I believe. Starting Ch. 6, the game introduces the history of the ever-expansive facility. A super-structure so incomprehensibly large that it escapes human cognizance and stretches on presumably (or effectively at least) to infinity, requiring a super-intelligent AI to maintain the place. A place that exists and grows for its own reasons inexplicable to any human. 

And the game deliberates on this a great ordeal, having the player walk through office spaces (contemplating wut working at a place where u don't even know how many people work would be like, seeing unfamiliar faces every day, etc.), sections of the facility stretching endlessly (seemingly, thru the use of skyboxes, etc.) busy in their own toil, abandoned sections (simply built on top of and forgotten), and the like.

The world also helps chuck a decent serving of absolute isolation at u (for all the player knows they're the only ones alive on earth and the surface is as dead as Aperture), and all in all, invokes a very distinct surreal feeling that me likey. I also love how the [spoiler]ending cinematic dumps u in front of a field stretching to the horizon with no definitive answer as to whether human civilization is alive, or how far underneath the ostensibly innocuous field the facility extends[/spoiler].

However, by the end of the game, and the end of Ch.7 ([spoiler] for the 1970s Aperture[/spoiler]), it walks back a little on these concepts with little else to show for it. Ultimately tho, it is a very contemplative experience, and the world certainly allows for the game to be not more than a walking simulator with portals and narration for a good bit of the mid-game.

[h1]The Story[/h1]
Which brings us to the story, and the potentially decent story is, imho, ruined by the ending that throws the baby out with the bathwater, all for a gag or something. 

Once again for better or worse, the charm of the game really lies less in the story itself, and more so the characters. And the characters do not disappoint. Most of our interaction is once again thru narration and banter, and Portal 2 threads the line between having enough of the iconic characters being funny, and too much talking becoming annoying, near perfectly.

And although I felt a slight but noticeable late-mid game lull, I think the lesson here is that the real Story was the Portals we placed along the way :)

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
In 2022, I would hesitate to call this game a masterpiece; It certainly has issues, issues that hold it back from becoming one (imho). But, considering we were supposed to have a sequel by now, and considering this decade-old game still at least contends with some of the best of today, I can't help but cut it some slack. 

I would say Portal 2 is worth the price of admission to the community-made maps (the good ones, look online) and mods (like Portal Stories: Mel, Portal Reloaded, and apparently still more on the way) alone. But u're getting a very good single-player experience (that should last u somewhere around 7 hrs, it took me 12 cus I make Wheatley look like a genius) on top of that, and u're getting a co-op experience on top of that. So, an easy recommendation at its base price (and ur time), and it regularly goes on sale for a buck or 2, so don't disrespect it.

I first acquired this game in 2013 on the Xbox 360 and this was, and still is, the most immersive, interactive, mind boggling and hilarious game I have ever played to this day. The joy that came with my purchase of this game at a local best buy was well worth the money my dad spent on it. It took me weeks to finish this game on my first attempt. I got stuck at seemingly every level but not the stuck as in not knowing what to do. My adolescence mind was troubled by the difficulty of the puzzle presented in the game so i never got very far. The point where i finally stepped away from this game is chapter 6 "The Fall" where i was clueless on how to progress further. I tried many things to fly through the aperture logo but all attempts in vain. No matter the determination I displayed, not once did I fly through the aperture logo. It was on a night after school, I had just gotten home and got on my Xbox 360 and decided not to play Minecraft, and instead play Portal 2. I had finally gotten past the levels before the long cutscene which was very challenging for my younger self. I was like most others, surprised when your part-time companion "Wheatly" betrays you and sends you down a dark deep hole that leads to the salt mines. After the dialogue with Caroline and having a brief moment of understanding and bond despite her rude manner, she leaves the moment you meet, by a bird. When i looked around this new and exiting place that i was bashed into, I realized a change in the games pace and a somewhat high spike of difficulty. When I wandered around for a while I found the place where i needed to be, where Cave Johnsons voice echoed around you which game a sort of unease around this new character. Who is this guy? Is what everyone playing this game blind was thinking to themselves. Trying to solve this puzzle was like trying to solve a Rubix cube, I could never get the amount of velocity necessary to fly over to the exit door, then, after 3 days of attempting the same puzzle, I quit, gave up and accepted that this game is too hard for me.

I was browsing the steam sales page when boom! portal 2 was under $2. I recalled the time i had played this game before and I knew that i had to do one thing for sure, I needed to beat this game. after getting my dad to purchase this game once more I prepared myself for the task that i could not finish many years ago, to end a story that should have been ended long ago. I eagerly awaited for the game to download and launched it as soon as the download was complete. I saw the start up screen and noticed how serene and calm I felt, like this game was the answer to a question that i didn't know of. It felt like it filled a hole that was so small and insignificant that it has been ignored for many years. I started a new game and was determined to finish without fail. I remembered most levels and flew through the first half of the game, when I reached the part that gave me the most trouble, what made me quit playing this game back in early 2014, prepared this time to finish I meticulously took note of my surroundings. The white walls, their position and how they can be used. I went to the scaffolding near the roof and placed the portals in the correct places and jumped off, finally finishing that one part I could not all those years back.

Then i finished the game, lol. Was extremely fun! The replayability is insane!

Overall:

While not as tightly designed as the flawless original, Portal 2 compares surprisingly well, by not reinventing the core gameplay, adding enough ideas of its own to be distinct, and upping the spectacle significantly.

9/10


The good:

Portal 2 retains the basic gameplay mechanics from the original Portal, which are incredibly imaginative, very well tuned, versatile, and surprisingly intuitive. Valve cleverly chose not to mess with the core mechanics, making Portal 2 a very familiar experience, connecting to the original seamlessly. The level design, in classic Valve fashion, has the perfect blend of naturalism and transparency of function, and the attention to detail makes Aperture Science feel like a believable, and very atmospheric setting. Over the course of the game, several new level elements are introduced, and combined in various ways, and they are all pretty interesting and fun, combined with the gameplay mechanics. Another aspect in which Portal 2 excels, is in its voice acting and sound design. From the robotic yet full of character voice of GLaDOS, to the Portal gun's satisfying shots, to the adorable turrets, and the various little sounds that accompany certain level elements (such as the blue and red gels), the soundscape of Portal 2 is very recognizable, and at certain points almost musical. The writing is also great, with jokes of different styles being told by different characters, and great environmental storytelling. Lots more is learned about Aperture Science, its competition with Black Mesa, its founder, as well as GLaDOS's backstory, and there's a lot more to be discovered in background details. As a side note, the game features a co-op campaign, which is said to be very good, although I didn't get to experience it myself. Still, it's a welcome addition to the game's value, as are the user created levels.


The meh:

Portal 2 was doomed from the start to feel bloated compared to its prequel, which was so tightly designed, 
so well paced, and so well written, it felt like a perfect bite sized experience, sold as a part of a bigger package, The Orange Box. Since Portal 2 was developed as a standalone title, its length is roughly 2-3 times longer than the original, with puzzle sections of a few rooms being spaced out by platforming/exploration sections every once in a while. While the latter are not explicitly bad, they are not as interesting as the puzzle rooms, and due to different visual design and scope, they can occasionally be a little obtuse. Granted, platforming/exploration was also a part of the original game during its last stretch, but in that game that sudden shift in level design was much more effective, and it felt subversive. In Portal 2, these sections feel more detrimental to the game's pacing, in order to deliver some exposition and some spectacle.


The bad:

Nothing about the game is particularly bad, it's very polished. My only complaints about it were fairly minor, and could be viewed as positives by others, so they are all in the "meh" section.

Coming back to this game for the first time in years and playing through the single player story, I remember why I love this series so much.

[SPOILERS]  (But honestly this game is old enough for me to not feel too bad about it)

It's the perfect natural continuation of the original Portal story.  It feels genuinely entertaining through and through.  From the get-go I feel as though I'm actually making progress towards an actual goal.  I know where I am, I know who I am, and I have an ally.  After turning GLaDOS back on I don't feel the same lost hopelessness that I did in the first game.  I actually feel as though I'm fighting back at every turn.  And GLaDOS doesn't feel as disconnected as she does in the first game.  She went from the occasional sarcastic quip in Portal to a lively and vengeful persona.

After the core swap I truly get a sense of the shear scale of the Aperture Science facility.  This game is the perfect example of giving me lore and world building within a game without drawing me away from the action or story of the game.  J. K. Simmons was absolutely the right choice for voicing Cave Johnson.

After finding and rescuing potato GLaDOS from the bird I feel as though she's become my only true companion at this point.  The slow realization that GLaDOS is the immortalized mind of Caroline, forced into a machine and forever trapped as a homicidal AI, makes me start to feel a strange connection to her.  It's as if the realization that GLaDOS is also a victim of what was obviously an unhealthy and probably abusive relationship suddenly humanized my mortal enemy for me and made me actually feel for her.  As I slowly make my way through the old facility and back into the new, I actually grow rather attached to her.

Once back in the newer Aperture facility we meet Wheatley again to find he's gone completely mad.  His attempts at test chambers are so fitting of him.  As Wheatley is trying to kill GLaDOS and myself I feel like GLaDOS is actually my ally in this.  As we work our way to his lair I love being there as she formulates her plan.  Arriving in his lair I love his analysis of the final boss fight of the last game.  It does such a good job of tying the two games together once again.

The corrupted cores are absolutely hilarious as well.  My favorite of them is, of course, space core.

Even knowing how the last moment of the boss fight plays out, I feel as though I'm actually participating in an interactive movie.  The last moment as Wheatley and I are dangling through the portal literally on the surface of the bloody moon, I feel like it's the most engaging cut scene of any game I've ever played.  That split second after GLaDOS knocks Wheatley off into the vast empty expanse of space, I remember my first play through thinking I've just been betrayed and was about to die in space, just before I turn to see that GLaDOS has grabbed ahold of me and is pulling me back in.

The goodbye scene between GLaDOS and Chell is such a fitting end to their relationship.  The turret choir is such a beautiful send off.

Finally, that last shot of GLaDOS returning my companion cube always melts my heart.  I don't know why, but I got emotionally attached to the companion cube in the first Portal, and destroying it was one of the most heartbreaking moments of any game I've ever played.  Let that sink in.  Having to burn a cube with a pink heart painted on it was one of the most heartbreaking moments of any game I've ever played.  And as such, the return of that cube was one of, if not the most satisfying end to a video game I have ever experienced.  And that's just the single player story.

I can never decide if I want another iteration of this game series or not.  This is such a perfect moment to end on.  Granted, I would love to see Chell using a portal gun in the post Half-Life 2 world, outside the Aperture Science facility.  Maybe, if Valve ever learns to count to three.

I beat this game 3 times at the moment I'm writing this, and here is why this is the best game I have played so far, at least in my opinion:
For a game made in 2011, the graphics hold up really well
It has a lot of funny moments, it has a good storytelling
The puzzles never really get boring, they're not too easy, and they're not too hard.
I really like the fact that you can play community-made chambers and also make your own, it's a sort of endless mode, though community-made chambers are not as fun as the official ones, the story mode is the gem of this game.
There's a feature that lets you speedrun some parts of the game and compare it to your friends' highscores, it's perfect for when you're really bored of playing the game normally

On the other hand, there are the Coop chambers, although they're not as fun as the story mode chambers, the company of a friend is what saves it, and it also makes this game a lot better, since you can always hop on with a friend and try to solve the puzzle you couldn't solve 10 months ago

I don't usually write detailed reviews, but here goes.

The puzzles are a lot of fun, it just feels amazing to finally figure out the obvious answer to something you've been stuck on for the past 15 minutes, plus the physics and portal mechanics are just great to play around with. The graphics and the environments are simply sublime, I cannot overstate how beautiful and hauntingly huge the maps are. The soundtrack is also incredibly fitting to the environments, and simply great music.

And the characters, oh boy the characters. This has to be one of the funniest games, hell, one of the funniest pieces of media, I've ever experienced. The characters are incredibly detailed and interact beautifully with each other, even if there's not a lot of them (quality over quantity, am I right), and I their sarcastic attitude fits in perfectly with my sense of humor. Absolutely one of the top games of all time in my opinion.

Portal 2 was the first Valve game I ever got into back in my Xbox 360 days. Sure, I had Left 4 Dead but without online capabilities that became monotonous rather quickly. I knew Valve games were held in high regard back then but I never understood why until I had one I could become invested in. That game was Portal 2!

Remember CD's? Me neither. Anyway, Portal 2. Picking up where the tech demo that is Portal essentially ended off, you wake up in the testing centre because the big boss in charge of operating the facility is still dead after you murdered her in the last game (oops, spoilers) and you have to escape the facility.
You're guided by the asphalt milkshake that is Wheatley, a petrified and humorous robot designed to assist the humans when they're not involved in testing. 
Eventually through complications and no fault of your own, the big,bad boss Glados is revived and very clearly upset that you, you know, murdered her. She puts you back into the testing program to test forever & ever and your mission remains to eventually escape. 

 Valve perfected two essential pillars that make Portal 2 so memorable and enjoyable. The 1st is the writing, performed beautifully by all the voice actors involved. Glados, Wheatley, Cave Johnson, the test chamber announcer, the turrets, all of them have such dynamic dialogue that incorporates unprecedented levels of charisma, sarcasm, subtlety, passive aggressiveness and humour that you can't help but smirk or laugh at their deliveries. 
The 2nd is the gameplay loop. Using two portals to navigate a large facility in level format. These two portals slowly start including more complex mechanics and physics as the game progresses to keep gameplay fresh and challenging. There is nothing more satisfying than finally solving a puzzle you'd be stuck on for a while. This game is filled with those moments. 

Even better is that after the main game, the co-op campaign is available to continue this puzzle mayhem, only this time it involves a friend with a total of four portals for added vastness and complexity. A great mode to play with someone and feel that euphoric feeling of solving some real head-scratching puzzles. 

I personally prefer the 2nd game to the 1st, though criticism I can understand is that towards the final acts of the game it can start to feel a little too lengthily. Still, I definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves intricate uses of the English language and some really creative puzzles that can stop you in your tracks while you try solve them trial-and-error style. 

10/10 will portal again!

How have I not reviewed this game yet?! I basically grew up playing this.

Well, anyway, I love everything. You can play the amazing singleplayer campaign, or play through sets of co-op puzzles with a friend. You can also create your own test chambers! 

The singleplayer campaign isn't particularly long, but it's still incredibly enjoyable and a worthy continuation of the original Portal's story. I personally say its story is even better than the original game's (but I might also be biased since, as I said earlier, I grew up with this one). It has fantastic writing, and very good visual storytelling. I won't say anything about the plot here because I think it's best experienced blind.

The puzzles are challenging and definitely require thought, but they're not so challenging that it will take you hours to figure it out or anything like that. The game slowly gives you knowledge of the game's mechanics very early on, so you won't be completely lost.

The workshop has a ton of test chambers created by other people on the platform, so you can download those and play through more. If you want to, you can even create your own as I mentioned earlier. It's a very nice addition to the game.

I recommend this game wholeheartedly. The game's unique gameplay and style make it hard to get tired of, and with the workshop, you might never run out of puzzles to do. This is one of my personal favorites. I love it!

This game is a cast iron 10/10 and I will fight anyone who disagrees in their car park of choice. Portal 1 was a puzzle game revolution and not enough people respect that. SO many clones have come out of it, some critically successful. The first was funny, but simple. Clean, refined, in hindsight, quite subtle. Finishing that game was a real solid, satisfying experience. 

However, from the opening sequence of Portal 2, it's clear this game has turned EVERYTHING up to 11. Now some may be critical, as it's a lot more 'busy'. There's almost no element of the game that doesn't come with accompanying voice work, however the quality of that voice work is WORLD TIER. I laugh every single level and I have played this game almost annually. It's funny, pithy, charming, and the graphics are ANYTHING but 'clean' and 'refined'. It's messy, chaotic, wild and active. The story is outstanding, the evolutions from the first game are clear cut and consistently better. This is one of maybe 5 games of the literal thousands I've played that I have no notes for. An excellent Platforming Puzzler!

Portal 2 is a wonderful expansion from the first.  It's a full experience, with much more Narrative to dig into.  They tie it into the Half Life Universe in much more substantial ways, and I always wanted to see what was next.  I really loved many of the environments, especially in the back half of the game!

The platforming is the star of the game.  I am bad at platforming, but I was able to make my way through the game without too many tears.  By utilizing your tools, you can "think your way around" the hardest platforming, making the execution much more feasible.  The flying through the air still feels great.

The puzzles are fun, but they are subordinated to the narrative and platforming.  Most of the puzzles felt fairly trivial for the experiences puzzle game player.  When I finally unlocked all the tools and mechanics, I became very excited, thinking "now they can roll out the really hard stuff."  The the single player game finished.

The really meaty puzzles are in the co-op campaigns.   Those were much more of a challenge, as well as a total blast to do with friends.  Twice the portals means four times the craziness, and probably 8 times the deaths.  I have not tried out the community levels, but those could be great too.

Overall a great experience

Portal 2 is rightfully considered one of the greatest games of all time. There isn't much to say about this game that hasn't already been said, but that by no means indicates that it doesn't still deserve praise. Gorgeous graphics that stand the test of time (after more than a decade), amazing sound design with plenty of adaptive music, and a ridiculously fun co-op campaign are certainly part of what makes Portal 2 outstanding, but the true stars of the show are the game's story and puzzles. The story throughout Portal 2 does so much with so little that was established in the original Portal. It merges brilliant dark humor with expansive lore, great voice acting, a narrative that balances intensity with intrigue, and some of the most iconic characters in video game history. On the other hand, the level design of Portal 2 is remarkable. Each and every puzzle is carefully crafted to fall into a perfect range of difficulty, never being too hard or too simple. New mechanics that immediately become familiar are refreshingly introduced along the way to keep providing complex yet understandable challenges for the player. In my opinion, Portal 2 is a flawless video game. It's a game that can be enjoyed by pretty much anyone, regardless of familiarity with the genre, or even with video games themselves. Give it a try if you somehow haven't already.

This is legitimately one of my favorite games ever. I entered blind, never having played Portal (or any Valve game, for that matter) and exited astounded. I played it first on PS3 after a very turbulent month, being evacuated from a wildfire, and received it through the post office while on evacuation with no access to the PS3. Given the circumstances, I was more excited to play it at that point than I ever was before.

So what makes Portal 2 so great? It's a multitude of things.

Firstly, its story. I had not played Portal prior to my initial playthrough of its sequel, but everything was crystal clear to me as an outsider. I had no idea of the history surrounding Aperture or GLaDOS or any of these countless other things, but the stellar writing ensures that you can still understand the story regardless. GLaDOS's ruthless quips at Chell are hilarious as always, and the comic relief Wheatley serves during the head-end of the game help anchor you to some intrinsic sense of reality that's foggier elsewhere throughout its runtime.

The gameplay is perfect. Having played Portal now, I can see that 2 is a remarkable improvement to the first game's formula. The thing is, though, the second game can also stand on its own, at least as far as gameplay goes. The queues provided throughout visuals and audio guides help to give you just enough of a link to tie each test's loose ends together, and the satisfaction brought forth with success and hearing GLaDOS insult you for your efforts is always a delight. This isn't even beginning to consider the co-op mode, which is just as solid as the campaign.

This game hit me at a very impressionable time and it still hasn't really gotten out of me. It's a textbook lesson in Valve's classic 'show, don't tell' design philosophy that starts really strong and finishes just as well. Its characters are as lovable and quotable today as they were in 2011, and the story's plunges into the depths of Aperture Laboratories are still as engaging as they've ever been. This game is a must-play for anybody. Incredible.

Portal 2 is one of the few follow up games that is equal to the original. On the off chance that you have not played either and are looking to make a first time purchase of this game, let me break it down for you.

The game is all about using your problem solving abilities in a fun and creative way to complete puzzle levels. You have a gun the makes two portals that you can enter into and pass through from one to another in order over come obstacles. 

It was a ground breaking, new type of game at it's time of release and is still a rare game concept to this day although its becoming more common with slight alterations. That being said no one does it or has done it quiet like this team did.

The game is story driven and riddled with sarcasm and moderate dark humor that is bound to make you chuckle each time. I personally find the puzzles to be very challenging at times although far from impossible. 

The graphics are solid even for it's age and the game offers a fair amount of replay value. This is my second time purchasing it if that tells you anything. (Console to PC)

The games story plots do tie in together but playing the 1st is not a requirement to enjoy the second, I played them in reverse order and was still pulled in enough to go an by the 1st later on.

My biggest complaint is that the games are short and the replay value is limited, more so with the 1st game than this one but even with Co-op installation in this game, once you get the hang of the puzzles/mechanics, you will start completing the levels faster and faster.


Overall, I think it's a great game to keep in the library and I always go back to it from time to time because it's just so satisfying,relaxing and easy to lose yourself in (Eminem?).

Portal 2 is a masterpiece gameplay wise. It does what Portal started, but adds new elements to play with, adds more to the story and universe and even coop mode. As a single player game, you can have tons of fun, there are good amount of secrets in it and doesn't feel boring at all (well maybe for the [spoiler] old Aperture Science part[/spoiler] but that's my opinion, also you can solve community made maps and map packs, which some of them really awesome. As a CO-OP game... well this is one of the best CO-OP experience I ever experienced. For 2011, the game looks and sounds great, controls are really easy.

The only thing I can nit pick on, is about the single and coop story mode, which you for me didn't had replay value.

But all in all, this one is an amazing game for anyone, there is no question about trying it out. For 8.2€, it's a steal, just go for it!

There are community made maps for single player and co-op, there are so many well made community maps that feel like they were produced by a game studio. You can even make your own map if you wanted to. SOOO many easter eggs and secrets in this game its unreal. There are barely any glitches that you can just run into during game play. Even the title screen changes depending on where you are in the game. The community for this game is insane. Speedrunning this game is insane, if you somehow feel like you are getting bored of this game, then try speedrunning it. This is honestly one of the best games i have ever played. Oh and i forgot to mention... THE CUSTOM MODS FOR THIS GAME IS INSANE!!!! If you have this game you should really consider downloading the mods for this game, some even just straight up make a whole new game with new mechanics and a whole story with new characters and its just the coolest thing ever, examples are: Portal Stories Mel, Portal Reloaded and Aperture Tag just to name a tiny amount of them. This game is perhaps one of, if not my most favourite game of all time.

+ Engaging lightweight narration through AI monologues and details in the environment.
+ Great sound design, voice acting, and music.

(This review is just about the campaign, not the editor/workshop/co-op/etc)

I love shooting a portal at the wrong spot because I literally can't see the platform I'm trying to make the portal appear next to and falling to my death once I go through it so I have to wait for the game to reload the entire level and set me back 30 seconds for a scripted section that also doesn't work properly so I have to wait another 30 seconds.

For 3/4 of the game I was having fun, but it suddenly devolved into these shitty esoteric puzzles with fifteen million conflicting mechanics that result in solutions that don't logically follow because they rely on features integrated into the convoluted systems instead of actual intuition (as in you have to know EVERY single thing a specific mechanic can do or can't do in every context, keeping in mind the non-deterministic nature of the Source engine and other sources of error like slightly misaligned portals and the garbage slow "smoothed" movement that feels more like I am a rhinoceros than a human). Wheatley constantly repeating the same unfunny voice line every time the game completely reloads the level because the physics in Source aren't deterministic and the light tunnel decided to not work this time does not help matters. This went from "fun game" to "math homework except with questions that randomly deviate from the laws of mathematics" in like 3 hours. Oh, and it's the Source engine, so bump the randomness up by a factor of 10. Did I mention that I spent an entire day trying to fix stuttering that made the game unplayable? If you want to know what it was, you need to have the game installed on an SSD or it'll just hang every 3 seconds for no reason. I don't know what it is about Valve games and being great most of the time except for one specific section where they just ran out of ideas or something, like the HL2 canals for example. Most of the latter quarter of this game is thinking of a fun out-of-the-box solution and it not even slightly working, but not because it wouldn't work in theory. Theoretically you could run yourself through a portal loop to gain momentum and then turn around mid-air to fire the exit portal on an angled wall to make a jump, but that of course doesn't work because 1. it's fun and 2. the momentum you end up with is basically random (thanks Source) and the angle is wrong anyway. The ACTUAL solution (that I didn't look up, by the way) is to place portals on two opposing walls to spray them with portal-conducting goop, alternating walls and gaining height each time, then using those to get to a catwalk, falling from it onto more portal goop and flying out of the angled plate. If you like looking up solutions in walkthroughs and scoffing as the guy basically exploits the game to win you can be my guest, but I don't like doing math homework. It's funny, because in Portal 1 when I got stuck I just stopped playing the game instead of ripping my hair out because the game was actively fucking with me and yelling in my ear constantly with this stupid 16-year-old-redditor-that-thinks-he's-really-funny sense of humor.

I don't think Portal 2 is as legendary as it was heralded to be back in its prime, but it was still very good.

Portal 2 is considered to be one of the best puzzle games of the 2010's and my god, I could not agree more. 
While I do have some gripes with some minor elements of the game, I personally enjoy this game lots and love to replay it.

Firstly, the cast of characters in this game is tight while also being a little more loose compared to Portal 1. GladOS, lacking her cores from the first game, is actually quite alive and cynical compared to her cold, artificial presence in Portal 1. Wheatley serves as the nice counterpart to GladOS as he serves as our companion for some... of the game, guiding us to take her down despite constantly being a klutz. Wonder why that's the case? And finally, we have one of my favorite characters in gaming ever, CAVE JOHNSON voiced by none other than J.K. Simmons. Cave is the perfect character that narrates the second third of the game that balances witty, one-liner CEO talk with a sad and depressing story of Aperture falling from grace back in it's hayday. Only someone like J.K. could play a role like that so well. I mean, look at Whiplash.

Secondly, the game mechanics are spot on. Both building on and expanding topics covered in Portal 1, Portal 2 updates it's mechanics to fit a longer experience and slowly, I mean SLOWLY, introduces them throughout the WHOLE GAME, keeping you engaged whenever a new material is thrown into the test chamber with you. The satisfaction of soaring through a portal or the bounce of a gel makes me marvel at the smoothness and creativity of it all. I also appreciate the addition of light movement towards portals to help with correction trajectories.

Finally, the soundtrack and atmosphere of Portal 2 fits so well for the story it tries to tell. While Portal 1's atmosphere was artificial and science-fiction, Portal 2 opts for a post-apocalyptic feeling both in visuals, using overgrown plants and fallen shrapnel to make the place look worse for wear, and also in the music, abandoning the cold, ambient droning tones like the sounds of fluorescent light bulbs to an industrial, sci-fi and gloomy sound palette. It's a nice contradiction to what Portal 1 represents and helps make the game feel larger in life.

However, my only gripe with this game comes from my constant tendency for 100% games. If you want to 100% Portal 2, you better have a friend who wants to as well because a quarter of the achievements in total are for co-op and definitely require teamwork, dedication, and maybe buying someone a copy of the game just to help. While it might come off as petty, the fact that one of the achievements in this game involves completing the tutorial for Portal 2 co-op with someone who has never touched it and you have had to complete it fully is quite absurd. 

Overall, Portal 2 is quite the spectacle in gaming. Combining a myriad of sci-fi, comedy and puzzle aspects together into one big pot of Aperture Science goop for you to test with. It's surely worth the hype and anyone wanting to experience an action-packed, brainteaser puzzle game should BUY THIS NOW. 

P.S: When you finish the game, DON'T SKIP OUT ON THE MODS TO THIS GAME. There are some quite talented fans of the game who have created full games themselves based on mechanics of Portal 2. Check out Portal Stories: Mel or Aperture Tag for a start.

What's there to say that hasn't been said already?

This bad boy includes, but is not limited to:
- A gun which lets you shoot wormholes on walls allowing you to travel through the timespace continuum
- Dozens of puzzle elements which all interact with portals and eachother in interesting ways
- Plot twists, plot twists everywhere
- A super tragic, believeable, perfectly revealed story
- 500 gigatons of god tier comedy which still get a smile out of me on the [i] nine nine nine nine       nine nine nine [/i] th playthrough
- Hillarious robot characters, one of which voiced by STEVE MERCHANT
- A way for literally anyone to make a puzzle themselves with the most user-friendly level editor ever created
AND SO MUCH MORE
Buy this game. Now. DO IT. THIS IS A THREAT (jk) (kinda) (do at least watch a play-through of the first though) ok BYYYEEEEEEEEE

Ive been playing Portal and Portal 2 for years and love it!!
Incredible classic. Has aged extremely well.

Portal 2 is just flat out fun. The single player is short (about 6-7 hours worth of play time) and isn't as challenging as Portal but it's much more creative and a joy to play. Co-op is incredibly fun and really is the best part about the game.

The only flaws that I can find (and it's a nit pick anyway) are that like the first it is decidedly linear (but the environments are much more open and you don't feel as cramped) and that some of the solutions to the scripted events feel a little overly convenient.

This is a top notch title that's simply fun to play.

I completed the game a couple days ago, and I believe many will agree with me on the fact that Portal 2 is nothing short of absolutely phenomenal. The puzzles are creative and fun to figure out, the story line is interesting yet dark, the characters are hilarious, and Want You Gone absolutely slaps. It's no wonder that it's the highest rated game on Steam.

Portal 2 is a sequel to the puzzle game Portal. Portal is a game about portals which basically teleport you around. Portal 2 is a great sequel. The scenes are very cinematic and detailed that, in my opinion, this game looks like it was released in 2020. Overall, this game is great and I think you should buy it.

Portal 2 is literally one of the most polished, detailed, and most well written games I’ve ever played. Even a decade later it’s still more fun and more cleverly designed than many modern games, and it’s a true testiment to how amazing Valve can be when they actually give a crap. The small details of random panels jerking and attempting to fold back into place make it truly feel like a run down testing facility, and the dialogue is more funny and entertaining than most shows I’ve watched. Despite there only being a few characters, they all have loads of personality (excluding Chell), and even the mostly mute Peabody and Atlas are filled to the brim with character. The story is super cool, and perfectly bounces off of the story of the first game. I could spend paragraphs and paragraphs describing the excellency of this game, but it speaks for itself. This game is a must buy no matter the price, which is even better considering how cheap the game is. This is one of the few games that I’d give a proper 11/11 chunks of pure marble.

so, I managed to fix the game's audio bug, however it needs to be done every other time you open the game. you open the console, and type "snd_rebuildaudiocache". you then wait a while, then sign out of your computer, DO NOT SHUT DOWN. you will then log back in, and open the game. it SHOULD then be fixed.
now, if you don't know what the "console" that I'm talking about is, you need to go into the "options" tab in the game, "go into the "keyboard" tab, then look for an option I believe to be labeled "developer console". it is automatically set to disabled. enable it, then type the command I listed above, and follow the listed instructions, and that SHOULD be it.
Other than this audio issue, the game is great.

I’m gonna voice the unpopular opinion here and say the original game was better. Obviously, it was cheaper. If you just care about puzzles, then get both this game and the original. But if you care about atmosphere and ambience, this game is a big step down. For me, a big element in making Portal what it was was the mysterious, silent, and slightly creepy environment in which you worked in. Cameras watching your every move, but never a soul behind those glazed windows. Occasionally a sign of something being off. A panel was removed, revealing a crawl space where it appeared some deranged person had been living. They also used the ambience found in Ravenholm. Portal two may have some similar looking environments…but now they’re spoiled by Glados, wheatley, or Johnson yelling over the intercom and jabbering constantly. Nevermind the obnoxious and ham fisted cake and companion cube references. Less can be more, and this game is proof of that.

The basic mechanic (retained from the first game) is so ingeniously simple that the game almost makes itself. What I mean is, the entire game-play loop is exhausted in the portal mechanic itself, leaving more or less the entire development process for Valve to do what they do best: wonderfully creative and clever level design. Additionally, the script is next-level hilarious and the AI protagonists are pure gold. You can tell the devs had loads of fun making it, and that definitely rubs off on the player. In short, it's a brilliant game, one of the few which transcend their genre: pretty much everyone who plays this will love it, not just fans of puzzle games.

This game saved my life.

I am 51.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

As good as the single-player story is, the co-operative is the real highlight of Portal 2. The beginning of the co-op picks up right after the end of the single-player game, giving you and your partner control of two robots, and serves as a continuation of the story of Aperture Science. It features fewer characters than the single-player mode but is still filled with enough sharp writing, deadpan jokes and absurd humor to keep you entertained between puzzle sections and provide motivation toward an end goal. Better yet, instead of simply recycling puzzle designs from the single-player portion, the inclusion of another player significantly alters the way you need to think.

In Portal 2, communication is vital to success.

That's because each of the robotic co-operative characters carries a portal gun, which means two guns and four portals. Valve takes full advantage of the increased capacity for dimensional holes by raising the level of challenge and coordination required. As is obvious if you've ever played Left 4 Dead, Valve knows how a good co-operative mode requires a game design that doesn't simply encourage but requires you to work together. In Portal 2, communication is vital to success.

Getting through can be frustrating, especially if you're playing with someone you don't know, because there's no diffusion of responsibility here. You can't hide in a corner and wait for someone else to do all the work. The contributions of each person involved are plain to see, and Valve's developed numerous tools to help make communication as smooth as possible.

You can set context-sensitive markers on parts of the environment to wordlessly indicate where a portal should be placed, where a partner should move, and even trigger a countdown clock to synchronize when switches should be hit or buttons pressed. The indicators may feel superfluous at first, but once you're setting up four portal chains of light bridges to block turret fire or redirecting edgeless safety cubes as they fly through open air over bottomless pits, it's obvious how useful they can be. Barely a moment will go by in silence while playing Portal 2 with another, except when you're listening to GLaDOS belittle your intelligence with endearing sarcasm.

Man I'm genuinely surprised. I never thought I'd enjoy a puzzle game. Portal 1 proved me wrong. +The game looks beautiful, sounds great and plays really well.
+I love the characters. The voice acting, their personalities, the things they say and do. Its all perfect.
+Just like the first game really short loading times. It can get a bit annoying if you keep dying like i do but otherwise its not bad.
+The puzzles get a lot more complicated and we have a lot of new tools we can use to solve these puzzles.
+The game is a lot longer then the first one.
+From the start to the finish its all just a lot of fun. What else do you want from a game ?
+Co-op game mode ! You can play with your friends.

I really liked Portal 2, but have some comments for people who might be considering playing now.
Firstly, I loved the story and the dialogue and the levels were pretty solvable, though a couple near the end are really tricky. I have bad coordination, which made some 'boss' fights really finicky, however I found after like the fourth or fifth time dying I suddenly could get past the one block that was killing my time--whether that's the game adapting to my terrible gameplay or just me practicing enough, if you are like me and at the fifth time dying are about ready to give up, just know that you will get it! (Even if you need walkthroughs at times). I would replay this game though for the dialogue alone.
Saying that, as someone with ADHD, and whose playthrough was double the time it took to complete Portal, I have realized that my personal limit for story-based games is about 8 hours. I hyperfocus on the game, and the characters are so compelling I just want to play right through, which, I mean, you can do for fifteen hours straight, but it's not really well-advised. I did spread it out over like two or three days, but for those who get really swept up in the story and hyperfocus, just set some limits playing this game!

It is a good game. Graphics are amazing. Story is amazing. Gameplay is amazing. Music is amazing. Everything about this is amazing. They even have an area for making your own levels, which gives it the ability to be replayed and still be fun. Even the creators (Valve) think that this is the best game they have ever made. Wished there was a third (official) game. Portal Stories: Mel is cool, I just wished Valve cared more about not only portal, but their other games as well. Sure, some of these games did get other games for their series, like Half-Life Alyx, or Aperture Hand Lab. The only issue is that those games is that they aren't "threequels". Half-Life Alyx is a prequel of Half-Life 2, Aperture Hand Lab, I'm not even sure when this takes place, but it's definitely not after the events of Portal 2. In short, Portal 2 (and most of other Valve's games) is good, the only issue is that the company dislikes "threequels". Also a "threequel" is like a third title in a series, forgot to mention that. I recommend playing this if you can get your hands on it.
