My Opinion on Portal 2: (OPINION AND POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING)

Portal is a great game series,  P2's mods are great as well. 

Whats Portal about?

 Portal  follows Chell, a test subject going through Aperture Science with the Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System, or GLaDOS for short, watching you complete test chamber after test chamber. GLaDOS is trying to kill you (Chell). Like Half-Life and Half-Life 2, the protagonist (You) is happily silent. You are equipped with the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device. (ASHPD or Portal Gun) Your goal is to escape Aperture Science, Don't die, and kill GLaDOS.

Whats my thoughts on Portal? 

Portal 2 is an amazing game. it introduced Co-op, they had cosmetics. (didn't really work out) The cosmetics were probably being tried in Portal 2, scrapped, and used in Team Fortress 2. (works a lot better there.)
Portal 2 is a game I, and many others hold close to their heart. 

I found Portal probably around 2014. I was screwing around on my PlayStation 3 and I found Portal 2 in the XMB menu. I played it. liked it, never played it again until last year. It wraps the story up pretty good. If you want Portal 3, I recommend a mod for Portal 2 called Portal Stories: Mel. 

What do I not like about Portal 2?

That I wont be able to experience it for the first time again.

In conclusion, Portal is one of the best puzzle games out there. If you haven't played the games, play them! They are almopst always on sale.

The product known as Kraft Dinner (KD) in Canada, Kraft Macaroni & Cheese in the United States and Australia, and Macaroni Cheese in the United Kingdom is a nonperishable, packaged dry macaroni product by Kraft Foods Group, traditionally cardboard-boxed with dried macaroni pasta and a packet of processed cheese powder. It was first introduced under the Kraft Dinner name simultaneously in both Canada and the U.S. in 1937.[1] The brand is popular with Canadians, who consume 55% more boxes per capita than Americans.[2]

There are now many similar products, including private label, of nonperishable boxed macaroni and cheese. Commercially, the line has evolved, with deluxe varieties marketed with liquid processed cheese, as well as microwavable frozen mac-and-cheese meals. The product by Kraft has developed into many flavor variations and formulations, including Easy Mac (a product that has been renamed Macaroni & Cheese Dinner Cups), a single-serving product designed specifically for microwave oven.

The product's innovation, at the time of the Great Depression, was to conveniently market nonperishable dried macaroni noodles together with a processed cheese powder. The product is prepared by cooking the pasta and adding the cheese powder along with additional perishable and/or refrigerated ingredients such as butter (or margarine) and milk. The product is thus a simple-to-prepare, affordable, and meatless family dinner.

8.2/10. Better puzzles, better environments, more storytelling, more game. I might maybe love GLaDOS now too. Lots more music that straight up bangs (faith plate I'm looking at you) and all around more cool stuff to look at and mess with. If you liked Portal you'll love Portal 2, and if you haven't played Portal, this is better in every way.

There is a ton of character in this game. Everywhere you visit feels real and detailed, taking a departure from that sterile test chamber feel that was 80% of Portal to get behind the curtain. Portal 2 uses that to its advantage. There is a ton of dialogue (maybe a little too much?), GLaDOS herself somehow got even better. I don't know what they did but she's more than the voice informing you of this next test.

Moving on to the actual puzzles and stuff, there's a lot more of them, and new things to do, but there's a surprising amount of "walk from here to there but you need portals once or twice". It's a great opportunity to fit in some visuals, when you're not busy figuring out a puzzle, but sometimes I didn't even look around since I was busy trying to get to the next area. I got lost more than a few times, as in, I literally didn't know where to put my portal. The zoom feature is very nice but doesn't always make up for portal surfaces being teeny tiny. That and I just didn't see obvious stuff right away, which didn't always sting! Most of the tricky maneuvers you need come up again later on instead of being a one-time solution, so finally getting it stays satisfying instead of frustrating.

I loved the parts where I was on my own, no exit sign, no Wheatley, no prompts to interact with the only thing in the room. Getting to do it on my own was probably the most fun part in this game. I wish more was like that, honestly, because that's what I feel like a Portal game should be all about. Unfortunately, even when you're all alone, the game doesn't give you any time to figure it out before putting a big pop-up that says "USE [E] HERE", which really breaks that "hey look I'm doing it!" feeling. If it's not that, it's Wheatley literally telling you what to do.

Speaking of, Wheatley wouldn't shut up AT ALL EVER. Literally everywhere he could talk to you he had two or three MINUTES of dialogue where he just kept going on and on, and in that style of dialogue that's all "look at me I'm so witty and funny anyway here's exactly what you need to do and it's very obvious but I'm just making sure you know but maybe you're stupid so I just wanted to spell it out for you" that I got very tired of very quickly. They kept GLaDOS mostly the same from Portal, where she would speak like she wasn't chasing a reaction with every word. I much prefer that kind of dialogue, and it's a shame such a major character had none of it.

I haven't tried co-op yet, but I'm sure it's fun. I've played other co-op games so it doesn't really matter how good it is, since they're always fun with friends, but yeah. Just watch someone like Grayfruit play it.

Actual review: It took me probably about 10 hours to finish the game. The levels range from very hard to very easy. The levels do not require much skill (no super fast reaction times required), but do require you to think (with portals).The last level, however, is time limited, but most levels and interactions are not time limited at all. This is not, however, the type of game that you play a few minutes at a time. It takes anywhere from 5 minutes to 1 hour to complete a level, and after you complete a level, you will want to do more. The story is very good (funny, interesting, unexpected). Also, since its an older game, it gets put on sale, and it'll (probably - not tested) run on integrated graphics just fine.

This is one of my favorite games ever made. I play this and the first one at least once every 2 or 3 years because i love them so much. The 2nd game is obviously much better than the first because the first was just a tech demo, that they didnt expect to be popular, but it was and they made a sequal a thousand times better than any one could have imagined. This game also shines due to the fact that they got an insane voice cast. Ellen McLain reprised her role as GLaDOS which is surprising cause in the first game she sounds so different than in this game. Stephen Merchant plays the robot core Wheatley who is honestly one of the most surprisingly good villains ive ever seen. This entire cast is amazing but in my opinion the best actor in this game is J.K. Simmons. When i first played this game i recognized the voice of Cave Johnson and didnt know why, but it kept reminding me of J. Jonah Jameson from the Tobey Maguire Spider-Man movies, and now the Tom Holland movies, i didnt know why. then i googled the cast of this game and he showed up i obivously found out why. But in this game J.K. Simmons plays Cave Johnson who is the past owner of the Aperture Science company. He does such an amazing job that when hes yelling one of his pre-recorded messages it feels like your Tobey Maguire and hes telling you he wants pictures of Spider-Man. Anyway this review is way too long and if your not convinced to buy this game yet, its your own fault for missing one of the best games ever made.

I pulled the game out of the depths of my library to catch up on the missing achievements and saw that I haven't written a review yet. So, let's catch up on that:

I played both games back to back and I like the second one better for several reasons:

- Wheatley is awesome and so you have Glados AND Wheatley together.
- I like best the game sections that are outside the normal test chambers and the second part has more of them.
- the puzzles with the gels are a great innovation and fun

Valve has really created something great and anyone who has not played the Portal games should do so immediately.

I'll play Portal Stories Mel right after this, just like I did back then. Because this game (btw one of many unique mods for Portal, which are available for free in the Steam Store) contains something: tests where you have to puzzle to solve them and where it does not depend on skill. 
That would be the only criticism I have of the Portal games. Some test chambers and sections of the game have to do with timing and that can be very annoying, especially if you want to play comfortably and relaxed.
Good story, but AMAZING multiplayer experience, even years after its initial release it still holds up.

This game is one of my top 5 favorites period. I've played through both the single-player and co-op campaigns at least twice. This game's unique combination of puzzle solving, parkour and communication just has no equal. Solving each "escape room" using both the tools provided (portal guns/blocks etc) and the physics engine (gaining speed from falling, body blocking to stop movement) is SO SATISFYING that you just have to "do one more" before getting off to do whatever you know, you should really be doing. Even though each room has an obvious path to complete it, the way you discover the answer is completely up to you in a "trail and error" way of thinking about how to overcome the challenge. Honestly I consider this game somewhat of a "must-play". Some of my best gaming memories are from playing this game with a special friend(s). 10/10. This game goes on sale quite often for like 2$ so make sure to buy it for friend sometime too. Coop is really where this game hits the hardest.

Portal 2 is a game you have to play. For what it is, Valve masterfully crafted the experience's gameplay and storytelling elements into an instant-classic. The innovations on the gameplay-side since Portal 1 are wonderful, and the gradual difficulty progression curve keeps you in a flow state even as the game gets exponentially harder than the first hour of the game. It's so well-thought out how they introduce new tools to your arsenal and mental frameworks for approaching puzzles that they clearly spent as much time and playtesting as they needed to nail it down.

The only weak point is the story/narrative. For what it was for it's time, the lack of dialogue from the character and the interactions being limited to robots talking to your POV was like a 7/10 imo. Being largely an action puzzle game this can be kind of forgivable and the excuse that they were inspired by the end of 2001 a Space Odyssey and other human/robot relationships kind of covers them... it doesn't quite excuse the world feeling quite lonely or weak connection to the silent main character you play as. There should have been other human characters or in-game or over an intercomm having direct dialogue with the main character at the very least... It's a missed opportunity that any Portal 3 would surely fix, potentially making this classic become quite outdated.

The Portal series is now one of, if not my favorite games I've played to date. Portal 1 is significantly shorter, but both are still very easy to pick up and put down. I got them for a combined $3 USD during a sale, but honestly, despite having one of the worst price/hour ratios in my library at full price (about $1.20/hour), it is worth every cent, even without a sale. Like I've heard many times, One of the worst things about Portal is that you can never play it for the first time again, and I'd have to agree. These games are 100x better if you don't know anything about them. Not to mention it's got one of the best lines in gaming history ("So. How are you holding up? BECAUSE I'M A POTATO.").

TL;DR: The Portal series is phenomenal and can be obtained for much less than base price, but are worth every penny of full retail. Also go in as blind as possible.

And I must say, this is easily my favorite video game that I have ever played. Great writing, jokes, puzzles, and artistic composition. And all of these things are just as stunning the second time, and I am sure they will be on every other subsequent replay. My absolute favorite part of this game is the scale, as every time you get to see into the bowels of Aperture, you are taken aback by the horror and beauty of the abyss. Also I like the part with the potato, but that is all I'll say about it so it doesn't spoil the fun. Get this game alongside the first Portal, they are absolute necessary plays for anyone in my opinion.

As someone who has only gotten around to playing the Portal series recently, I was blown away by the sheer creativity and mind-bendingly clever design of these games.

A lot of times, you'll open up a new level, look around 5 secs in and think "man, I don't even know where to start" but as you pick up the pieces gradually, you'll find quite often the answer is hidden in an obvious but well-hidden manner. 
And when you finally do manage to put them together and work it out, it feels INCREDIBLY gratifying. At times, you'll do things that don't feel like they're possible at first.

The puzzles themselves are great, and very well-thought out, but what brings all of it together is the story. 
Whether you're a person who likes lore in games or not, you're bound to enjoy the tongue-in-cheek writing and fantastic VA performances present in Portal 2. 
Though there are only a handful of characters in the story, each one is different from the last and each add something to accentuate and contrast the tone of the game, in the best ways possible.

The first game was a monument of its own, bringing something completely new to gaming, and the sequel only builds upon it. I would recommend playing Portal 1 if you care about the story.

The art direction is something else I can truly commend with this game, there are a few different "locales" you visit over the course of the story and even though at times the colour palettes can feel minimal, it does a lot with what it's given to work with. 

And even when you're done with the story, there's a multiplayer campaign you can grab a friend along with and rack your brains together to. 

Overall, I can't recommend this enough, such a damn good game.

Aaah Portal 2... I've always wondered why the reception of this game was so positive, not only on the internet, but also among my friends. I never really understood it, because I don't like puzzle games and solving a puzzle never really gave me that dopamine hit that I get by playing Fps games or games with character building.
When I eventually got to play Portal 2 you better believe I was shocked. The puzzles were great, the narration was entertaining, the jokes and the dialogues were actually funny and the game still looked great even on the aging source engine. It was blasphemous that I refused to play this game just because of the puzzle genre stereotype that I was so used to. I still didn't get that dopamine hit I was crawing for, but the game gave me something else instead - a memorable story, characters and a satisfying ending.
Also the humour in this game can be outstanding, but not everyone will enjoy it and some people may be annoyed by it. I for one loved it, because it's the exact type of humour I love, but that is not universaly true for everyone. Just be aware of the possibility that it could completely miss the mark for you. 
Otherwise the game is amazing, please try it If you haven't before, snatch it on a sale and enjoy both the singleplayer's story as well as the co-op with a friend - you won't regret it.

Captivating story, great environment, and a classic.
One of my all-time favorite games. The best sequel ever, as well. It improves on the first game in every way possible and still makes me laugh consistently more than 7 years after I first played it.

OVERALL REVIEW:
10/10, I have many MANY hours but i have switched accounts, and this has been one of my favorite games for years its just a shame valve cant count past 2 otherwise maybe we would get a sequel, but sadly we wont. 

STORY:
It has really good story, and although its best you play the 1st game first (alot), you can just play this game and they explain everything again, and also explain a bit of the first game so you kind of know a bit of backstory for that game if you haven't played it.

PRICE:
Its always pretty cheap, about £7 (and in a bundle with the first game, about £10) but right now its £1 (christmas).

SPEEDRUN:
This game has tons of speedrun potential also, so if you like speedrunning you will probably like this game alot, its as if most of the game was based on speedrunning, BUT you don't need to know how to speedrun to play the game, cause its a great game either way, and if you want to, definitely recommend playing the whole game through atleast once before you start learning to speedrun.

COOP:
The coop is fun also, its an ENTIRE campaign in coop! So definitely get a friend to play it with you or something cause its just as fun as the single-player to me.
You can matchmake with random people too, but although that can still be fun, not as fun as with friends as usual in games.

EXTRAS:
The game also is pretty funny in general. And is a well written puzzle game, it doesnt put you straight into the incredibly complicated levels, starts off with putting a cube on a button... but after a while when you get to the harder levels, its still not too hard, so you dont have to look up the answers (but you might).

Both Portal and Portal 2 are classic games, introducing iconic characters, fascinating and innovative mechanics, and an entirely fresh take on a first-person shooter game. While some areas of the game are almost free-roam and it isn't always immediately clear where you're intended to go, the platforming is mostly straightforward, and the eventual payoff and the satisfaction of solving a puzzle or completing the game is generally worth it, at least in my opinion. I'd highly recommend the franchise to any and all people who like games.

Incredible game. Truly one of the best games on steam. GlaDOS and Wheatley are absolutely hilarious. Choosing which is better is a tough assignment. And the puzzles are really well done too. I had a tough time picturing how they would innovate on the previous game, and they succeeded. The only part of the game I didn't like was chapter 6 and 7. Without saying any spoilers, they were in very large, open rooms, and a lot of the difficulty I had was finding a hidden small segment of wall to portal to. The puzzles in those two chapters were a bit weird, although the new puzzle mechanic in those chapters was awesome. Those two chapters also contain a lot of lore, but the plot for those chapters was a bit hard to follow. 

Anyway awesome game, one of the best on steam. Buy it! Wait for a sale if you're unsure.

Edit: just finished the game. I'd give it a 9 out of 10. The game dragged on a bit long imo. But seriously, two of the funniest characters ever, the puzzles were mostly great, and the ending is amazing. I can't wait to play coop.

Portal 2 remains a shining achievement in gaming, a classic that stands as the masterpiece that many since its release have idolized, taken inspiration from, and iterated on. While the original Portal lays the groundwork for the game mechanically and narratively, Portal 2 runs with a bunch of new ideas and takes every idea to its next logical extreme. The writing is an evergreen flavor of funny, delivering comedy effortlessly unlike many games which try so hard to get a laugh. The game's main trio of performances cannot be understated, and set the tone behind dozens of intricately designed puzzle rooms that have a knowledgeable set of progression that never feels like a massive leap in understanding for the player. The sequel's best moments are traversing through open spaces finding just the right area to portal to (ha), and I hope if a third game ever sees the light, taking this idea to more open world level design (similar to a Control or Mario Odyssey structure) would be a further extension on the simple, but extraordinary power of the portal gun.

Might be the greatest sequel in history. SO many more levels, SO many more characters, SO much more backstory, and it even has co-op! Normally sequels just build off of the first game (I don't deny that this does too) but this doesn't build. It completely overshadows it. The first game was a pure classic, but this takes Portal into the modern era. The graphics are impeccable, showing you the full capabilities that Valve brings to the table. There are so many more voice actors, fully immersing you in a way that Portal never could. And the twist. Ah, the twist. To quote Jack Black, "A good story has a beginning. A middle. And the Twist." I never saw it coming. There is also so much more raw, delicious plot! An unlikely partnership, a painful backstab, and again, a beautifully-written song at the end. I recommend that all players of Portal and Half-Life should IMMEDIATELY get this game and play RIGHT NOW! But not just for Portal and Half-Life players. ALL gamers should put this on their wishlist, if they haven't already.

The Portal games are unlike any other kind of game out there. I think of it as a 'Cognitive Gauntlet', because you have to think your way around, and out. In "Portal 2", there are also so many user-created add-on's, that the game never has to end. In fact there is even an add-on now that is called "Cognitive Gauntlet". The  best part is, once you start playing, you'll never want it to end anyway. This is the only game where you are given a gun, but you are never expected to shoot anyone, because it makes portals instead of wounds or death.
    Out of all the games I have ever played, Portal 2 is at the very top place as my all-time favorite. My second all time favorite game is "The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim".
    I highly recommend Portal 2 to anyone who loves thinking things through, and solving puzzles.

I'm a massive fan of the original Portal, and I'd argue it's as close to technical perfection in game design as is possible. That being said, Portal 2 has a number of things going for it. It's far more visually interesting, the story is deeper, and the characters are three dimensional. New mechanics help the gameplay stay engaging, and the level editor greatly extends the replay value.

All that being said, some of the charm of the original is lost here. You won't get to know the game as intimately, because it's longer and less compact.

This review is long past due, I don't know how I didn't write a review for this game over so many years. But by far! The best game Valve has made. Portal 2 is the definition of a perfect puzzle game. It really makes you think in a different aspect with portals, it's so extraordinary. The story is absolutely outstanding and heartwarming, with comedic and lighthearted moments to cinematic scenes all while trying to escape Aperture Science. The visuals are nothing too captivating but very memorable. The audio is fantastic, Portal 2 has some of the best soundtracks I've heard out of any game it's perfect for trying to think while going through test chambers. Everything about the main game is perfect I could play it a hundred times, come back to it years later and play it again, and it would be still just as great as the first time I experienced it.

And least I forget, the co-op part of this game which feels like it should be its own separate game. I have spent hours on top of hours having the time of my life will all of my robot teammates I played with in the past solving puzzles. It's still so much fun to this day to play with a friend or finding a partner online. And it doesn't get old because the community makes just as challenging and entertaining puzzles like in the main story! Including the most exciting maps you can find on the workshop like Gelocity (which is a race) that I must mention. Portal 2 is a game that will always be a big part of my life, with so many memories that I will forever cherish dearly.

Although being a puzzle game, Portal 2 features extremely interesting, funny and absolutely great characters.
The gameplay is sometimes considered a "walking simulator" in certain parts of the game but this is sort of expected because the main focus is well... PuZzLeS aNd SciEncE!!
The graphics aged well, I'm not saying it's some tsunami in Aperture Science graphics where everything has glossy reflections, but the artstyle makes everything look much better, the lighting is pretty good for a 10 year old game too.
Now the soundtrack is something from a different universe, IT'S AMAZING, the music fits well with each section of the game and it's extremely epic and sometimes relaxing sort of.
The sound design is very good especially the sound of the cores just makes me want to hear it 24/7, although the portal gun doesn't sound as good as in the first game it's still sounds good, all the other sounds are incredible as well (Although a very small portion of the sounds was taken from Half-Life 2 As AlwAyS VaLVe)
The map design is very good considering the fact that the game doesn't fail to lead you to the current destination in certain sections of the game without any hints that just appear all over the screen in some games.

To be fair, I really don't like leaving negative reviews for valve games. Honestly, this game is pretty good gameplay wise. The gels and the lasers provide interesting ways to complete the chambers. Also the test chamber builder is neat, go check it out!

The unfortunate thing about this game is its incoherent and messy story that relies way too much on jokes in the plot to help me take it seriously. You might be thinking "Why would you take it seriously? It's a portal game!" But when the last game had the right amount of humor and a story that fit into the half-life canon very well that's a good thing. But when GlaDOS gains the ability to manipulate walls and make chambers any where anytime out of anything she pleases, or the game taking place "50,000" years after the last game (impossible because the tectonic plates in the earth would have crushed the old test chambers by then) and the earth looking spotless in the final boss (Combine?) and the very questionable final cutscene (Chell walking out into the open world) is really bothersome as I take Half-Life games and their related canons very seriously.

The humor. Oh god the humor. It's funny the first few times but it loses its merit later on, and crams all kinds of unfitting jokes down your throat and tortures you with them. It's like valve focused more on the humor than helping the plot make an ounce of sense.
This game is a must play. Super easy to get into and super cheap. 10/10

Based on the information provided, can you guess what game this review is for? What's it about? What kind of game is it?

Point is, these reviews are completely interchangeable. I bet if you took this exact review, and copy and pasted it to every game in your library, you'd get the top review for half of the games you put it on, even if you didn't change the check marks to fit each individual game.

In my opinion, the Steam community should stop encouraging this format and instead downvote them all into oblivion. Maybe it's just me, and I guess it's not THAT big a deal, but for someone that puts at least some effort into the reviews they write, it is a little disheartening that the steam community prefers lazy checklists that ultimately don't say anything specific about the games in question. Plus I don't see how they could ever actually influence someone's decision to purchase a game or not when so little information is given.

Anyone agree or am I the only one that wants to read legitimately helpful reviews for games I might be interested in?

Postal 2 is a 2003 first-person shooter developed by Running with Scissors. It is the sequel to the 1997 game Postal and was released for Microsoft Windows in April 2003, macOS in April 2004 and Linux in April 2005. Postal 2, as well as its predecessor, have received notoriety for their high levels of violence, stereotyping, and black comedy. Unlike the first game, Postal 2 is played completely in first-person based on the Unreal Engine 2.

Set in the fictional town of Paradise, Postal 2 follows the life of "The Postal Dude", who must carry out mundane tasks throughout an in-game week, with the player deciding how violently or passively he will react to various situations. The player navigates the open world to carry out his chores, with player choice having an effect on the setting.

The game received a mixed reception from critics upon its release. The game has received several expansion packs, and in December 2003, a multiplayer expansion was released, titled Postal 2: Share the Pain. The game remains continually updated, with a new expansion pack titled Paradise Lost released in April 2015.

The game received attention for its violent gameplay, and was responsible for multiple controversies.[4] The game was followed by a sequel, Postal III, in December 2011.

Much like the first game, Portal 2 is very tightly paced, but I'd be lying if I said I thought as highly of the puzzles in this game as the first game. Don't get me wrong- they're still fun to solve, utilize physics properties creatively, have clever mechanics and get your brain thinking. But they're not quite as open-ended as the first game's. The puzzles in the first game could usually be solved in more than one way, but in 2 they feel much more restrictive. The puzzles are still fun to solve but it certainly hurts the story's replay value, especially since the puzzles don't quite reach the same level of challenge as the first game. Speaking of the story, it's executed a bit less than optimally as well in my opinion. Portal's story gave a nice contrast between comedic brashness and dark undertones but Portal 2's can't seem to stop reminding you how humorous the dialogue is at all times. It's well written dialogue for sure, but it's just not a very good continuation of Portal 1's atmosphere. It also tends to include some more heavy handed plot-twist moments that don't feel very in line with the spirit of Portal to me personally. Despite those issues the game is still very much fantastic. The dialogue is clever, the new puzzle mechanics are interesting, the progression is great, the variety is even better than the first game and the polish is immaculate. The soundtrack and sound effects are great additions that reflect the curious solitude of the test chambers adeptly. Overall it's a very good sequel despite some hurdles that kept it fro, becoming amazing. It feels like Valve leaned a bit harder into the Portal that the fanbase saw versus the Portal that they saw and created something based on that train of thought.

[h1]Portal 2 is a Masterpiece![/h1]
Portal 2 is amazing. It is the most well-rounded, thought out, and polished game that i have ever played. It is the single highest rated game on steam, and one of the most iconic video games of all time. I think it may even be my favourite game of all time.

[h2] Sum-Up[/h2]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Pros[/th]
        [th]Cons[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]
        1. Great story
        2. Superb humor
        3. Interesting puzzles
        4. Fun Co-Op
        [/td]

        [td]
        No Cons
        [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Bugs & Issues[/th]
        [th]Specs[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]
        - No bugs
        [/td]
        [td]
        - i5 10400f
        - 2070 super
        - 32GB RAM
        - 1080p 280hz monitor
        [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Rating:[/th]
        [td]10/10. This game is a Masterpiece.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [th]Is it worth buying?[/th]
        [td]Yes. The 8 dollars you spend on this game is the best 8 dollars you will ever spend. It is truly worth every cent.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [th]Content & Replay Value:[/th]
        [td]The campaign will take you around 5 hours to complete, and with over 700k workshop items and great fun in coop, I would say the replay value in this game is more then enough.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h2]Pros[/h2]
[b]1. [/b]
Your goal is once again to escape. The writing and the way that the plot develops has a perfect execution, and all of the world building that takes place throughout the narrative makes sense and fits perfectly into the lore of the world. On top of this, the pacing of the world is perfect and split onto various sections with a different major event happening in each of them. The story is great and when you think you get it, it turns the entire story around and flips up the characters. As you’re working towards your escape, the plot line serves as a backdrop for the puzzles and problems that you’re solving along the way. It is the perfect balance between narrative and gameplay, and everything ties together perfectly.

[b]2.[/b]
Many games struggle with humor. They either try too hard, and create unbelievable and unrealistic characters, or they don’t try hard enough, and it ends up being too serious. I believe Portal 2 is the perfect middle ground. GLaDOS constantly hurls insults at you, and the humor is extremely dark and depressing. It makes her into a much more well-rounded villain, and adds some depth to what would otherwise be a stale and overdone redemption story. Many of the jokes in this game had me laughing out loud and it seemed extremely fitting with the setting and situation. Her dark and dry humor is accented perfectly with Wheatly’s charismatic and energetic personality, and the combo go together perfectly. The underlying comedy helps to turn the story into something much more lively and engaging. 

[b]3. [/b]
The puzzles in portal are absolutely mind-bending. They make use of objects in the environment, as well as the levels themselves, and even the physics system in the game. You cant simply portal your way to the other side, you have to make use of light bridges, lasers, jump pads, and other entities in order to overcome the obstacles that you’re presented with. Not to mention the addition of the gels that really change up the gameplay from the first game and make for some interesting puzzles later on in your play through. Long story short, the puzzles in Portal 2 are amazing!

[b]4. [/b]
You can play through portal 2 in single-player mode, and go through the story with all of its ups and downs. And this is where a majority of this review is centered, but imagine going through the rooms with not two, but four portals. The complexity found in the puzzles really shines when you put your head together with a friend in order to figure out what the hell is going on. The Co-Op is about 5 hours long and you can team up with a friend to try and make it through all of the challenging levels without the story and plot found in the campaign. It is more of a cooperative puzzle-solving experience instead of a plot, and it really requires good teamwork. 

[h2]Cons / Bugs[/h2]
I find it truly rare these days to find a game with no cons or bugs. It is just my subjective opinion, but even so, it is very rare that I find games like this. I believe it is important to note that, and it should get some praise for being so great.

[h3]The Judgement: Portal 2 is a true masterpiece[/h3]
The outstanding story, awesome puzzles and amazing humor is showcased due to the simplicity and intentionality found in this game. Everything in the game is there for a reason, and that reason is highlighted once again by the amazing story. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun and challenging game.

Hard to follow up a game as great the first, but this one does alright. I wouldn't say it's as good, but it's more of the first in many ways through different chambers, and that in itself is enjoyable enough. Honestly, all Portal 1 needed were 2's level creation tools, and you could have almost done without 2.

However, its narrative really does carry the game well, much as it did with the first, so one can't discount it altogether. Both Portal games are standouts in first-person games insofar as flipping them on their head a bit, both in terms of non-violent gameplay and the significance of the narrative.

Engaging puzzles, great story/world building and an amazing follow up to the first game; While the first portal was severely lacking in the story department, portal 2 excels at not only keeping you intrigued by it’s narrative, but it’s also hilarious the entire time, at times even catching you off guard. Furthermore, the game is even better with friends when playing the Co-op campaign. If you haven’t played it yet, you are doing yourself a disservice. Plus, it turned 10 this year, so you’re already very late to the party.

~BENEFITS~  Story mode is extremely engaging in puzzles and story.  The CO-OP is always fun to play, either with a friend, or a random person on the game.  The Community test chambers vary in difficulty ranging from easy to painfully hard to solve.  The unique Sci-Fi atmosphere and witty dark humor never gets tiring while playing.

~DOWNSIDES~  Story mode can be completed in a short amount of time, 10 hours at max,  and if you have a decent memory you can easily resolve the puzzles,  so unless you want to play the game for just the story (like I do) you might want to play the community test chambers, since they offer a lot of diversity when it comes to puzzles instead of playing through the story mode again.

~CONCLUSION~
Portal 2 has aged incredibly well over the past 10+ years,  with iconic characters, locations, and story still being relevant to this day.  If you haven't played, don't hesitate on experiencing this gem of a game.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

this is my favorite game of all time. the arid setting and star-rattling soundtrack go so so SO well together. the puzzles are not only fun and challenging, but also just have better new mechanics than the first game. gone is waiting for some electric orb to slowly make its way down a hall - now you get to spray a bunch of shit everywhere that improves your mobility and lets you place more portals. or you can take a ride on those switches that launch anything that happens to land on it.

the game improves in the writing aspect, too. throwing wheatley into the mix makes the story much more engaging and makes it so that the game isnt over in 2 hours. the dark humor here is on point, and the ending is surprisingly sentimental and beautiful. the graphics are a sight to behold, too.

the multiplayer here is pretty much just coop portal gameplay, and having that extra player changes the way you have to think about every puzzle you see, because now you have a wholeass other living thing to account for.

this game is beyond perfect. venturebeat can eat my rosy ass.

If you consider yourself a full on gamer on PC/XBox 360/PS3 and have not played this (and its predecessor) then you are lying to yourself. If you can't seem to finish the game then push on through, watch some walkthroughs, that sort of stuff. The reward will be satisfying. This game is the pinnacle of perfection, a perfect sequel to a perfect game. I would NOT suggest trying to finish this for non-gamers (unlike I would with Portal), yet I would recommend anyone to take a look whenever they can. The graphics are still stunning even to this day and the game is made even better with the inclusion of a workshop for maps as well as a map builder. Of course Hammer would be better if you could use it but lets admit, I tried working with hammer and I must say, the basics left me in a state of keeping away for a wee while. Not to say that it's rocket science, flute sheet music or installing Gentoo but just saying.
What I really have to say is that this is a timeless classic which I recommend to anyone interested, as long as they have played the first game. This is usually on sale for pretty cheap anyway (I got both games in the Portal pack which I got a HUGE deal on for just about $3.50 NZD) so I don't see why you would hesitate to get it.

In my opinion PORTAL 2 is one of the best puzzle and story mode video games in my Steam library. The game contains puzzle levels, where you have to think if you want to solve them, interesting and crazy game's stories, cool characters and nice graphics. There are some crazy and funny jokes and moments in the game. Also there're two stories in the game - singleplayer (about Chell) and cooperative (about Atlas and P-body). The coolest thing is that there are different levels for the two stories, and in my opinion the levels in the cooperative story are more interesting than the other.  I don't think the game has drawbacks. The game's graphics are better than the first one and the both games are not expensive. So I recommend this game to puzzles' fans (and of course people, which like to use their brains) and to people who like video games where they play with your friend in co-op and use the power of teamwork. I hope you enjoy it!!

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]I certainly enjoyed the gameplay a lot and the coop is my fav "Portal" game for sure, and 6 is still a "pretty good" in my book. HOWEVER, if you had told me I was going to put that for Portal 2 back when I started it, I wouldn't have believed you. I mean these are just numbers anyway, but well. Gives you an idea.The original is one of my favorite games and I put a 9 on that because of how inventive, crisp and engaging the campaign was. Portal 2 is just more of the same things, it has lesser of all 3 I mentioned. By virtue of being a sequel, it obviously can't be equally as novel, but the problem is that MORE OF THE SAME also translates into the quantity, more so than the quality. This game is more than 4x longer than it should be. And the specificity of the mechanics does not warrant this length. The first game had 19 chambers and 3 additional rooms. This one has [b]37 chambers and 22 additional rooms[/b]. Which are bigger. By the end, I was begging for the game to be over since unlike the prv one, there wasn't a progression in difficulty, but more of a flatline near half-game after which it just refused to end. Apart from the length, another thing that I didn't like was the increased prevalence of "find the white marker across the whole map to portal to". It shifts half the challenge in the game from puzzle-solving to just standing and looking for a spot. They know it was going to be a "thing" hence the zoom button too. And I'm not a fan of this addition, personally. It ends up bloating a lot of the playtime.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]Portal 2 certainly wanted to have more of a "AAA story" compared to 1, which would certainly be some people's preference, but for me, the simplicity and intrigue of 1 was what did the most for me. And while I enjoyed Cave Johnson a lot, I kinda got saturated by the lore behind each and everything. There was some dialogue going on every single second. The humor seemed to be more r/fellowkids at times, in contrast to the mysterious and almost dark vibe of the previous. But I did enjoy the "final portal" shot and that whole sequence leading up to the overall "eh" finale. So, as you can tell, I both love and hate the game. I know one thing for sure though, that Portal 2 kinda lifted the veil of mystery that 1 had cast years ago, simplifying and materializing the world a whole lot for the player, for better or worse.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]The good ol' signature Portal look.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]9[/td]
	[td]It's built on the same engine as 1, so the mechanics are just as good. Everything from the movement, to mid-air physics, is great. This game also adds fluid mechanics which end up adding a lot of fun ways to solve puzzles.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]As I mentioned above, I didn't like the shift in the "kind" of challenge that was present in a lot of the game, where simply finding "where" to shoot the portal was the challenge. I don't want to discount some of the great puzzles in there btw, so credit where it's due. But you need to wade through a lot of filler to get to those. I did end up finding the game easier than 1, but I'm sure that's because I already know how to think in the way the game needs. Another thing that could've affected is I played the coop campaign a couple years ago itself, and my friend and I went directly into the BONUS content mistakenly. But I do think I'm not the only one who would've found 2 to be easier than 1. By the end, you had levels in Portal 1 with multiple solutions, one where you had to portal mid-air and shit. There's nothing that "climax feeling" as that in 2. But also, it's also a matter of the difficulty curve more than difficulty. Had the game been restricted to a shorter length, they would've had more control of the increment in challenge.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]I kinda began to feel the variety lacked in comparison to the game's runtime. While the fluids, gravity rays etc. were good fun for like the first 10ish levels I had em, the patterns began repeating pretty quickly with those.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]6[/td]
	[td]The "more" ending up to become less principle followed in the map design as well. While Portal 2 has some of the best puzzles out of the 2 games as well, I can still somehow only remember 1 or 2 of them even though I just finished the game over the course of the past few months - compared to a lot of memorable bits from Portal 1. In Portal 1, every element in the level followed a "Chekhov's Gun" kind of rule, where it ended up serving some purpose or another, and some puzzles still ended up having multiple solutions. But in 2, there were white patches everywhere around, most of them with no application. You could consider it a good thing, to confuse the player, but that isn't the way I appreciate challenge being added, since the difficulty when you spotted the "correct white patch" wasn't that difficult. And a lot of the level design ended up boiling down to "find the correct white patch", with only a few "solve the actual puzzle using all of these white patches" that 1 did.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]The voice acting, sound design etc. is still just as excellent. JK Simmons was great.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]I like the minimal UI, as the game shows everything important within the world itself. One thing that really bugged me was literal paragraphs of subtitles that show up whenever someone starts talking. I'm not even kidding, I've never seen a game be this bad with it, at least from what I recall. I ended up shutting them despite preferring to have them on during gameplay simply for this reason.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]The game runs really well, and is more than a steal for its price even without a sale.[/td]
    [/tr]

	[td]I don't judge puzzle games on their replay value. Only genre I do that with.[/td]
    [/tr]

Replay: a fantastic sequel that adds new movement mechanics to the portal dynamic. I felt like this one takes the kid gloves off much sooner. Loved how the story naturally allowed the levels to flow from tests to urban exploration, then back and forth as you zero in on Wheatley. The writing is better than I remember. I absolutely loved trying to squeeze the proverbial lemon out of all of the voiced characters that I could. Some very cool reactivity to whether or not you actually backtrack when NPCs bluff you. Tests got extra spicy at the end. Thankfully it had been a long time since I've last played so it was good fun working them out all over again. This time I'll be dipping my toes into the community maps/campaigns, and the new "Portal Reloaded" which launched earlier this year if I recall correctly. In sum, a great continuation and cap off to the original. More of everything, including a credits song and strong music sprinkled throughout as well.

A masterclass in puzzle design, Portal 2 has stood the test of time very well! Graphically and performance-wise, this game still stands a notch above most other modern games, being handled very well by my modern system. The story-line and lore still hold up, and I still tear up when I think about the tragedy of Cave Johnson & Caroline. On replaying this game, I found that the puzzles were still very rewarding to try and solve logically, and though I was stumped on a few, I was eventually able to figure out the solution once I remembered to stop thinking so linearly: to beat Portal 2, you have to think with portals!

Overall, I give Portal 2 a solid 10/10, and I cannot wait to start on the Cooperative Testing Initiative!

I first played this game on the Xbox 360 when I was 9 years old, and replayed it more times than I can count over the years. As an owner of a miniature portal gun, plush companion cube, and several other pieces of Portal 2 merch, some of which obtained at Comic Con in 2017, I can safely say that this game's witty and dry humor - as well as the overall premise - still holds up after ten and a half years. And the community levels make sure that you still have hours of gameplay ahead of you even when you've memorized the solutions to all the tests. Then there's the cooperative mode, which adds even more opportunity for wacky and mind-bending puzzles to complete. Overall, a comfort game from my childhood brings as much comfort now as it did back then. 10/10 fully recommend to anyone that wants to burn through a couple of hours by thinking with portals.

I know I mentioned the fact that this game was a masterpiece in my Portal 1 review but I slightly take that back, even if this is really, really good. When looking at this compared to Portal 1 it really just feels better in practically every way, almost as if the first game was the proof of concept while the sequel was executing these ideas in a much more effective way. The game is longer while feeling nice and concise, the atmosphere is for the most part even better and more immersive, and the writing is somehow even closer to perfect. This sort of game is more or less the gold standard of effective sequels in the way it not only builds off the first game in natural and clever ways, but feeling like its own distinct entity.

The classic hallmarks of Portal puzzle solving make a return but are for the most part even more satisfying. While the portal gun itself remains largely unchanged beyond some more minor tweaks to make it feel less clunky, particularly when it comes to portal directions and momentum storage being streamlined a bit to make it just age and feel better. Where the game really shines in its improvements come from those secondary mechanics that complement the portalling around, most of them actually contributing to puzzle solving in a more engaging way when compared to something like the light orb from the first game. They also tend to have an even more distinctly sci fi, futuristic feel to them, which provides a bit of a more lively, colourful vibe to the cold, clinical test chambers the player will be spending a lot of their time in. The game also makes a point to constantly introduce new mechanics in even when it's approaching the end. This is a bit of a double edged sword however, as while it keeps things consistently varied and provides a wide range of challenges to overcome, it means that the difficulty curve ends up being pretty inconsistent as the game frequently needs to slow things down in order to teach the player new mechanics. With that said however, this grievance is alleviated by having even these more minor puzzles ties in with the story and make the player feel as if they are constantly progressing, which is great in keeping the pacing feeling right even if the difficulty is a bit all over the place at points.

The other issue with the puzzle solving rears its head in the middle portion of the game especially for me, this problem being the way certain "environmental puzzles" work. There are many points in the game in which rather than having to perform some kind of thought provoking action, the player will instead essentially be told to scour their surroundings to find a white wall to portal to instead. While this works occasionally as a way to fully establish the sheer scope of the setting, it's repeated so many times that it ends up becoming tedious and unsatisfying, there's such little difference between a lot of the scenarios as well, it's just, doing the same thing over again without much thought. It doesn't help that the telegraphing on where to go during these is fairly inconsistent, sometimes being intuitively designed to guide the player, while other times it feels as if part of the challenge is figuring out where the game wants you to go. The same can be said for a few stages, where so much of the difficulty comes from figuring out what the game even wants from you, rather than figuring out how to do it. I'd hesitate to call this actually difficult, and more just obtuse, it doesn't feel like the game's being clever in these moments, it just feels poorly designed. Fortunately, the game's usually so full of clever stuff that these weaker, more frustrating moments are easily overlooked.

The atmosphere is where I really feel this game shines, especially in the way it varies throughout. The opening scenes of seeing this long-ruined facility overgrown with foliage and broken equipment provides a more open, yet still desolate, isolated feel, but seeing it all slowly be repaired around you provides a completely different foreboding tone, representing the growing control the antagonist is gaining. Similarly, for my complaints about the middle section, I really love it in terms of how it looks and feels, being impossibly large in order to not only paint a picture on just how big Aperture Labs were, but also to give a true feeling of hopelessness when you realise you're at the lowest area of this absurdly large place. It also ties nicely into the background and environmental storytelling, as while the main plot is focused on escaping, a rich story about the rise and fall of this huge corporation along with the atrocities they caused and the failures associated with it is so compelling and makes for a fascinating experience.

As a final note, while the writing is a bit more on the nose and lacks some of the more nuanced elements of the first game it makes up for this by just being insanely funny and still having top tier writing. There's a certain earnestness in the dialogue and jokes that stops it from feeling overly smug or obnoxious no matter how frequently you're bashed over the head with it, which is further elevated by the way so much of the humour manages to tie in with another aspect of the experience as well. Having great comedy is one thing, but tying it in with the core experience in such an elegant and cohesive way is another altogether, and is really one of the defining aspects of this game working as well as it does. If you liked the first Portal, play this one for sure, if you didn't like the first Portal, probably play some of this one anyway. The game is concise, doesn't overstay its welcome, yet doesn't feel too short either, there's a satisfying arc here, and for those who are looking for a harder experience or something to play with a friend, the multiplayer in this is amazing as well, and really ups the difficulty in a fun way. Everyone's said their piece about this game because it's so damn iconic and a definitive classic, but hey, it's a classic for a reason.

So, it turns out I've been living under a rock the last decade and finally got myself bored to death at the later stages of the plague's forced confinement. During this period I decided to do a lot of stuff out of boredom like install Linux to a portable HD and use it on whatever PC I could put my hands on without messing with it's own OS.

Turns out Steam works great on Linux and both Portal and Portal 2 have native versions for Linux. Heck even games that don't have a native Linux version work on Steam through some wizardry I don't comprehend very much to the extent of a title like Max Payne working better on Linux than on Windows out of the box.

In this time of quarantined boredom, I played the whole story mode on Portal and now I'm on Portal 2. To whoever else who is still under a rock and didn't play this yet, please play Portal first. It helps with character development and how you care about the in-game characters.

Many of you will tell me I should have played other Half Life series before this, but if you are lazy af like me, do the following:

- Play Portal to the end
- Read a bit about the lore. There is a timeline somewhere that is great for understanding what's going on, but stop when events of Portal finish in the timeline. Just by playing the game you may come to an incorrect conclusion about what's going on.
- Play Portal 2

I started playing Portal 2 chiefly do the huge amount of requests I got from friends and viewers to check it out. And I'm glad I did. It's a great party game. It's a game where you get together with friends, and have a big WHODUNIT match, very much like an interactive board game, but better. It's a LOT of fun, when you have people to play with.

However, you have to understand that is simply that. A casual, party game meant to be played with friends. It's not a game that requires a great amount of skill, just the ability to be a detective,  it requires you to be an excellent liar. It's definitely a game worth playing, but it isn't a game that you should take and replace your life with.

The core gameplay loop does get boring relatively quickly, because there is nothing to work towards, nor does it have any real progression mechanics. It simply exists as a fun, round-by-round type game. Nothing more, and nothing less.

I hope you found this review helpful! Please leave me a rating, and give me your thoughts in the comments, as I would love to hear feedback, ideas, and what personal experiences you've had with this title.

Portal 2 is amazing. The End. Buy the game. That is all. An amazing sequel continuing a very entertaining and not too challenging puzzle game with more story elements, co-op campaign, level editor, community made maps, some fun secrets, and a great campaign with a great story and a few characters with funny dialogue. It's just a nice game to play if you’ve never played through before. 

+Puzzles aren’t that challenging although I would say this game was more challenging than the previous I didn’t have to look up the solutions to any of the test chambers
+Lots of different locations and types of rooms compared to the original
+A lot of interactive items: buttons, cubes, gravity beams, different gels that change your movement, lasers, etc.
+From what I’m sure this is less than $5 on sale
+Grade A dialogue
+More than just a puzzle game
+Lots of cool hidden secrets and easter eggs
+Cheats
+You can select individual test chambers/chapters to play from
+Challenge mode now applies to all test chambers instead of 6 and your score is put upon a leaderboard against your friends list
+Level editor for both solo and co-op levels
+Co-op campaign that you can play with a friend or can do online matchmaking [spoiler] good luck with that [/spoiler] The co-op campaign is super fun and there are a lot of chapters to play through. Additionally you can download custom co-op campaigns and keep playing even after finishing the main game!
+You can taunt and do different gestures in co-op
+Different hats, flags, and skins for co-op
+Community made maps that can easily be downloaded from the Steam Workshop 
+Split-screen
+Remote Play
+The overall level design and environments you go throughout this game is amazing. 
+Quick save during any part of the campaign/challenge maps and quick loading

-I still didn’t get any cake
-The different hats/skins in co-op are rather difficult to obtain. Majority are either no longer obtainable, costs real money and none can be obtained from just playing the game, or you will have to trade with someone else in order to obtain them. Basically you cannot get any of the skins in the game without paying in some sort of way.

Most games released today can't even come close to Portal 2, and I think this will stay true for a long long time.

Portal and Portal 2 are the most innovative puzzle games of their time. Portal 2 is an extension of the brilliant design and potential that the original offered, with new mechanics, graphical improvements, and a new, very charming singleplayer story, with very charming characters.

Portal's gameplay revolves around the properties of two "portals" which players can shoot onto specific types of walls. Players can enter through one portal and seamlessly emerge through the other in addition to being able to see directly through them to the other side. Momentum is preserved when traversing through portals, which allows players to gain thrilling levels of velocity while basically playing with space.

Though the player controller's normal walking speed is painfully slow, players can take advantage of various movement techniques to speed themselves up during gameplay. Once you learn how to air-strafe and bunnyhop, the rest becomes increasingly easier to master. Movement techniques enhance the experience.

The game offers a fantastic singleplayer experience with lovable characters and hilariously witty dialogue. Its replay value is immense for someone like me who enjoys experiencing the game world. There's also a two-player cooperative course, full of chambers to complete. On top of all that exists the Perpetual Testing Initiative, or Community Test Chambers. Community members can create and publish their own test chambers for others to enjoy, and there are a lot of geniuses who play this game. You'll virtually never run out of content.

All in all, this is one of my favorite video games of all time. It's incredibly clever in concept and in execution. Though I will close Portal 2 for the last time someday, that day will be very near to the day I die.

This game was released in 2011, and still looks STUNNING for its age, I remember I was shocked in the first scene with Chell's room crumbling as Wheatly (quite poorly) manoeuvred it that the Source engine could do something like that! Being a Source game, not only does it look amazing, but can run on pretty much anything - there isn't a reason to not play it!

I would recommend playing the first game first however, while the story isn't [i] as [/i] central and it doesn't look [i] as [/i] good as Portal 2 (not that it looks bad), it is a great intro to the mechanics, gives quite a bit of back story to the game and it still has GLaDOS's amazing humor!

Overall, this game is timeless and I can recommend it to absolutely anyone. Especially for those who want a good puzzle or are used to shooters but want something a bit different (the portal gun is the perfect device for that).

Portal 2 is the best puzzle game I have played. The portal gun is incredibly fun to use and has enough of a skill ceiling that you could play through the game several times while learning new things you can do with portals each time. The puzzles were always engaging and offer a decent amount of challenge on your first play through and on additional plays you can attempt usually difficult portal placements or sequences to bypass some of the puzzles. I have played the co-op campaign with three different people and enjoyed it each time, if the game was made by a different developer anytime in the last 6-8 years the co-op would have likely been a dlc but it is just part of the game, for 10 dollars and frequent 75% off sales it is one of the best purchases you can make on Steam.

Even after all these years, knowing the solution to all the puzzles, and hearing the same story and jokes again and again. Portal 2 is not really a game to me anymore, but like a trip down memory lane. A walking trail I can describe every step of but I still walk down for nothing more than the experience.

In my opinion, Portal 2 falls short of the first Portal by a combination of the following factors:
[list]
[*] Lots more game mechanics to wrangle
[*] Long periods of walking
[*] Very visually dark, with no option to adjust brightness
[*] The environments are generally a lot more visually cluttered, making for better graphics, but also making it harder to engage with the puzzles
[*] Many puzzles that make you answer "what am I supposed to do", instead of "how am I supposed to do it"
[/list]

I can understand how this game would appeal to people more than the first, but for me personally, I prefer the cleaner, brighter aesthetic of Portal. I also prefer the puzzles in the first Portal, which rely more on portals and less on the other varied mechanics introduced in Portal 2.

A classic first-person puzzle game, that is enjoyable for anyone, yet challenging enough for even the most hardcore gamer. The effects introduced this time around have added another level of complexity to the test chambers, making them even more difficult. However, the mechanics of light surfaces, excursion funnels, and the mobility gels also provides players with options for exploring even the hardest testing chambers. The cooperative game is one of the best I've played, requiring team building and strategic problem solving, as well as absolute trust in your teammate. These cooperative challenges can be difficult for even the best of teams, but they are also a lot of fun. Overall, if you have not tried this awesome game or its predecessor, you are simply missing out.

[h1] I like Steam more than Valve, but this is the best Valve game without a doubt. [/h1]

It had always been in the 'Play Next' tab of my Steam Library ever since I played Portal 1 in 2019, but I'd always ignored it cause I didn't really feel like committing to a long puzzle game.

I have to keep telling myself that this is a [u]linear game[/u] because I've always been made disappointed when I try to explore or try something else even a bit. Every level in Portal 2 is a confined space with one task to achieve. 'Secret Areas' aren't really secret areas cause it's probably important to solving the puzzle. But the main thing is that if there's a straight path ahead, then that meant's you're not gonna achieve much by going to the left or right, which may irritate some people who are used to games with side objectives crammed in every nook and corner. But to be fair, Portal 1's radios were too excessive, and a linear design was probably the best way to go about in a 3-dimensional puzzle game such as this.

GLaDOS was the best character Valve had made during its prime. No one from Half-Life or their multiplayer games comes close to how amazing it felt when the autotuned robotic voice talked to me. Just like Gordon Freeman, Chell is also a silent protagonist, but she doesn't look like Heisenberg from Breaking Bad, so only her Orange jumpsuit can save her from losing to the free man himself.

[spoiler] There was some questionable level design at the end of chapter 4 where you're stuck in a room with 3 turrets and you had to find a small gap in the wall to shoot a portal to a wall far away, but aside from that, the level designs for the [i]'Modern Aperture'[/i] stages were great.[/spoiler]

As for the older [i]'Aperture Innovators'[/i] maps, I didn't like them as much. The modern labs were just like Portal 1 but detailed with decay, ruin, and organic growth due to being kept unmaintained for several years, which looked really atmospheric. Whereas the underground labs remind me of the plastic-feeling Source games of time's past. Other than the visuals, I was also not too happy with the new elements added for gameplay: The [b]bouncy[/b] and [i]speedy[/i] gels made me slightly motion-sick whenever I interacted with them (a very common quirk with Source™ games), and when the cube is lathered with the gel, it got really hard to track them with my eyes whooshing around the entire room cause it kept bouncing off of the walls onto another. But the most pointless gameplay element of them all were the White and Clear gels (water I suppose). They could've just stopped with the Blue and Orange gels cause most of the time I just spammed the White gel on every surface I could find and then solve the puzzle with my brain afterward. Solving a puzzle with pre-determined portal-spaces was more fun than trial-and-error spilling the white gel everywhere. At least the Clear gel let me stop the bouncy cube from bouncing all over the place, so here's my final gel ranking: [b]Orange > Blue > Clear > White[/b]

After I finished the campaign, I was blown away cause I didn't have any other major hiccups during the game that warranted using a guide. The very next day, I tried the co-op with an online friend, did a couple of levels, and then didn't touch the game for another 3 months. I couldn't find anyone convenient to play with, so I played a few levels here and there until I got my old friend back, where we together tried to 100% all the co-op achievements. One [b]major[/b] issue in co-op was that you can't disable the in-game mic... This game gets random bug fix updates even in 2021, but they still couldn't fix an oversight that allowed you to use Discord or Steam VC without the audio echoing every time.

At least there weren't any game-long 'Collectibles' achievements like in other valve games. Most of them were restricted to a chapter at most.

[u]Final verdict:[/u] This was the best game created by Valve by a longshot. wouldn't play again though.

Earlier in the year I put together my first gaming rig, after a lifetime of console gaming. Went ALL OUT on the components, and after trying out the latest and greatest, i randomly decided to give 360/PS3 era games a run. An unexpected gaming detour but one that I am absolutely loving. Playing these classics at the level they were originally designed for has been like playing them afresh. I shudder at the thought of those old machines struggling to hit 25 FPS. 

It's been 10 years since i've played Portal 2, and - other than the loading screens after ever test chamber - it hasn't aged a day. Nostalgia works in funny ways, and playing it at 4K, 120 FPS feels like how i remember it from back in 2011 on my 360. 

Peerless writing, outstanding puzzles, and a vibe so fresh it's bordering on timeless. 

If you've not played it after all this time, get it done. Pennies for one of the most original and enjoyable games ever made.

Next up, Bioshock Infinite.

The Portal franchise started when Valve picked up a student game design team's final project and made it into a bonus feature of sorts for the orange box. Portal 1 eventually became one of the most beloved games of all time, and for it's sequel, that team was given a way higher budget and [b]BOY CAN YOU TELL.[/b] Portal 2  is truly, unironically the only game I can call perfect. I have played through it's campaign more times than I can count, and thoroughly enjoying the experience each individual time. The co-op mode is also incredibly fun (if not a bit of a friendship destroyer lol), the community made test chambers bring thousands of hours worth of new content to it, and [b] that [i]SOUNDTRACK[/i][/b]. Truly a must-play. If someone made me validate videogames as an art form, I'd just show them this absolute masterpiece.

[i]Portal 2[/i] is the same as [i]Portal[/i], but worse.
The gameplay is the exact same, with a few new gimmicks. This is fine, as the first game was perfectly acceptable.

At least one of the puzzles has a softlock, forcing you to reload. It's not hard to do, either. 
Additionally quite a few of the puzzles are obtuse, with solutions so ridiculous it's surprising anyone could beat them without a guide.

The ending is amazing however, unlike the first game.

Single Player mode has an interesting story, starting at the decayed Aperture Science enrichment center, from which you're trying to escape.

OS Support:
Linux - Fully supported, well-made port. Beware that the port doesn't have all of the spoken languages from the windows version.

[h1]Do i Need to tell you buying it ?[/h1]

This... is a masterpiece. A significant improvement over Portal in both the storytelling and gameplay department. The puzzles were all fun and challenging- never did they require RNG or impossible-to-notice elements in order to solve puzzles unlike most other games nowadays. Puzzles had a clear, logical mindset that only required you to connect the dots in the right way at the right time.

There was no compromise in the storytelling department. It had an excellent story to share and it continued perfectly from Portal 1. I listened to the developer commentary and I appreciated all the little details the writers put into the story to make the gameplay and the story work seamlessly together. The character development and, spoiler, plot twist, was neat. Portal 2 is a prime example of how you create a world that blends both gameplay and storytelling together in a way that appeals to both types of people who play for either the story or the puzzles.

Until I get a VR headset and try out Half-Life Alyx, I am content with calling Portal 2 Valve's Magnum Opus.

In my opinion a game that you must have played.
Even years after the release still worthy to play if you haven't already. An excellent puzzling game, where you have to solve chambers by teleporting yourself or other objects with the help of two portals, which you can place onto walls. Not too easy, but also not too difficult, although it can be challenging sometimes, but still fun.
Really good and exciting story, which is also interesting and sometimes quite funny. Contains much background information.
Even for 2021 I still wouldn't describe the graphics as outdated, because it still looks beautiful, while being easy to run on low-end hardware.
I can also recommend the multiplayer mode, where you can play together with one of your friends, with more challenging chambers to solve.

I would recommend also playing Portal 1 before playing Portal 2, but you don't really need to. You can also get the game much cheaper during a steam-sale together with Portal 1.

9.5 / 10

[b]Preformance:[/b]
You don't need a powerful gaming rig to play at reasonable framerate but it is recommended.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
The singleplayer gameplay is fairly short but still enjoyable.

[b]Addictiveness [I know it's not an actual word, shut up]: [/b]
You could spend hours designing community test chambers.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
Still decent since 2011.

[b]Story: [/b]
a well constructed plot which takes place after [spoiler]Chell gets put into hibernation for YES months by Ratman after Chell was recovered from the portal explosion which killed GlaDOS in Portal 1.[/spoiler] Overall, great story and lore.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
You will need a brain to be able to solve the puzzles.

[b]Is it worth the price?[/b]
Yes; no need to wait for  a sale.

[b]Conclusion: [/b]
Would highly recommend this game if you're into the Portal or Half Life series. Still just as fun as it was 10 years ago, but don't take my word for it, try it out for yourself if this review made you interested.
