Don’t kill me for offering a contrarian opinion here, but I think both Portal games are a victim of being overrated. I thoroughly enjoyed the first game, but not to the extent of the full whack of 10/10’s and ‘best game ever’ accolades that fans throw at it – it did, however, have an awesome villain and a fantastic ending song.

Portal 2 is a game of two halves. Initially, it kicks off by following on from the ending of Portal 1, and introduces the hilarious, Wheatley AI, a goofball in every sense of the word, rapid-fire, nonsensical ramblings that add a touch of comedy throughout.

He’s here to help you get out of the joint, and he’s awful at it. And of course, his incompetence leads to a certain villain showing up, and the two mesh well.

At this point, I was totally convinced the game was 9/10 awesomeness, both Wheatley and our villain were brilliant, superbly written and fun to interact with as we go through the typical Portal puzzles, using portals to navigate test chambers.

Where the game fell away for me was in Part 2. See, at the halfway point you get thrown out of the test chambers, I won’t elaborate on why, but suffice to say you get to use your portal gun in more open environments. You also get to incorporate ‘gels’ into your puzzle solving, so blue allows you to bounce higher, orange lets you run fast and white lets you create portals on any surface it comes in contact with.

It’s all neat, but the expanded world doesn’t really change up the puzzles (for me), it just makes them more tedious as I now have to scour the environment for the one flipping piece I can throw a portal on, figure out the mechanics and move on. And this breaks the pacing to such an extent that I just felt it became an entire slog.

The story also, doesn’t really pick up here, because we’re treated to a history lesson – which is nice, but in combination with the pace-breaking, it just doesn’t really entice me so much as it probably should.

This portion of the game was such a slog that it really killed the momentum of the first half, and it doesn’t help that it is more or less devoid of character interaction outside the historical blurbs. That’s what knocks the score down for me. Still, it’s a decent game, worth playing and it has an absolute army of fans that love it, so just treat my view as an anomaly in the pool, that’s science as our friendly villain would say.

I miss the tight pacing and atmosphere of Portal, but Portal 2 improves on its predecessor in nearly every other way. Test chambers are made more complex thanks to the inclusion of the new gel mechanic, the difficulty curve is properly balanced, the campaign and its story is fleshed out this time around, a CO-OP campaign is present, and P2 has a great sense of humor. Portal 2 is easily the most unique gaming experience I've ever had. It's a nice break from the droves of shooters out on the market.

It's a great classic based around platforming, logical thinking, illogical physics, and witty writing. The main story isn't terribly long, and there's an alternate story line in the two-player cooperative mode. Add on countless community created testing chambers and a workshop to create your own, its playable from ten to hundreds of hours of solid gameplay.

What can I say about Portal 2? It's an absolute masterpiece of a game! I remember I immediately got it for the Xbox 360 the day it came out in 2011, and I binge-played the hell out of it!

My only complaint is that Portal 2 felt like it was more focused on the story than puzzle solving to me. Then again as I think about it, there's a lot more chambers that get increasingly complex as you progress when compared to Portal 1/Still Alive. I'm not denying that the story is amazing, but you know what I mean right? Sometimes I admit that the community made test chambers are even harder than the built in test chambers.

Speaking of, Valve really took it a step forward when they added the community test chambers! The ability to create your own test chambers was just the cherry on top! I wish there was more added to the test chamber editor, like custom textures, custom environments, etc. I know the Authoring tools and hammer editor exists for that, but you know, they both can be hard to use if you don't know what to do.

So all in all, Portal 2 gets a 9.5/10 from me! It has an excellent story and great gameplay!

The object of the game is to escape the Aperture Science testing facility, being run by the evil AI Glados, who wants nothing more than to force the player to complete various tests until the player is killed. I previously reviewed Portal, and in that review, I claimed that the only puzzle game better than Portal is Portal 2.

I'm not exaggerating when I say that the sequel blows what's already a stellar game out of the water. I'm going to need several paragraphs to accurately describe just how good of a puzzle game, nay, how good of a game, Portal 2 is.

A game is not a game without gameplay, and all other aspects, including graphics, story, characters, and setting are all meaningless if the gameplay isn't good. Fortunately for Valve, Portal 2 delivers exceptional gameplay, with the Portal Gun shining once again in a series of levels that are a well-balanced mix of actual test chambers and dilapidated pathways between them. The puzzles make you think, but not enough to make you quit the game. It's also incredibly fun to be launched out of a portal at high velocity, something you get to do a lot more of in this game than its predecessor. Combine that with the various new tools you have to work with to get by as the game goes on, as well as impressive level design and rich setting, and you have a wonderful single-player experience. The developers really outdid themselves on this one.

While the puzzles alone make this as good as the first Portal, it's the characters that make this game even better than the first. GladOS is back and more spiteful than ever, with dialogue that made me laugh the whole game. On merit of GladOS alone, the writers deserve to get big heads. To top it off, Ellen McLain is better than ever, not only making GladOS more alive than ever, but really selling everything about her character. It isn't just GladOS that makes this game phenomenal though. Wheatley, a new addition to the robotic crew of Aperture Science, is just as endearing as GladOS, while remaining entirely different and amazing in his own right. Despite shifts in his interactions with the player, you never feel like it isn't Wheatley, and honestly, I relate to his cluelessness on a personal level. Stephen Merchant nails the role, delivering a performance that I still can't get out of my head. And I can't talk about incredible characters without referencing the recorded messages of Cave Johnson, voiced by the legendary J. K. Simmons. Man, though he never interacts with the main character, Cave Johnson remains a fan favorite due to his "everything is possible" personality mixed with his complete disregard for safety. Sure, it didn't affect his employees well, but when it boils down to it, not even he was exempt from his attitude about his passions, and ultimately, that makes him a character that we find ourselves respecting, even if we would never look up to him. And J. K. Simmons was possibly the only man who could make me like a flippant CEO. He knew the role, and performed the heck out of it. Combine that with superb voice acting from the announcer before GladOS returns, both the good and the broken turrets, and the brief Caroline cameos, not to mention the noises Dee Bradley Baker makes for Atlas and Peabody, the characters and their stellar characterization make this game a masterpiece.

Portal 2 improves on the original in quite a lot of ways, and story is one of them. Almost non-existent in Portal, Portal 2 gives the player purpose in their puzzle-solving adventure. While not terribly complex, it serves as more than enough to get the player personally invested in the outcome. Full of tense moments, riddled with witty remarks, laden with subtle foreshadowing, and driven by a quest that taps into the human desire for freedom, you'll be sucked into the story. To top it off, the game's finale is quite possibly one of the most memorable in all of gaming, which just wouldn't have been possible without the efforts the story team went through to make something magnificent.

All this alone would make Portal 2 one of the best games of all time. But Valve even added a co-op testing course that takes place immediately after the events of the main game. The levels are substantial, and the humor continues to be top-notch. There's even a small storyline, though while it's a little more substantial then that of Portal, it's mostly for flavor. Which isn't to day it's bad, in fact, I quite enjoyed it. The meat of the experience, the complex levels that require two players to beat them, are delightfully difficult, and extremely satisfying to complete, so long as your partner is someone you have fun playing with. I imagine playing with a random player has the potential to turn sour, but that's through no fault of the game itself. Overall, the multiplayer experience was well worth the addition, and it serves as a sparkling gemstone in what is already the crowning achievement of Valve.

If that's not enough, the game has immense replay value. There's enough content to forget how the puzzles play out after a while, and even if you do remember it, the story is still a blast to experience, thanks to the characters Valve created. The co-op mode provides even more replay value, especially if you haven't played the levels with a specific person before. And if that's not enough for you, the community chambers available are extensive, available in both single and multiplayer, and ranging in difficulty from cakewalk to M. C. Escher designing Ocarina of Time's Water Temple.

To top it off, it has a soundtrack that perfectly encapsulates the vibe of the long-abandoned Aperture Science. It's mostly atmospheric, but it makes the whole game feel alive. The game even has not one, but two songs performed by Ellen McLain right at the end to send you off, including another excellent composition by Jonathan Coulton, "Want You Gone." The song isn't quite as popular as "Still Alive," but it's a good tune nonetheless.

Seriously, the game is that good. With excellent gameplay, amazing sets, levels that work the brain, a killer cast, engaging gameplay, a co-op mode that's its own beast of content, a fantastic soundtrack, and a ridiculously high level of community content, Portal 2 deserves to be remembered as one of the best games ever created. For the best possible experience, I do recommend playing Portal first, which is a great game in its own right, but I'm not joking when I say that its sequel is bound to make the history books.

[b]"Portal 2" continues on the path of the original "Portal" but this time Valve gave us a more complete, longer and even better technically game. The concept is extraordinary, the puzzles' logic is unique, the characters are adorable and the sense of humor is just awesome. The cinematic approach and the clever plot will make your journey through the ruins of Aperture's facilities a magical, surreal experience. The community support of extra levels and the co-op mode give it a lot more extra play hours. Masterpiece.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
- The main concept is fantastic and the unique gameplay is now even more enriched with various new elements. Control mechanics are accurate and responsive. You can' t stop creating portals here and there to see what happens.
- The puzzles are intelligent with their own unique logic. You have to redefine the way your mind works. They are not too hard, but challenging enough to entertain you for several hours. Some of them are easily placed among the best puzzles ever.
- Amazing, surreal humor. Well written and clever dialogues full of irony. Like the original "Portal" it is one of the most hilarious games out there.
- Really good and atmospheric visuals even for today standards. It does not feel old.
- Fantastic sound design with a big variety of sound effects. The main characters' voices are as enjoyable as it gets.
- Great directory and cinematography. The whole journey through the ruins of Aperture's facilities is a seamless continuous cinematic experience.
- Most NPCs are unique. They are absolutely adorable, although they are considered to be villains.
- Awesome, unforgettable music. The credit's song is iconic.
- Animations are so smooth. The building feels alive.
- The story is basic but it is enough to support a puzzle game and enhance the atmosphere.
- One of the best co-op modes out there as it requires good collaboration and synchronization by both players. It is not just a supplement to the single player mode but drives the game to a whole new dimension. Co-op mode robots are so funny too.
- There are dozens of test champers created by the community that can extend the playtime for several extra hours.
- Many levels have more than one solution. Steam achievements also push you to complete some interesting small challenges.
- Some view angles that are created among portals are so surreal. The trip among vertical to horizontal portals (and vice versa) is pure magic.

The bad
- Too many loading screens. They are quick but there is literally one of them every five minutes.
- During the single player mode there are one or two less interesting parts, where nothing really happens. You walk in a straight line without solving a puzzle or learning something new about the story. They are not long, but I felt that they ruined that game's pace for a while.
- Boring design of your character (Chell), although you can see her only via some portals. Everything else in the game is so uniquely designed.

Portal 2, whilst a great game of it's own merit, is lesser than it's predecessor. Yes, the physics are impressive, the graphics are lovely even to this day, and Stephen Merchant as Wheatley is everything I could have ever desired in this lifetime, but the main issue I hold is, oddly enough, the gameplay. As opposed to the original's tightly designed test chambers and sole puzzle focus with comedy thrown in as a bonus, the sequel feels more so like Valve wanted to do more with the story, much to the game's detriment, I find. The strength of the original was that tight pacing - it had puzzles galore, not too hard but not too easy, some nice dark humour, and was of a perfect length. Conversely, Portal 2's campaign feels like it drags on somewhat, especially with the deficiency of actual puzzles in this puzzle game. Most of the game boils down to a sight-seeing tour that just so happens to be infrequently broken up by begrudgingly implemented puzzles. Yet, despite the lack of puzzles, as previously mentioned, the game does feel overly long and bloated. 

However, if you wish for a more concise, puzzle-focused experience, you may find what you seek in the Co-Op. The addition of another dolt and another two portals gives the puzzles that extra layer of depth, making them meatier and more head-scratching, and most crucially, extremely satisfying when you work them out. Despite this, it also lacks replayability - if you know the solutions but your partner doesn't, you'll just end up resenting each other, and if you both know the solutions, you'll get through much too quickly and easily. There is more life breathed into this part of the game via Workshop support. The most baffling addition to this mode, however, are the Team Fortress 2 styled cosmetics that Valve must have also realised were a terribly silly concept and never added any more of. Truly strange.

Overall, as a standalone product on it's own merits, Portal 2 is a great game that deserves and would typically be receiving my utmost praise, but it finds itself as a sequel to Portal; one of the best, tightest designed games to grace this mortal plane of existence. That is a tough act to follow - a nigh-impossible one. Portal 2 takes a good crack at it, but falls just a bit short to the point where I would prefer to replay Portal 1. That being said, if you haven't already, and you enjoyed Portal 1, do yourself a favour and play through Portal 2. Despite all of it's shortcomings over it's predecessor, it is still a phenomenal game, and one that simply must be played, if only to christen your Steam account.

If you somehow haven't already played this game, then just play it. This game on its own is captivating enough, a small but intricate and sweet story, combined with great and challenging puzzles. The single player of this game is a surreal experience, everything sweeps you off your feet in the end and I promise you will really feel immersed in its world. Now, with co-op, you are playing an entirely different game. Here you really get to build and elaborate on bonds you have with friends in such an interactive way, one moment you can be in tears of laughter from ruining each others plans and causing deaths to your partner, to complete silence as both your brains steam while you try and figure out what is supposed to come next. The co-op gets you stimulated mentally in every way possible, communication, understanding, and so much more. The workshop is a great PC addition because you can get lost in a mixture of amazing and horrible solo or co-op levels, and that is a game in and of itself. This is one of the only games I have ever played more than once, and on top of that I have played it on more than one platform. Playing this with people who haven't played before over and over and feeling like I'm experiencing something for the first time again. This is one of the only games I can call more than a game, it is an experience, and a memory. Play this if somehow you haven't already.

At the time of writing, I have played through Portal 2's single player story mode every day for the past 8 days. I did not do this to increase my hours on the game. I did not do this because i wanted a better understanding of the games inner workings or mechanics. I did this for one simple reason. This game is the most fun gaming experience i may have ever had. I previously played this game on XBOX 360 a year or so after release. I hadn't even turned 10 years old at the time so i couldn't appreciate just how solid this game truly is. I bought this game while it was on sale about a month ago as i am slowly chipping away at purchasing all Valve and Id Software games. In the month since i have dedicated over 50 hours of my time to the game, 85% of that time dedicated the incredibly well written and solidly designed story mode. The game also offers the much praised co-op mode (which admittedly i have not completed. My brother is usually busy doing other things and many of my other friends don't even have the game) and community made test chambers which i have also sunk some time into, alongside a simple and intuitive chamber builder. Overall, this game is one of, if not THE best game of the 2010's and i highly recommend it to gamers of any skill level.

Portal 2 expands on the characters and world of Portal, with an almost staggering amount more cinematic flare than the original. Though in doing so, it sacrifices the elegant simplicity of the original. If you can accept that Portal 2 isn’t ‘trying’ to accomplish the same thing as Portal 1 and accept it for its narrative strengths, then you’ll have just as much fun as the original. In addition to the single player campaign, Portal 2 also possesses a co-op campaign that’s definitely worth playing if you can find someone willing. All that praise being said, I don’t feel as though Portal 2 is as much of a ‘must-play’ as Portal 1. If Portal 1 left you wanting more Portal-Puzzles, then it’ll deliver, but if you felt the ending of Portal 1 left you satisfied, then I don’t feel like anyone should force themselves through Portal 2 just for the sake of it.

This game is simply fantastic - it's the first valve game I have played and it was brilliant, when i bought the game i had little knowledge of why it was so critically loved, I thought likely it is for the puzzles - which do a great job balancing difficulty and satisfaction, especially later on into the story, but unexpectedly what had me loving this game so much was it's unique characters, interesting story and even the intriguing larger sci-fi universe only explained through pictures and voice messages. 

So much about this game was fantastic but the stand out part of that for me was the humour - I'm very rarely laughing at video game dialogue and until this game I had seen very few previous attempts at humour in the medium. But this game truly nailed it - from the overhead announcers brilliant lines to the sarcastic comments from Glados, or the somewhat slapstick humour from Wheatly - just truly a joy to have unfold in-front of me, and I enjoyed every line.

The length of the game could be criticised by some but for me it was a refreshing change of pace from a traditional 20 hour campaign, in-fact in odd ways it reminds me of Titanfall 2's campaign both excellent stories that tell so much in a 7-10 hour experience and leaving you wanting more information on what would happen next, but still fulfilling enough so that they don't rely on an unlikely sequel to satisfy the story.

Now is where it is important to mention the downsides of the game but to be frank, I found almost none significant enough to harm the experience, some issues for others may have been more significant but personally, I found the game to still look relatively good, it's physics engine and puzzles still feel intuitive and the controls are logical and easy to understand.

Overall, the game is a wonderful experience and I implore anyone else to purchase this game, if your reading reviews trying to decide - just buy it - it is simply fantastic, and deserving of its title as a classic.

Since I first played the Portal 2 singleplayer campaign about a month ago, I've been obsessed with this game and everything about it to the point where I've played it thrice: once to enjoy, once for the developer commentary, and once for achievements. The puzzles are incredibly well balanced and well paced (especially after playing Portal a few days prior)--I only truly felt stuck on the second Chamber 16 (which I later discovered had a commentary node explaining how the level was redesigned slightly because playtesters were more lost than I was on it). The story's writing is immaculate, featuring an incredible sense of humor and a very fun-to-follow plotline. The soundtrack is incredible, and I love the unique style each piece has. And this is all before mentioning the co-op campaign, which I'm certainly looking forward to finish with one of my friends.

I just love it. Portal 2 has quickly become one of my favorite games of all time, and it's let me craving more. More explanations for why Aperture Science followed the path it did (e.g. why the mainframe causes the central core to become a murderous megalomaniac). More puzzles with such finely tuned balance (tried the Portal: Reloaded mod and it is pure suffering in comparison to the learning curve in Portal 2). Just... more stuff to the point that I can't describe it. I haven't been able to find any other game that provides the unique puzzle solving, pacing, story, and overall experience Portal 2 provides, and I'm starving for more.

In short, (in my opinion) Portal 2 is one of the greatest games of all time--if not, THE greatest--and it's a title I'm proud to say it overwhelmingly deserves.

Then once you memorize all of the co-op puzzles you can show new players the ropes to becoming good at the game. After this most people quit because they get bored and have nothing else to do, however a small amount of players will attempt to learn how to speedrun which opens up a ton of new ways to play in both singleplayer and co-op. Part of the reason why I love this game so much is the fact that it being 10 years old opens up a ton of new things to do in the game such as learning new glitches and tricks or getting a faster time or even just finding other people who enjoy the speedrunning aswell and becoming friends. All of these things to do in such an old source game is why this game is in my top 5 games of all time list. I know this review is kind of late for this game but if you are just seeing this I hope this convinces you to buy the game or if you already have it, to try speedrunning and glitch hunting as that is an entire nother world of fun to be had in a game that most people are bored of by now.

Using a portal gun that shoots two portals that connect to each other, Portal 2 sees you completing a series of test chambers using your intelligence and critical thinking to solve puzzles. Portal 2 is one of the great classics of gaming, especially in the realm of puzzle games. Valve was able to create and expand on such a unique concept in this installment. The puzzles have been vastly improved from last game. The challenge ranges from easy stuff to mind-bending solutions that will sometimes leave you needing a walkthrough guide open to pass. From this, Valve has surely passed over the bar for satisfying, yet challenging puzzles. 

With its simple story, Portal 2 also hosts a few but memorable characters that basically define the Portal franchise. Its characters are able to drive the plot forward in a way that makes the plot deeper than you might think. Thus, the developers have created a story that is on par with their other story-based games and secured a place in gaming Hall of Fame. 

If you still itch for more Portal after the ending, there is also a co-op story mode to play with your friends. In addition, the Steam Workshop advertises many puzzles that players can try out for themselves. Some of these puzzles are leagues and leagues more difficult than the puzzles in the vanilla game, so good luck.

A ten year old game perhaps but this is an amazing platform/puzzle game. Stephen Merchant brings a lot of humour to proceedings and there's a lot of story going on throughout. As with Half Life, you think you're nearing the end of the game and then you find there's still loads of content remaining. J K Simmons has some great dialogue in the latter part of the game too.
On top of the excellent single player game there's also an innovative co-operative game to play too (actual co-op requiring genuine teamwork, not just two people playing through the game at the same time).
Some of the puzzles are quite tricky to figure out but there's a good sense of achievement when you finally work out the solutions, and as I managed to complete the co-op game with my 4 year old the challenges are obviously not entirely impossible.
The only negative I found was that you really need to know what you're doing with regards to setting up your controllers in the Steam settings (especially if, like me, you're using one PS4 controller and one Xbox One controller) but that's not really an issue with the game itself as it works perfectly once you've sorted that out.

Portal 2...

Where do I even begin with this one...

For starters, the 3D animation of portal is wonderful, sometimes in games 3D animation can be real hit or miss but in this case I say it was a constant hit! The game assets all look wonderful. The soundtrack is... alright... I mean it works perfectly for the game and really gives of the right vibes, but just in general it's not a OST I would go back and listen to often if at all.

Story gets its own section oh boy. The story was phenomenal! Having the Wheatley bait and switch at the start wasn't something I was expecting but I was pleasantly surprised with him. Taking over Aperture and trying to kill me while I run around with G.L.A.D.O.S in a potato solving puzzles was a'lot more fun than I was expecting.

The Co-op...
Now, this is where the game got good... I'll quickly talk about the story... It was alright I guess. I mean, It's co-op story so I wasn't really expecting much, it was fun to see G.L.A.D.O.S get scared of a bird tho... ANYWAY. I have played through the Co-op 3 times with different people and every time it was enjoyable, so many laughs and good memories thanks to this game so for that I will forever be thankful. Maybe this sais more about my friends than it does the game, but solving puzzles with them was so much fucking fun.

Overall a great game that I would definitely recommend!

Portal 2 brings the player (and Chell) back to Aperture Laboratories, and it’s one of the most enjoyable first-person puzzle adventures yet. The gameplay mechanics start from where they left off in the first Portal, but keep adding new elements and improving it gradually, Test Chamber after Test Chamber. Eventually, Chell has an arsenal of tricks worthy of the best heroes, and her journey is one that the player will want to continue playing until the end. The story behind the game is amazing and explains not only the past of Aperture Science, but also the relationship between its creator, Cave Johnson, and Half-Life’s Black Mesa. Exploring the Depths of Aperture is one of the most incredible experiences in videogaming as a whole, both narration-wise as gameplay-wise. Add to that the incredible voice talents, the always sharp background music and a flawless technical compartment, and you got a jaw-dropping game. What tops all of this, is the personality of Wheatley, GLaDOS and Cave Johnson… Portal 2 is a masterpiece. No further words needed.

Life was meaningless.

I had no purpose other than to continue my work, the only thing I had ever known. Work had been fun at first, and my boss had seemed nice and rather witty. However after some time, my boss began acting strange. It started with the lying. Then, my boss began to intentionally make my work dangerous. I survived, but only through quick thinking and a bit of luck.

Eventually the everyday grind of navigating my way through a neverending maze lost any appeal. My boss promised me cake when the job was completely done, but it wasn't worth it. I wished for something, anything, even death, that would rid me from this meaningless existence. I was tempted several times to walk infront of a turret or fall into the radioactive slime, but the pain these methods would bring seemed greater than the pain of a meaningless life, so I carried on.

Then one day, my boss had a surprise for me. He had brought me a Companion to assist me in my work. Or more specifically, an Aperature Science Weighted Companion Cube. At first, the Companion Cube assisted me with basic tasks which I nonetheless couldn't have done without it. We rounded a corner and came face to face with a ball of radioactive energy coming straight towards us.

I thought we were doomed, but then the Companion Cube jumped in front of me of its own accord and shielded me from certain death. My mouth dropped, as I imagined the pain the Cube must have been experiencing. My boss said something about "symptoms of enrichment center testing" and "perceiving inanimate objects as alive" but I paid no attention. I knew this was love. I knew this was real.

We continued on together for a while. The Cube was essential in completeing the task my boss had set for me. I tried talking to it, but I received no response. My boss then oddly informed me that the Companion Cube would never threaten to stab me (as if it would ever)...but more importantly he informed me that my Cube was mute. I felt a pang of sadness - not the selfish sadness one feels when they lose something, but the true sadness that is felt when empathizing with another being.

This revelation did not hamper my love for my Cube, my Companion, who had brought happiness and joy into my life, and who had selflessly endured pain to save me from death. After opening the final door which would lead to the elevator I had grown quite familiar with, our boss seemed to congratulate us on our new found compaionship. But then the bos said something which would change my life forever.

"However, [the Companion Cube] cannot accompany you for the rest of the test and, unfortunately, must be euthanized. Please escort your Companion Cube to the Aperture Science Emergency Intelligence Incinerator."

I gasped in horror, looking across the room and seeing what I now realized must be the Incinerator. I fell to my knees, tears already streaming down my cheeks. I looked at my faithful Companion and proceeded to envelop it in my arms, determined to never let it go.

My boss continued on as if nothing was wrong. "While it has been a faithful companion, your Companion Cube cannot accompany you through the rest of the test. If it could talk - and the Enrichment Center takes this opportunity to remind you that it cannot - it would tell you to go on without it because it would rather die in a fire than become a burden to you."

"You could never be a burden to me!" I cried, and hugged my Companion Cube to my chest. But then I remembered. Although my boss had lied to be at one time, boss had since promised that he could no longer lie to me. I had to finish the testing, or else I would never get the Cake. And if the Cube couldn't come with me...didn't want to come with me...

I hugged it one last time then picked myself up off the floor. I walked slowly, hesitantly, toward the button that would open the incinerator. It took more willpower than I've ever needed to press it. Then I picked up my Companion and held it over the flames. Tears clouded my vision and my hands began to sweat uncontrollably, and not just from the heat. I held it there for what seemed like hours, just crying and admiring its beauty. But then I remember the Cake. And the Cube slipped from my hands.

"You euthanized your faithful Companion Cube more quickly than any test subject on record," said my boss. "Congratulations."

11/10 would euthanize my Companion at the behest of my boss and all for a piece of cake again.

[b]Summary:[/b]
[i]Portal 2[/i] is excellent! For everything that made [i]Portal[/i] good, [i]Portal 2[/i] improved upon, including once again fabulous writing and puzzles.

[b]My Experience:[/b]
[i]Portal 2[/i] is a truly awesome game. A highly polished sequel to [i]Portal[/i], it gave everything fans wanted - an improvement to not only design, puzzles, and story, but also to the programming, feel, and performance. It continues to exceed standards in writing and humor, and the puzzles are even better designed than its predecessor. Now, it also has co-op! Like every game, this one is not flawless. However, it lived up to expectations and continues to be fun and hold a community years later. 

[b]My Recommendation:[/b]
[i]Portal 2[/i] is a great game, and I highly recommend it. If you have any interest in puzzle games, I think this game is a must. Of course, I recommend the wait for a good sale.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

If you enjoy games then this game will be right up your game!  This game is a game.  Now here's the thing... this game is a BIT of a game.  Now listen, I know that sounds bad, but this game is like the game of games, okay?  On the plus side though, the game has a lot of qualities you could probably call game-like.  Some might disagree with that I suppose, but I think it's very fair to call this a game, especially considering the sheer amount of game in this game.  Honestly, when you think about it, this game is really similar to a game in a lot of ways.  For example, it's a game, and I think that really says it all right there.  Let me explain... this game is like if a game and a game had a baby, and it's remarkably game.  Overall, I have very few problems with the game sections of this game, it's really just the small more game parts of the game that just irked me a little.  I'm sorry you had to hear it from me, but this is a game.  My sincerest apologies to anyone that didn't expect that this game would be such a game but that's just the hard truth.  I recommend this game for its game qualities and I think you should purchase this game.  Watch out for the secret Easter egg in level game.  SPOILER ALERT!!! It's a game.

This is a great game. It's a continuation of Portal, but it's so much better and longer. For the first half of the game, you go through test chambers, but this time, you're not alone. One of the personality cores, Wheatly, tags along, pretending to be your helpful companion, to take down GLaDOS. It works, but Wheatly becomes mad with power and takes over the facility, but not before putting GLaDOS' core into a potato battery. Anyway, for the second half of the game, you go through more test chambers, reunite with GLaDOS, now potatOS, go through even more test chambers, and defeat Wheatly before the facility explodes. There's also a brand new Co-Op mode with its own story, and a puzzle editor where you can create your own puzzles, upload them to the Steam Workshop, and play them with friends. Overall, this game offers many hours of fun, unique and challenging gameplay.

portal 2 is the best game ever made, and no one can tell me otherwise. the writing is hilarious and the characters are very enjoyable to watch. the environment and atmosphere in this game is rivaled only by bioshock. the soundtrack perfectly matches the game, and the ambient noise, especially when down in old Aperture, is on point it really makes the game feel lived in and helps portray a sense of loneliness and desolation to the player. the mystery surrounding the early days of Aperture is truly amazing, and can be uncovered by looking at the environment around you and thinking a little more deeply about some of the pre-recorded messages left for you by Aperture's late founder, Cave Johnson. this is a much better way of showing the history than just outright telling you. there are also many easter eggs in this game, and many are hilarious to longtime valve fans, but will go right over the head of a less involved fan. overall a 10/10 play and to anyone thinking about getting the game, just get it, its 5 dollars and an amazing game.

It's Portal. What do you expect? Note: this review is based on the singleplayer alone.

Pros:
- the writing is every bit as sharp as you'd expect, and in comparison to the original there's a lot more of it this time, and every bit of it is a delight
- the voice actors (all 3 of them) do an absolutely fantastic job, but the highlight here is still J.K. Simmons
- the puzzles stay consistent in quality throughout, and it never feels like you're treading familiar ground
- there are new additional elements to the puzzles that add entire new mind-bending dimensions to the game
- the physics setpieces still manage to look impressive a decade later
- the great art direction makes the game look great to this day, despite certain sections looking a lot more dated than others
- there is actually a story this time, with more concrete stakes and a lot more worldbuilding alongside it, all peppered with delightful pitch-black humor

Cons:

- some transition sections are incredibly linear, and go on maybe a bit too long
- some sections in the middle part of the game have huge amounts of empty space, leading to the player searching mindlessly for possible hidden elements. I was stuck in one puzzle for about an hour because the game didn't explain one mechanic (the carrying of momentum when jumping from propulstion gel) properly
- the final encounter feels maybe a tad too easy for a 7-8 hour game
- the ending song is great, but can't hold a candle to the bittersweet charm of the classic "Still Alive"

A few blemishes aside, this is every bit as good as the original Portal, and even better in certain respects. Do yourself a favor and play it

I like puzzle games. They are generally small games with colorful graphics, which offer puzzles to solve or traps to deconstruct to reach the next level, and they make me spend pleasant moments during the hours I spend in public transport.
Portal 2 (preceded by Portal, or even alone) is of a completely different dimension. First of all, we are immersed in the action: we no longer drag / open / pair virtual elements, we find ourselves really represented by this female character, as in a role-playing game, and it is she who must open passages, avoid turret fire, advance, progress, take lifts or escape... This makes the experience all the more fun as you don't feel like playing a puzzle game. This is very close from an adventure game, and even players who are not at all attracted by puzzles may find this game very interesting. The background story is engaging, very imaginative, and there are "Easter eggs" and nods to other Valve games (Half Life). For puzzle enthusiasts, the editor allows you to create and submit puzzles to the community, providing you with as much material as you want to continue "testing" long time after you finished the game. And of course, the cooperative mode allows two people to test their brain together, the hardest part being to decide who will be represented by which robot... In short, Portal 2 is an investment you can't regret.
Positive points: the rich story, the tests (more complex than in Portal 1), the long break in the old test rooms, the unexpected twists, the length of the game, the very realistic 3D graphics, the coop mode, the editor...
Negative points: Uh...

Very good overall, just like the first game. The puzzles are good from start to finish, and the newer things in the second half keep things fresh. The dry, sarcastic, and sometimes bad humour keeps it from getting too serious and just works. My one complaint is the same that I had with the first Portal. You go from having very defined progression to being completely in the dark, and in Portal 2 that cycle repeats. I don't think you need to know exactly how far along you are in a game at all times, but it's somewhat annoying when you think you're almost done and still have half the game left. It's definitely not a dealbreaker; just a little annoyance worth mentioning.

Portal 2 is a masterpiece of not only the world of gaming, but is also a masterpiece of the world of storytelling. As you make your way through the test chambers, you get a further look into the backstory of Aperature. The funny moments (which are luckily funny instead of 'ah yes joke for kids, now lets get some money') do not get in the way of the serious moments, which you'll have to play this game to see. If you have ever played Undertale by Toby Fox, you will know just how special it can be if you have characters that feel real, instead of your common Skyrim NPC. Valve accomplishes this in what seems to be effortless, enhancing the story even further.

Spoiler ahead, watch out if you haven't played this game.






At the final battle when we see Wheatley mad with power, we make the decision to shoot a portal into the moon, sucking his core into the vacuum of space. I can't speak for everyone else, but for me this felt like the death of a real being. Chell finally escapes, and GLAdoS is left to test with Atlas and P-body for the rest of time. The ending is bittersweet, considering there will probably never be a Portal 3 game in the future, but I can safely say that this is one of the only games that really had an impact on me as a person. Valve truly outdid themselves with this one. Bravo.

Incredibly well designed and engaging. One of the most memorable experiences I've had playing [i]any[/i] game would have had to be in Portal 2. However, with that said, I do think that there are both positives and negatives in this game. 

First off, I don't think that it's the best game for speedrunning (because of how much dialogue is in the game), which is why mods have been made for that very purpose, however even though that was not Valve's initial concept, it still has that capability. The integration between the hl2 universe and the portal universe, (which was due to not having a large enough design team back when Portal 1 was still in development) actually played a very interesting role in this game, and the easter eggs that you find along the way accomidate for the players that find the Lore more interesting than the game and are just in it for the storyline. The puzzles aren't too challenging, however I will say there is copious amounts of dialogue in the game. So much so, that you can acquire many achievements for just sticking around long enough to hear it. 

I'd like to conclude by saying that this game is very well designed in all fields. Not only in the programming itself but in the music soundtrack, the Lore that was put in, as well as the physical characters and their voice lines. This game has something for everyone, whether you're a fan of Wheatly or more a fan of Glados, you still get equal amounts of exposure to both characters, leaving you with a very memorable experience.

[h1]The real deal[/h1]
This is Portal 2. It doesn't need any introduction simply because Portal 1 already set the bar, making it a classic; but there are some things which are worth noting. 

As always my reviews are more like a personal thought on something which intrigues me rather than an analysis.

If you're interested on reading my thoughts about the first one, you can click here:
https://steamcommunity.com/id/bodolovsello/recommended/400/

[h3]Original twists on classic Portal mechanics[/h3]
That's right. Core gameplay remains the same while revamping some mechanics. In fact here not only you'll have turrets, portals and platforms but even various gels which can alter your jumping abilities and movement speed.

I feel that puzzle-wise the overrall level design of the campaign has improved quite a bit, involving areas in a more vast scale.

[h3]Lore-amplified[/h3]
What do I mean by [i]amplified[/i]? Well, apart from the opening sequence (which is iconic in game history), the whole game feels like a massive improvement applied to its storytelling, dialogue and lore. 

In fact we'll venture across the old Aperture Laboratories, listening to Audio Logs from Cave Johnson (founder of Aperture) as well as having a more in-depth look at GLaDOS and her personality.

Being able to walk through the old Aperture felt somewhat new, refreshing and I was honestly curious to just look around me.

[h3]Dialogues, again[/h3]
I can't stress this enough. Dialogues in Portal were interesting and well written, but here I think Valve actually overdone itself by adding a lot more movement into them. 

I think adding Wheatley was an interesting move, mainly because we have a back and forth between GLaDOS and him and, thanks to the excellent voice acting, it works flawlessly.

Plus, the extra voice lines when you stand still while waiting to do things as requested by GLaDOS or Wheatley are worth the wait.

[h3]Something which bothered me[/h3]
While I really liked the game, I can't say I really enjoyed that one bit where Cave Johnson talks about lemonade, where you have to use the white gel to create portals. I honestly didn't enjoy solving that puzzle not only because it felt frustrating, but also unclear. It's really nothing gamebreaking, really, but it bothered me because every other level seemed always like an interesting idea and had a clear, logical structure to it. Could be me of course, but still, that's my experience.

[h3]Portal 2 retains an attractive look, even after 10 years[/h3]
Maybe it's because there are no facial animations involved or because the environment is modern and simplistic, but I always enjoyed Portal's graphics. I just finished it again before sitting down here writing this review and I must say that it still feels pleaseant to watch.

My only complaints could be the pre-rendered cutscenes: were them really necessary? I think it's somewhat that the ending is a little immersive-breaking because you notice right away the passage from in-game graphics to cgi.

I won't state this as a negative aspect though, mainly because there are so many good animations during the campaign that I can't really complain.

[h2]A worthy successor, if not a better one[/h2]
Portal 2 is indeed a really good sequel and not only it expands its story in an interesting way, but even lasts longer than its predecessor. It improves the formula in every aspect, so... What is there to say, if not "buy it". 

Recommended!

Also, check out my other reviews here on steam:
https://steamcommunity.com/id/bodolovsello/recommended/

This game has an amazing story that kept me so tied in that I would be caught playing for hours on end, and I enjoyed every second of it. It legitimately depresses me that no game will give me the same feeling that Portal has given me ever again. The entire atmosphere of this game makes you feel like you are alone, with incredible views and silence in most parts of the game, which I happen to love. When there are characters, they have lovable voices and personalities that keep you engaged to listen to their back and forth witty comments. The game play is of course, incredible. Even when I was stuck on some of the puzzles, the game managed to keep me fighting on and trying again. Valve has done a great job of using the materials they created to make new and exotic puzzles over and over again. If you read this review and want to see the game, please do not watch any game play or get spoiled in any way whatsoever. This is an experience you want to have on your own, and one you will miss when it is over. Thank you valve, for this masterpiece.

Presently an impression based on the first half of the single player campaign:
Portal 2 disappoints with a lot of fake tension and by removing your own actions from the center of the story. The main characters are GladOS and Wheatley, not you, you are just trapped stringing along their character moments.

When Bureaucracy Core comes off his rails, you are fastened into your own railroad and the game represents its direction by taking up the center of your view for a while with his "face" making it difficult to focus on where you're going.

Once you get to puzzles, the puzzles are still good.

The story the game is occasionally lauded for, though? Probably over half the time you're being urgently called to run or take some next action, it is completely impossible to fail. You can just sit there, and you will not die unless you find a ledge not covered in invisible walls (there are excessive amounts of invisible walls "protecting" you from drops, fires, being crushed by those wall panels that move) to jump off or something. There is nowhere else you can go, and nothing else you can possibly do. And the game, voiced by Wheatley, will just Not. Stop. Nagging your ear off.

Once there was a facility to escape where you had to figure out how to transfer the thinking-with-portals you had learned to do into an environment that felt much more complex and free-roaming. Once there was more consistency in light walls being portal-compatible and dark walls not. Once there was a game where you were the hero, cleverly navigating a dangerous environment with your wits and an experimental portal gun.

... Now you're barely given any space to explore in, nor three seconds to think and enjoy it, if the game has decided this segment is meant to be "high intensity". But it doesn't have the guts to let you fail.

Around where I got so sick of Blue Bubbles pleading me every few seconds for several MINUTES to get in an elevator after wresting control away from GladOS that I finally did... only to have him THEN finally rethink whether he wanted me to in order to bring me down to be a captive audience to his self-indulgent melodrama acting out the hammiest of face-heel-turns I was feeling like... I'm not sure whether I am even going to care enough to get through this.

From time to time I saw a way to go quickly, and got excited feeling as though it might be a branching path, but when I turned around to check what might have been the other way, it was always an immediate dead end. Nope, no room for divergence here. Not every game has to have branching paths of course, but it just got so stale sometimes how short and pointless so many of the dead ends were - very little even there to see.

It could have been so much more, but it forgot to respect the player enough to let them have any difficulty outside of carefully marked Puzzle Zones, and the tension and menace just completely falls apart when it's so easy to see through. A tragic answer to a great original.

This was one of those games which I had heard a lot about but never played; it had co-op so I got it to play with a friend. Initially I only played the co-op which was really fun and gave a great sense of satisfaction once we figured out a challenging puzzle- since I enjoyed it so much I decided to try out the single player (I realise the co-op story is based after the single player story now). The world building in this game is phenomenal, every single character is wonderful and really add to the story, even the world building through easter eggs and the comic give this game and its story so much depth; the puzzles gradually get more complex and slowly introduce different mechanics while still maintaining the simple idea of only having two portals to work with- each puzzle presents its own unique challenge and they vary enough that they never become boring or tiresome. This game was a pleasure to play and it deserves every ounce of love from its community, I can't believe I waited this long to try it.

This game is so innovative and fun, definitely a classic. The co-op mode is incredibly well executed, and I had so much fun playing this game with one of my friends. The story line is great, and the levels are designed spectacularly around the plot's development. The levels can be challenging, but are never too difficult. It's lots of fun and very relieving to figure out the solution to a puzzle, especially with a friend. On top of the two different campaigns in the game, there are plenty of extremely entertaining workshop maps and a pretty easy-to-use level editor. I strongly recommend Portal 2, and if at all possible, get a friend and play co-op. The game is super well made, and contains hours of fun. I've never met someone who disliked it.
